When the old lady had\r\nexpatiated, a long time, on the excellences of her children, and the\r\nmerits of her kind good husband besides, who had been dead and gone,\r\npoor dear soul! just six-and-twenty years, it was time to have tea.\r\nAfter tea she began to teach Oliver cribbage: which he learnt as\r\nquickly as she could teach: and at which game they played, with great\r\ninterest and gravity, until it was time for the invalid to have some\r\nwarm wine and water, with a slice of dry toast, and then to go cosily\r\nto bed.\r\n\r\nThey were happy days, those of Oliver\xe2\x80\x99s recovery. Everything was so\r\nquiet, and neat, and orderly; everybody so kind and gentle; that after\r\nthe noise and turbulence in the midst of which he had always lived, it\r\nseemed like Heaven itself. He was no sooner strong enough to put his\r\nclothes on, properly, than Mr. Brownlow caused a complete new suit, and\r\na new cap, and a new pair of shoes, to be provided for him. As Oliver\r\nwas told that he might do what he liked with the old clothes, he gave\r\nthem to a servant who had been very kind to him, and asked her to sell\r\nthem to a Jew, and keep the money for herself. This she very readily\r\ndid; and, as Oliver looked out of the parlour window, and saw the Jew\r\nroll them up in his bag and walk away, he felt quite delighted to think\r\nthat they were safely gone, and that there was now no possible danger\r\nof his ever being able to wear them again. They were sad rags, to tell\r\nthe truth; and Oliver had never had a new suit before.\r\n\r\nOne evening, about a week after the affair of the picture, as he was\r\nsitting talking to Mrs. Bedwin, there came a message down from Mr.\r\nBrownlow, that if Oliver Twist felt pretty well, he should like to see\r\nhim in his study, and talk to him a little while.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBless us, and save us! Wash your hands, and let me part your hair\r\nnicely for you, child,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Bedwin. \xe2\x80\x9cDear heart alive! If we had\r\nknown he would have asked for you, we would have put you a clean collar\r\non, and made you as smart as sixpence!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOliver did as the old lady bade him; and, although she lamented\r\ngrievously, meanwhile, that there was not even time to crimp the little\r\nfrill that bordered his shirt-collar; he looked so delicate and\r\nhandsome, despite that important personal advantage, that she went so\r\nfar as to say: looking at him with great complacency from head to foot,\r\nthat she really didn\xe2\x80\x99t think it would have been possible, on the\r\nlongest notice, to have made much difference in him for the better.\r\n\r\nThus encouraged, Oliver tapped at the study door. On Mr. Brownlow\r\ncalling to him to come in, he found himself in a little back room,\r\nquite full of books, with a window, looking into some pleasant little\r\ngardens. There was a table drawn up before the window, at which Mr.\r\nBrownlow was seated reading. When he saw Oliver, he pushed the book\r\naway from him, and told him to come near the table, and sit down.\r\nOliver complied; marvelling where the people could be found to read\r\nsuch a great number of books as seemed to be written to make the world\r\nwiser. Which is still a marvel to more experienced people than Oliver\r\nTwist, every day of their lives.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere are a good many books, are there not, my boy?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr.\r\nBrownlow, observing the curiosity with which Oliver surveyed the\r\nshelves that reached from the floor to the ceiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA great number, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Oliver. \xe2\x80\x9cI never saw so many.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou shall read them, if you behave well,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old gentleman\r\nkindly; \xe2\x80\x9cand you will like that, better than looking at the\r\noutsides,\xe2\x80\x94that is, some cases; because there are books of which the\r\nbacks and covers are by far the best parts.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI suppose they are those heavy ones, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Oliver, pointing to\r\nsome large quartos, with a good deal of gilding about the binding.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot always those,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old gentleman, patting Oliver on the head,\r\nand smiling as he did so; \xe2\x80\x9cthere are other equally heavy ones, though\r\nof a much smaller size. How should you like to grow up a clever man,\r\nand write books, eh?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think I would rather read them, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Oliver.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t you like to be a book-writer?\xe2\x80\x9d said the old gentleman.\r\n\r\nOliver considered a little while; and at last said, he should think it\r\nwould be a much better thing to be a book-seller; upon which the old\r\ngentleman laughed heartily, and declared he had said a very good thing.\r\nWhich Oliver felt glad to have done, though he by no means knew what it\r\nwas.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, well,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old gentleman, composing his features. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t be\r\nafraid! We won\xe2\x80\x99t make an author of you, while there\xe2\x80\x99s an honest trade\r\nto be learnt, or brick-making to turn to.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Oliver. At the earnest manner of his reply, the\r\nold gentleman laughed again; and said something about a curious\r\ninstinct, which Oliver, not understanding, paid no very great attention\r\nto.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Brownlow, speaking if possible in a kinder, but at the\r\nsame time in a much more serious manner, than Oliver had ever known him\r\nassume yet, \xe2\x80\x9cI want you to pay great attention, my boy, to what I am\r\ngoing to say. I shall talk to you without any reserve; because I am\r\nsure you are well able to understand me, as many older persons would\r\nbe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, don\xe2\x80\x99t tell you are going to send me away, sir, pray!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed\r\nOliver, alarmed at the serious tone of the old gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncommencement! \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t turn me out of doors to wander in the streets\r\nagain. Let me stay here, and be a servant. Don\xe2\x80\x99t send me back to the\r\nwretched place I came from. Have mercy upon a poor boy, sir!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear child,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old gentleman, moved by the warmth of\r\nOliver\xe2\x80\x99s sudden appeal; \xe2\x80\x9cyou need not be afraid of my deserting you,\r\nunless you give me cause.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never, never will, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d interposed Oliver.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope not,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined the old gentleman. \xe2\x80\x9cI do not think you ever\r\nwill. I have been deceived, before, in the objects whom I have\r\nendeavoured to benefit; but I feel strongly disposed to trust you,\r\nnevertheless; and I am more interested in your behalf than I can well\r\naccount for, even to myself. The persons on whom I have bestowed my\r\ndearest love, lie deep in their graves; but, although the happiness and\r\ndelight of my life lie buried there too, I have not made a coffin of my\r\nheart, and sealed it up, forever, on my best affections. Deep\r\naffliction has but strengthened and refined them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs the old gentleman said this in a low voice: more to himself than to\r\nhis companion: and as he remained silent for a short time afterwards:\r\nOliver sat quite still.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, well!\xe2\x80\x9d said the old gentleman at length, in a more cheerful\r\ntone, \xe2\x80\x9cI only say this, because you have a young heart; and knowing\r\nthat I have suffered great pain and sorrow, you will be more careful,\r\nperhaps, not to wound me again. You say you are an orphan, without a\r\nfriend in the world; all the inquiries I have been able to make,\r\nconfirm the statement. Let me hear your story; where you come from; who\r\nbrought you up; and how you got into the company in which I found you.\r\nSpeak the truth, and you shall not be friendless while I live.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOliver\xe2\x80\x99s sobs checked his utterance for some minutes; when he was on\r\nthe point of beginning to relate how he had been brought up at the\r\nfarm, and carried to the workhouse by Mr. Bumble, a peculiarly\r\nimpatient little double-knock was heard at the street-door: and the\r\nservant, running upstairs, announced Mr. Grimwig.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs he coming up?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Mr. Brownlow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the servant. \xe2\x80\x9cHe asked if there were any muffins in\r\nthe house; and, when I told him yes, he said he had come to tea.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Brownlow smiled; and, turning to Oliver, said that Mr. Grimwig was\r\nan old friend of his, and he must not mind his being a little rough in\r\nhis manners; for he was a worthy creature at bottom, as he had reason\r\nto know.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall I go downstairs, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Oliver.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mr. Brownlow, \xe2\x80\x9cI would rather you remained here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this moment, there walked into the room: supporting himself by a\r\nthick stick: a stout old gentleman, rather lame in one leg, who was\r\ndressed in a blue coat, striped waistcoat, nankeen breeches and\r\ngaiters, and a broad-brimmed white hat, with the sides turned up with\r\ngreen. A very small-plaited shirt frill stuck out from his waistcoat;\r\nand a very long steel watch-chain, with nothing but a key at the end,\r\ndangled loosely below it. The ends of his white neckerchief were\r\ntwisted into a ball about the size of an orange; the variety of shapes\r\ninto which his countenance was twisted, defy description. He had a\r\nmanner of screwing his head on one side when he spoke; and of looking\r\nout of the corners of his eyes at the same time: which irresistibly\r\nreminded the beholder of a parrot. In this attitude, he fixed himself,\r\nthe moment he made his appearance; and, holding out a small piece of\r\norange-peel at arm\xe2\x80\x99s length, exclaimed, in a growling, discontented\r\nvoice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook here! do you see this! Isn\xe2\x80\x99t it a most wonderful and\r\nextraordinary thing that I can\xe2\x80\x99t call at a man\xe2\x80\x99s house but I find a\r\npiece of this poor surgeon\xe2\x80\x99s friend on the staircase? I\xe2\x80\x99ve been lamed\r\nwith orange-peel once, and I know orange-peel will be my death, or I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nbe content to eat my own head, sir!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis was the handsome offer with which Mr. Grimwig backed and confirmed\r\nnearly every assertion he made; and it was the more singular in his\r\ncase, because, even admitting for the sake of argument, the possibility\r\nof scientific improvements being brought to that pass which will enable\r\na gentleman to eat his own head in the event of his being so disposed,\r\nMr. Grimwig\xe2\x80\x99s head was such a particularly large one, that the most\r\nsanguine man alive could hardly entertain a hope of being able to get\r\nthrough it at a sitting\xe2\x80\x94to put entirely out of the question, a very\r\nthick coating of powder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll eat my head, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Mr. Grimwig, striking his stick upon\r\nthe ground. \xe2\x80\x9cHallo! what\xe2\x80\x99s that!\xe2\x80\x9d looking at Oliver, and retreating a\r\npace or two.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is young Oliver Twist, whom we were speaking about,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr.\r\nBrownlow.\r\n\r\nOliver bowed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t mean to say that\xe2\x80\x99s the boy who had the fever, I hope?\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nMr. Grimwig, recoiling a little more. \xe2\x80\x9cWait a minute! Don\xe2\x80\x99t speak!\r\nStop\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d continued Mr. Grimwig, abruptly, losing all dread of the fever\r\nin his triumph at the discovery; \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s the boy who had the orange! If\r\nthat\xe2\x80\x99s not the boy, sir, who had the orange, and threw this bit of peel\r\nupon the staircase, I\xe2\x80\x99ll eat my head, and his too.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no, he has not had one,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Brownlow, laughing. \xe2\x80\x9cCome! Put\r\ndown your hat; and speak to my young friend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI feel strongly on this subject, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said the irritable old\r\ngentleman, drawing off his gloves. \xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s always more or less\r\norange-peel on the pavement in our street; and I _know_ it\xe2\x80\x99s put there\r\nby the surgeon\xe2\x80\x99s boy at the corner. A young woman stumbled over a bit\r\nlast night, and fell against my garden-railings; directly she got up I\r\nsaw her look towards his infernal red lamp with the pantomime-light.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t go to him,\xe2\x80\x99 I called out of the window, \xe2\x80\x98he\xe2\x80\x99s an assassin! A\r\nman-trap!\xe2\x80\x99 So he is. If he is not\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d Here the irascible old gentleman\r\ngave a great knock on the ground with his stick; which was always\r\nunderstood, by his friends, to imply the customary offer, whenever it\r\nwas not expressed in words. Then, still keeping his stick in his hand,\r\nhe sat down; and, opening a double eye-glass, which he wore attached to\r\na broad black riband, took a view of Oliver: who, seeing that he was\r\nthe object of inspection, coloured, and bowed again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s the boy, is it?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Grimwig, at length.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s the boy,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mr. Brownlow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow are you, boy?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Grimwig.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA great deal better, thank you, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Oliver.\r\n\r\nMr. Brownlow, seeming to apprehend that his singular friend was about\r\nto say something disagreeable, asked Oliver to step downstairs and tell\r\nMrs. Bedwin they were ready for tea; which, as he did not half like the\r\nvisitor\xe2\x80\x99s manner, he was very happy to do.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is a nice-looking boy, is he not?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Mr. Brownlow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mr. Grimwig, pettishly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t know?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know. I never see any difference in boys. I only knew two\r\nsort of boys. Mealy boys, and beef-faced boys.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd which is Oliver?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMealy. I know a friend who has a beef-faced boy; a fine boy, they call\r\nhim; with a round head, and red cheeks, and glaring eyes; a horrid boy;\r\nwith a body and limbs that appear to be swelling out of the seams of\r\nhis blue clothes; with the voice of a pilot, and the appetite of a\r\nwolf. I know him! The wretch!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Brownlow, \xe2\x80\x9cthese are not the characteristics of young\r\nOliver Twist; so he needn\xe2\x80\x99t excite your wrath.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are not,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mr. Grimwig. \xe2\x80\x9cHe may have worse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHere, Mr. Brownlow coughed impatiently; which appeared to afford Mr.\r\nGrimwig the most exquisite delight.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe may have worse, I say,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Mr. Grimwig. \xe2\x80\x9cWhere does he come\r\nfrom! Who is he? What is he? He has had a fever. What of that? Fevers\r\nare not peculiar to good people; are they? Bad people have fevers\r\nsometimes; haven\xe2\x80\x99t they, eh? I knew a man who was hung in Jamaica for\r\nmurdering his master. He had had a fever six times; he wasn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nrecommended to mercy on that account. Pooh! nonsense!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNow, the fact was, that in the inmost recesses of his own heart, Mr.\r\nGrimwig was strongly disposed to admit that Oliver\xe2\x80\x99s appearance and\r\nmanner were unusually prepossessing; but he had a strong appetite for\r\ncontradiction, sharpened on this occasion by the finding of the\r\norange-peel; and, inwardly determining that no man should dictate to\r\nhim whether a boy was well-looking or not, he had resolved, from the\r\nfirst, to oppose his friend. When Mr. Brownlow admitted that on no one\r\npoint of inquiry could he yet return a satisfactory answer; and that he\r\nhad postponed any investigation into Oliver\xe2\x80\x99s previous history until he\r\nthought the boy was strong enough to hear it; Mr. Grimwig chuckled\r\nmaliciously. And he demanded, with a sneer, whether the housekeeper was\r\nin the habit of counting the plate at night; because if she didn\xe2\x80\x99t find\r\na table-spoon or two missing some sunshiny morning, why, he would be\r\ncontent to\xe2\x80\x94and so forth.\r\n\r\nAll this, Mr. Brownlow, although himself somewhat of an impetuous\r\ngentleman: knowing his friend\xe2\x80\x99s peculiarities, bore with great good\r\nhumour; as Mr. Grimwig, at tea, was graciously pleased to express his\r\nentire approval of the muffins, matters went on very smoothly; and\r\nOliver, who made one of the party, began to feel more at his ease than\r\nhe had yet done in the fierce old gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s presence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd when are you going to hear a full, true, and particular account of\r\nthe life and adventures of Oliver Twist?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Grimwig of Mr.\r\nBrownlow, at the conclusion of the meal; looking sideways at Oliver, as\r\nhe resumed his subject.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo-morrow morning,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mr. Brownlow. \xe2\x80\x9cI would rather he was alone\r\nwith me at the time. Come up to me to-morrow morning at ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock, my\r\ndear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Oliver. He answered with some hesitation, because\r\nhe was confused by Mr. Grimwig\xe2\x80\x99s looking so hard at him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you what,\xe2\x80\x9d whispered that gentleman to Mr. Brownlow; \xe2\x80\x9che\r\nwon\xe2\x80\x99t come up to you to-morrow morning. I saw him hesitate. He is\r\ndeceiving you, my good friend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll swear he is not,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mr. Brownlow, warmly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf he is not,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Grimwig, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d and down went the stick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll answer for that boy\xe2\x80\x99s truth with my life!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Brownlow,\r\nknocking the table.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I for his falsehood with my head!\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined Mr. Grimwig, knocking\r\nthe table also.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall see,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Brownlow, checking his rising anger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe will,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mr. Grimwig, with a provoking smile; \xe2\x80\x9cwe will.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs fate would have it, Mrs. Bedwin chanced to bring in, at this moment,\r\na small parcel of books, which Mr. Brownlow had that morning purchased\r\nof the identical bookstall-keeper, who has already figured in this\r\nhistory; having laid them on the table, she prepared to leave the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStop the boy, Mrs. Bedwin!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Brownlow; \xe2\x80\x9cthere is something to\r\ngo back.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe has gone, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mrs. Bedwin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCall after him,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Brownlow; \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s particular. He is a poor\r\nman, and they are not paid for. There are some books to be taken back,\r\ntoo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe street-door was opened. Oliver ran one way; and the girl ran\r\nanother; and Mrs. Bedwin stood on the step and screamed for the boy;\r\nbut there was no boy in sight. Oliver and the girl returned, in a\r\nbreathless state, to report that there were no tidings of him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear me, I am very sorry for that,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Mr. Brownlow; \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nparticularly wished those books to be returned to-night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSend Oliver with them,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Grimwig, with an ironical smile; \xe2\x80\x9che\r\nwill be sure to deliver them safely, you know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; do let me take them, if you please, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Oliver. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll run\r\nall the way, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe old gentleman was just going to say that Oliver should not go out\r\non any account; when a most malicious cough from Mr. Grimwig determined\r\nhim that he should; and that, by his prompt discharge of the\r\ncommission, he should prove to him the injustice of his suspicions: on\r\nthis head at least: at once.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou _shall_ go, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old gentleman. \xe2\x80\x9cThe books are on a\r\nchair by my table. Fetch them down.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOliver, delighted to be of use, brought down the books under his arm in\r\na great bustle; and waited, cap in hand, to hear what message he was to\r\ntake.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are to say,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Brownlow, glancing steadily at Grimwig; \xe2\x80\x9cyou\r\nare to say that you have brought those books back; and that you have\r\ncome to pay the four pound ten I owe him. This is a five-pound note, so\r\nyou will have to bring me back, ten shillings change.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI won\xe2\x80\x99t be ten minutes, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Oliver, eagerly. Having buttoned up\r\nthe bank-note in his jacket pocket, and placed the books carefully\r\nunder his arm, he made a respectful bow, and left the room. Mrs. Bedwin\r\nfollowed him to the street-door, giving him many directions about the\r\nnearest way, and the name of the bookseller, and the name of the\r\nstreet: all of which Oliver said he clearly understood. Having\r\nsuperadded many injunctions to be sure and not take cold, the old lady\r\nat length permitted him to depart.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBless his sweet face!\xe2\x80\x9d said the old lady, looking after him. \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nbear, somehow, to let him go out of my sight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this moment, Oliver looked gaily round, and nodded before he turned\r\nthe corner. The old lady smilingly returned his salutation, and,\r\nclosing the door, went back to her own room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me see; he\xe2\x80\x99ll be back in twenty minutes, at the longest,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr.\r\nBrownlow, pulling out his watch, and placing it on the table. \xe2\x80\x9cIt will\r\nbe dark by that time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! you really expect him to come back, do you?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Mr. Grimwig.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Mr. Brownlow, smiling.\r\n\r\nThe spirit of contradiction was strong in Mr. Grimwig\xe2\x80\x99s breast, at the\r\nmoment; and it was rendered stronger by his friend\xe2\x80\x99s confident smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, smiting the table with his fist, \xe2\x80\x9cI do not. The boy has\r\na new suit of clothes on his back, a set of valuable books under his\r\narm, and a five-pound note in his pocket. He\xe2\x80\x99ll join his old friends\r\nthe thieves, and laugh at you. If ever that boy returns to this house,\r\nsir, I\xe2\x80\x99ll eat my head.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith these words he drew his chair closer to the table; and there the\r\ntwo friends sat, in silent expectation, with the watch between them.\r\n\r\nIt is worthy of remark, as illustrating the importance we attach to our\r\nown judgments, and the pride with which we put forth our most rash and\r\nhasty conclusions, that, although Mr. Grimwig was not by any means a\r\nbad-hearted man, and though he would have been unfeignedly sorry to see\r\nhis respected friend duped and deceived, he really did most earnestly\r\nand strongly hope at that moment, that Oliver Twist might not come\r\nback.\r\n\r\nIt grew so dark, that the figures on the dial-plate were scarcely\r\ndiscernible; but there the two old gentlemen continued to sit, in\r\nsilence, with the watch between them.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n CHAPTER XV.\r\nSHOWING HOW VERY FOND OF OLIVER TWIST, THE MERRY OLD JEW AND MISS NANCY\r\nWERE\r\n\r\n\r\nIn the obscure parlour of a low public-house, in the filthiest part of\r\nLittle Saffron Hill; a dark and gloomy den, where a flaring gas-light\r\nburnt all day in the winter-time; and where no ray of sun ever shone in\r\nthe summer: there sat, brooding over a little pewter measure and a\r\nsmall glass, strongly impregnated with the smell of liquor, a man in a\r\nvelveteen coat, drab shorts, half-boots and stockings, whom even by\r\nthat dim light no experienced agent of the police would have hesitated\r\nto recognise as Mr. William Sikes. At his feet, sat a white-coated,\r\nred-eyed dog; who occupied himself, alternately, in winking at his\r\nmaster with both eyes at the same time; and in licking a large, fresh\r\ncut on one side of his mouth, which appeared to be the result of some\r\nrecent conflict.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKeep quiet, you warmint! Keep quiet!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Sikes, suddenly\r\nbreaking silence. Whether his meditations were so intense as to be\r\ndisturbed by the dog\xe2\x80\x99s winking, or whether his feelings were so wrought\r\nupon by his reflections that they required all the relief derivable\r\nfrom kicking an unoffending animal to allay them, is matter for\r\nargument and consideration. Whatever was the cause, the effect was a\r\nkick and a curse, bestowed upon the dog simultaneously.\r\n\r\nDogs are not generally apt to revenge injuries inflicted upon them by\r\ntheir masters; but Mr. Sikes\xe2\x80\x99s dog, having faults of temper in common\r\nwith his owner, and labouring, perhaps, at this moment, under a\r\npowerful sense of injury, made no more ado but at once fixed his teeth\r\nin one of the half-boots. Having given in a hearty shake, he retired,\r\ngrowling, under a form; just escaping the pewter measure which Mr.\r\nSikes levelled at his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou would, would you?\xe2\x80\x9d said Sikes, seizing the poker in one hand, and\r\ndeliberately opening with the other a large clasp-knife, which he drew\r\nfrom his pocket. \xe2\x80\x9cCome here, you born devil! Come here! D\xe2\x80\x99ye hear?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe dog no doubt heard; because Mr. Sikes spoke in the very harshest\r\nkey of a very harsh voice; but, appearing to entertain some\r\nunaccountable objection to having his throat cut, he remained where he\r\nwas, and growled more fiercely than before: at the same time grasping\r\nthe end of the poker between his teeth, and biting at it like a wild\r\nbeast.\r\n\r\nThis resistance only infuriated Mr. Sikes the more; who, dropping on\r\nhis knees, began to assail the animal most furiously. The dog jumped\r\nfrom right to left, and from left to right; snapping, growling, and\r\nbarking; the man thrust and swore, and struck and blasphemed; and the\r\nstruggle was reaching a most critical point for one or other; when, the\r\ndoor suddenly opening, the dog darted out: leaving Bill Sikes with the\r\npoker and the clasp-knife in his hands.\r\n\r\nThere must always be two parties to a quarrel, says the old adage. Mr.\r\nSikes, being disappointed of the dog\xe2\x80\x99s participation, at once\r\ntransferred his share in the quarrel to the new comer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat the devil do you come in between me and my dog for?\xe2\x80\x9d said Sikes,\r\nwith a fierce gesture.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t know, my dear, I didn\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Fagin, humbly; for the\r\nJew was the new comer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDidn\xe2\x80\x99t know, you white-livered thief!\xe2\x80\x9d growled Sikes. \xe2\x80\x9cCouldn\xe2\x80\x99t you\r\nhear the noise?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot a sound of it, as I\xe2\x80\x99m a living man, Bill,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Jew.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh no! You hear nothing, you don\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d retorted Sikes with a fierce\r\nsneer. \xe2\x80\x9cSneaking in and out, so as nobody hears how you come or go! I\r\nwish you had been the dog, Fagin, half a minute ago.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the Jew with a forced smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCause the government, as cares for the lives of such men as you, as\r\nhaven\xe2\x80\x99t half the pluck of curs, lets a man kill a dog how he likes,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nreplied Sikes, shutting up the knife with a very expressive look;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s why.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Jew rubbed his hands; and, sitting down at the table, affected to\r\nlaugh at the pleasantry of his friend. He was obviously very ill at\r\nease, however.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGrin away,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sikes, replacing the poker, and surveying him with\r\nsavage contempt; \xe2\x80\x9cgrin away. You\xe2\x80\x99ll never have the laugh at me, though,\r\nunless it\xe2\x80\x99s behind a nightcap. I\xe2\x80\x99ve got the upper hand over you, Fagin;\r\nand, d\xe2\x80\x94me, I\xe2\x80\x99ll keep it. There! If I go, you go; so take care of me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, well, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, \xe2\x80\x9cI know all that; we\xe2\x80\x94we\xe2\x80\x94have a\r\nmutual interest, Bill,\xe2\x80\x94a mutual interest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHumph,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sikes, as if he thought the interest lay rather more on\r\nthe Jew\xe2\x80\x99s side than on his. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, what have you got to say to me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s all passed safe through the melting-pot,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Fagin, \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\nthis is your share. It\xe2\x80\x99s rather more than it ought to be, my dear; but\r\nas I know you\xe2\x80\x99ll do me a good turn another time, and\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStow that gammon,\xe2\x80\x9d interposed the robber, impatiently. \xe2\x80\x9cWhere is it?\r\nHand over!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, Bill; give me time, give me time,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Jew,\r\nsoothingly. \xe2\x80\x9cHere it is! All safe!\xe2\x80\x9d As he spoke, he drew forth an old\r\ncotton handkerchief from his breast; and untying a large knot in one\r\ncorner, produced a small brown-paper packet. Sikes, snatching it from\r\nhim, hastily opened it; and proceeded to count the sovereigns it\r\ncontained.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is all, is it?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Sikes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Jew.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou haven\xe2\x80\x99t opened the parcel and swallowed one or two as you come\r\nalong, have you?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Sikes, suspiciously. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t put on an\r\ninjured look at the question; you\xe2\x80\x99ve done it many a time. Jerk the\r\ntinkler.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThese words, in plain English, conveyed an injunction to ring the bell.\r\nIt was answered by another Jew: younger than Fagin, but nearly as vile\r\nand repulsive in appearance.\r\n\r\nBill Sikes merely pointed to the empty measure. The Jew, perfectly\r\nunderstanding the hint, retired to fill it: previously exchanging a\r\nremarkable look with Fagin, who raised his eyes for an instant, as if\r\nin expectation of it, and shook his head in reply; so slightly that the\r\naction would have been almost imperceptible to an observant third\r\nperson. It was lost upon Sikes, who was stooping at the moment to tie\r\nthe boot-lace which the dog had torn. Possibly, if he had observed the\r\nbrief interchange of signals, he might have thought that it boded no\r\ngood to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs anybody here, Barney?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Fagin; speaking, now that that\r\nSikes was looking on, without raising his eyes from the ground.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDot a shoul,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Barney; whose words: whether they came from the\r\nheart or not: made their way through the nose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNobody?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Fagin, in a tone of surprise: which perhaps might\r\nmean that Barney was at liberty to tell the truth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDobody but Biss Dadsy,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Barney.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNancy!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Sikes. \xe2\x80\x9cWhere? Strike me blind, if I don\xe2\x80\x99t honour\r\nthat \xe2\x80\x99ere girl, for her native talents.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s bid havid a plate of boiled beef id the bar,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Barney.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSend her here,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sikes, pouring out a glass of liquor. \xe2\x80\x9cSend her\r\nhere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBarney looked timidly at Fagin, as if for permission; the Jew remaining\r\nsilent, and not lifting his eyes from the ground, he retired; and\r\npresently returned, ushering in Nancy; who was decorated with the\r\nbonnet, apron, basket, and street-door key, complete.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are on the scent, are you, Nancy?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Sikes, proffering the\r\nglass.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I am, Bill,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the young lady, disposing of its contents;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cand tired enough of it I am, too. The young brat\xe2\x80\x99s been ill and\r\nconfined to the crib; and\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, Nancy, dear!\xe2\x80\x9d said Fagin, looking up.\r\n\r\nNow, whether a peculiar contraction of the Jew\xe2\x80\x99s red eye-brows, and a\r\nhalf closing of his deeply-set eyes, warned Miss Nancy that she was\r\ndisposed to be too communicative, is not a matter of much importance.\r\nThe fact is all we need care for here; and the fact is, that she\r\nsuddenly checked herself, and with several gracious smiles upon Mr.\r\nSikes, turned the conversation to other matters. In about ten minutes\xe2\x80\x99\r\ntime, Mr. Fagin was seized with a fit of coughing; upon which Nancy\r\npulled her shawl over her shoulders, and declared it was time to go.\r\nMr. Sikes, finding that he was walking a short part of her way himself,\r\nexpressed his intention of accompanying her; they went away together,\r\nfollowed, at a little distant, by the dog, who slunk out of a back-yard\r\nas soon as his master was out of sight.\r\n\r\nThe Jew thrust his head out of the room door when Sikes had left it;\r\nlooked after him as he walked up the dark passage; shook his clenched\r\nfist; muttered a deep curse; and then, with a horrible grin, reseated\r\nhimself at the table; where he was soon deeply absorbed in the\r\ninteresting pages of the Hue-and-Cry.\r\n\r\nMeanwhile, Oliver Twist, little dreaming that he was within so very\r\nshort a distance of the merry old gentleman, was on his way to the\r\nbook-stall. When he got into Clerkenwell, he accidently turned down a\r\nby-street which was not exactly in his way; but not discovering his\r\nmistake until he had got half-way down it, and knowing it must lead in\r\nthe right direction, he did not think it worth while to turn back; and\r\nso marched on, as quickly as he could, with the books under his arm.\r\n\r\nHe was walking along, thinking how happy and contented he ought to\r\nfeel; and how much he would give for only one look at poor little Dick,\r\nwho, starved and beaten, might be weeping bitterly at that very moment;\r\nwhen he was startled by a young woman screaming out very loud. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, my\r\ndear brother!\xe2\x80\x9d And he had hardly looked up, to see what the matter was,\r\nwhen he was stopped by having a pair of arms thrown tight round his\r\nneck.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Oliver, struggling. \xe2\x80\x9cLet go of me. Who is it? What are\r\nyou stopping me for?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe only reply to this, was a great number of loud lamentations from\r\nthe young woman who had embraced him; and who had a little basket and a\r\nstreet-door key in her hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh my gracious!\xe2\x80\x9d said the young woman, \xe2\x80\x9cI have found him! Oh! Oliver!\r\nOliver! Oh you naughty boy, to make me suffer such distress on your\r\naccount! Come home, dear, come. Oh, I\xe2\x80\x99ve found him. Thank gracious\r\ngoodness heavins, I\xe2\x80\x99ve found him!\xe2\x80\x9d With these incoherent exclamations,\r\nthe young woman burst into another fit of crying, and got so dreadfully\r\nhysterical, that a couple of women who came up at the moment asked a\r\nbutcher\xe2\x80\x99s boy with a shiny head of hair anointed with suet, who was\r\nalso looking on, whether he didn\xe2\x80\x99t think he had better run for the\r\ndoctor. To which, the butcher\xe2\x80\x99s boy: who appeared of a lounging, not to\r\nsay indolent disposition: replied, that he thought not.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no, no, never mind,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young woman, grasping Oliver\xe2\x80\x99s hand;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m better now. Come home directly, you cruel boy! Come!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the young woman, \xe2\x80\x9che ran away, near a month ago,\r\nfrom his parents, who are hard-working and respectable people; and went\r\nand joined a set of thieves and bad characters; and almost broke his\r\nmother\xe2\x80\x99s heart.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYoung wretch!\xe2\x80\x9d said one woman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo home, do, you little brute,\xe2\x80\x9d said the other.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Oliver, greatly alarmed. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know her. I\r\nhaven\xe2\x80\x99t any sister, or father and mother either. I\xe2\x80\x99m an orphan; I live\r\nat Pentonville.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly hear him, how he braves it out!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the young woman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, it\xe2\x80\x99s Nancy!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Oliver; who now saw her face for the first\r\ntime; and started back, in irrepressible astonishment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see he knows me!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Nancy, appealing to the bystanders. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t help himself. Make him come home, there\xe2\x80\x99s good people, or he\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nkill his dear mother and father, and break my heart!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat the devil\xe2\x80\x99s this?\xe2\x80\x9d said a man, bursting out of a beer-shop, with\r\na white dog at his heels; \xe2\x80\x9cyoung Oliver! Come home to your poor mother,\r\nyou young dog! Come home directly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t belong to them. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know them. Help! help!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Oliver,\r\nstruggling in the man\xe2\x80\x99s powerful grasp.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHelp!\xe2\x80\x9d repeated the man. \xe2\x80\x9cYes; I\xe2\x80\x99ll help you, you young rascal! What\r\nbooks are these? You\xe2\x80\x99ve been a stealing \xe2\x80\x99em, have you? Give \xe2\x80\x99em here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nWith these words, the man tore the volumes from his grasp, and struck\r\nhim on the head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s right!\xe2\x80\x9d cried a looker-on, from a garret-window. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s the\r\nonly way of bringing him to his senses!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be sure!\xe2\x80\x9d cried a sleepy-faced carpenter, casting an approving look\r\nat the garret-window.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99ll do him good!\xe2\x80\x9d said the two women.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd he shall have it, too!\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined the man, administering another\r\nblow, and seizing Oliver by the collar. \xe2\x80\x9cCome on, you young villain!\r\nHere, Bull\xe2\x80\x99s-eye, mind him, boy! Mind him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWeak with recent illness; stupified by the blows and the suddenness of\r\nthe attack; terrified by the fierce growling of the dog, and the\r\nbrutality of the man; overpowered by the conviction of the bystanders\r\nthat he really was the hardened little wretch he was described to be;\r\nwhat could one poor child do! Darkness had set in; it was a low\r\nneighborhood; no help was near; resistance was useless. In another\r\nmoment he was dragged into a labyrinth of dark narrow courts, and was\r\nforced along them at a pace which rendered the few cries he dared to\r\ngive utterance to, unintelligible. It was of little moment, indeed,\r\nwhether they were intelligible or no; for there was nobody to care for\r\nthem, had they been ever so plain.\r\n\r\n\r\nThe gas-lamps were lighted; Mrs. Bedwin was waiting anxiously at the\r\nopen door; the servant had run up the street twenty times to see if\r\nthere were any traces of Oliver; and still the two old gentlemen sat,\r\nperseveringly, in the dark parlour, with the watch between them.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n CHAPTER XVI.\r\nRELATES WHAT BECAME OF OLIVER TWIST, AFTER HE HAD BEEN CLAIMED BY NANCY\r\n\r\n\r\nThe narrow streets and courts, at length, terminated in a large open\r\nspace; scattered about which, were pens for beasts, and other\r\nindications of a cattle-market. Sikes slackened his pace when they\r\nreached this spot: the girl being quite unable to support any longer,\r\nthe rapid rate at which they had hitherto walked. Turning to Oliver, he\r\nroughly commanded him to take hold of Nancy\xe2\x80\x99s hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you hear?\xe2\x80\x9d growled Sikes, as Oliver hesitated, and looked round.\r\n\r\nThey were in a dark corner, quite out of the track of passengers.\r\n\r\nOliver saw, but too plainly, that resistance would be of no avail. He\r\nheld out his hand, which Nancy clasped tight in hers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive me the other,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sikes, seizing Oliver\xe2\x80\x99s unoccupied hand.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere, Bull\xe2\x80\x99s-Eye!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe dog looked up, and growled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee here, boy!\xe2\x80\x9d said Sikes, putting his other hand to Oliver\xe2\x80\x99s throat;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cif he speaks ever so soft a word, hold him! D\xe2\x80\x99ye mind!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe dog growled again; and licking his lips, eyed Oliver as if he were\r\nanxious to attach himself to his windpipe without delay.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s as willing as a Christian, strike me blind if he isn\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nSikes, regarding the animal with a kind of grim and ferocious approval.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, you know what you\xe2\x80\x99ve got to expect, master, so call away as quick\r\nas you like; the dog will soon stop that game. Get on, young\xe2\x80\x99un!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBull\xe2\x80\x99s-eye wagged his tail in acknowledgment of this unusually\r\nendearing form of speech; and, giving vent to another admonitory growl\r\nfor the benefit of Oliver, led the way onward.\r\n\r\nIt was Smithfield that they were crossing, although it might have been\r\nGrosvenor Square, for anything Oliver knew to the contrary. The night\r\nwas dark and foggy. The lights in the shops could scarecely struggle\r\nthrough the heavy mist, which thickened every moment and shrouded the\r\nstreets and houses in gloom; rendering the strange place still stranger\r\nin Oliver\xe2\x80\x99s eyes; and making his uncertainty the more dismal and\r\ndepressing.\r\n\r\nThey had hurried on a few paces, when a deep church-bell struck the\r\nhour. With its first stroke, his two conductors stopped, and turned\r\ntheir heads in the direction whence the sound proceeded.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEight o\xe2\x80\x99clock, Bill,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nancy, when the bell ceased.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the good of telling me that; I can hear it, can\xe2\x80\x99t I!\xe2\x80\x9d replied\r\nSikes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wonder whether _they_ can hear it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nancy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course they can,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Sikes. \xe2\x80\x9cIt was Bartlemy time when I was\r\nshopped; and there warn\xe2\x80\x99t a penny trumpet in the fair, as I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nhear the squeaking on. Arter I was locked up for the night, the row and\r\ndin outside made the thundering old jail so silent, that I could almost\r\nhave beat my brains out against the iron plates of the door.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor fellow!\xe2\x80\x9d said Nancy, who still had her face turned towards the\r\nquarter in which the bell had sounded. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, Bill, such fine young chaps\r\nas them!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; that\xe2\x80\x99s all you women think of,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Sikes. \xe2\x80\x9cFine young\r\nchaps! Well, they\xe2\x80\x99re as good as dead, so it don\xe2\x80\x99t much matter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith this consolation, Mr. Sikes appeared to repress a rising tendency\r\nto jealousy, and, clasping Oliver\xe2\x80\x99s wrist more firmly, told him to step\r\nout again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait a minute!\xe2\x80\x9d said the girl: \xe2\x80\x9cI wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t hurry by, if it was you\r\nthat was coming out to be hung, the next time eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock struck,\r\nBill. I\xe2\x80\x99d walk round and round the place till I dropped, if the snow\r\nwas on the ground, and I hadn\xe2\x80\x99t a shawl to cover me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what good would that do?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the unsentimental Mr. Sikes.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUnless you could pitch over a file and twenty yards of good stout\r\nrope, you might as well be walking fifty mile off, or not walking at\r\nall, for all the good it would do me. Come on, and don\xe2\x80\x99t stand\r\npreaching there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe girl burst into a laugh; drew her shawl more closely round her; and\r\nthey walked away. But Oliver felt her hand tremble, and, looking up in\r\nher face as they passed a gas-lamp, saw that it had turned a deadly\r\nwhite.\r\n\r\nThey walked on, by little-frequented and dirty ways, for a full\r\nhalf-hour: meeting very few people, and those appearing from their\r\nlooks to hold much the same position in society as Mr. Sikes himself.\r\nAt length they turned into a very filthy narrow street, nearly full of\r\nold-clothes shops; the dog running forward, as if conscious that there\r\nwas no further occasion for his keeping on guard, stopped before the\r\ndoor of a shop that was closed and apparently untenanted; the house was\r\nin a ruinous condition, and on the door was nailed a board, intimating\r\nthat it was to let: which looked as if it had hung there for many\r\nyears.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Sikes, glancing cautiously about.\r\n\r\nNancy stooped below the shutters, and Oliver heard the sound of a bell.\r\nThey crossed to the opposite side of the street, and stood for a few\r\nmoments under a lamp. A noise, as if a sash window were gently raised,\r\nwas heard; and soon afterwards the door softly opened. Mr. Sikes then\r\nseized the terrified boy by the collar with very little ceremony; and\r\nall three were quickly inside the house.\r\n\r\nThe passage was perfectly dark. They waited, while the person who had\r\nlet them in, chained and barred the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnybody here?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Sikes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied a voice, which Oliver thought he had heard before.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs the old \xe2\x80\x99un here?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the robber.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the voice, \xe2\x80\x9cand precious down in the mouth he has been.\r\nWon\xe2\x80\x99t he be glad to see you? Oh, no!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe style of this reply, as well as the voice which delivered it,\r\nseemed familiar to Oliver\xe2\x80\x99s ears: but it was impossible to distinguish\r\neven the form of the speaker in the darkness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x99s have a glim,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sikes, \xe2\x80\x9cor we shall go breaking our necks, or\r\ntreading on the dog. Look after your legs if you do!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStand still a moment, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll get you one,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the voice. The\r\nreceding footsteps of the speaker were heard; and, in another minute,\r\nthe form of Mr. John Dawkins, otherwise the Artful Dodger, appeared. He\r\nbore in his right hand a tallow candle stuck in the end of a cleft\r\nstick.\r\n\r\nThe young gentleman did not stop to bestow any other mark of\r\nrecognition upon Oliver than a humourous grin; but, turning away,\r\nbeckoned the visitors to follow him down a flight of stairs. They\r\ncrossed an empty kitchen; and, opening the door of a low\r\nearthy-smelling room, which seemed to have been built in a small\r\nback-yard, were received with a shout of laughter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, my wig, my wig!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Master Charles Bates, from whose lungs the\r\nlaughter had proceeded: \xe2\x80\x9chere he is! oh, cry, here he is! Oh, Fagin,\r\nlook at him! Fagin, do look at him! I can\xe2\x80\x99t bear it; it is such a jolly\r\ngame, I can\xe2\x80\x99t bear it. Hold me, somebody, while I laugh it out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith this irrepressible ebullition of mirth, Master Bates laid himself\r\nflat on the floor: and kicked convulsively for five minutes, in an\r\nectasy of facetious joy. Then jumping to his feet, he snatched the\r\ncleft stick from the Dodger; and, advancing to Oliver, viewed him round\r\nand round; while the Jew, taking off his nightcap, made a great number\r\nof low bows to the bewildered boy. The Artful, meantime, who was of a\r\nrather saturnine disposition, and seldom gave way to merriment when it\r\ninterfered with business, rifled Oliver\xe2\x80\x99s pockets with steady\r\nassiduity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook at his togs, Fagin!\xe2\x80\x9d said Charley, putting the light so close to\r\nhis new jacket as nearly to set him on fire. \xe2\x80\x9cLook at his togs!\r\nSuperfine cloth, and the heavy swell cut! Oh, my eye, what a game! And\r\nhis books, too! Nothing but a gentleman, Fagin!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDelighted to see you looking so well, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, bowing\r\nwith mock humility. \xe2\x80\x9cThe Artful shall give you another suit, my dear,\r\nfor fear you should spoil that Sunday one. Why didn\xe2\x80\x99t you write, my\r\ndear, and say you were coming? We\xe2\x80\x99d have got something warm for\r\nsupper.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt his, Master Bates roared again: so loud, that Fagin himself relaxed,\r\nand even the Dodger smiled; but as the Artful drew forth the five-pound\r\nnote at that instant, it is doubtful whether the sally of the discovery\r\nawakened his merriment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHallo, what\xe2\x80\x99s that?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Sikes, stepping forward as the Jew\r\nseized the note. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s mine, Fagin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew. \xe2\x80\x9cMine, Bill, mine. You shall have the\r\nbooks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf that ain\xe2\x80\x99t mine!\xe2\x80\x9d said Bill Sikes, putting on his hat with a\r\ndetermined air; \xe2\x80\x9cmine and Nancy\xe2\x80\x99s that is; I\xe2\x80\x99ll take the boy back\r\nagain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Jew started. Oliver started too, though from a very different\r\ncause; for he hoped that the dispute might really end in his being\r\ntaken back.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome! Hand over, will you?\xe2\x80\x9d said Sikes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is hardly fair, Bill; hardly fair, is it, Nancy?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the\r\nJew.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFair, or not fair,\xe2\x80\x9d retorted Sikes, \xe2\x80\x9chand over, I tell you! Do you\r\nthink Nancy and me has got nothing else to do with our precious time\r\nbut to spend it in scouting arter, and kidnapping, every young boy as\r\ngets grabbed through you? Give it here, you avaricious old skeleton,\r\ngive it here!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith this gentle remonstrance, Mr. Sikes plucked the note from between\r\nthe Jew\xe2\x80\x99s finger and thumb; and looking the old man coolly in the face,\r\nfolded it up small, and tied it in his neckerchief.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s for our share of the trouble,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sikes; \xe2\x80\x9cand not half\r\nenough, neither. You may keep the books, if you\xe2\x80\x99re fond of reading. If\r\nyou ain\xe2\x80\x99t, sell \xe2\x80\x99em.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re very pretty,\xe2\x80\x9d said Charley Bates: who, with sundry grimaces,\r\nhad been affecting to read one of the volumes in question; \xe2\x80\x9cbeautiful\r\nwriting, isn\xe2\x80\x99t is, Oliver?\xe2\x80\x9d At sight of the dismayed look with which\r\nOliver regarded his tormentors, Master Bates, who was blessed with a\r\nlively sense of the ludicrous, fell into another ectasy, more\r\nboisterous than the first.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey belong to the old gentleman,\xe2\x80\x9d said Oliver, wringing his hands;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cto the good, kind, old gentleman who took me into his house, and had\r\nme nursed, when I was near dying of the fever. Oh, pray send them back;\r\nsend him back the books and money. Keep me here all my life long; but\r\npray, pray send them back. He\xe2\x80\x99ll think I stole them; the old lady: all\r\nof them who were so kind to me: will think I stole them. Oh, do have\r\nmercy upon me, and send them back!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith these words, which were uttered with all the energy of passionate\r\ngrief, Oliver fell upon his knees at the Jew\xe2\x80\x99s feet; and beat his hands\r\ntogether, in perfect desperation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe boy\xe2\x80\x99s right,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked Fagin, looking covertly round, and knitting\r\nhis shaggy eyebrows into a hard knot. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re right, Oliver, you\xe2\x80\x99re\r\nright; they _will_ think you have stolen \xe2\x80\x99em. Ha! ha!\xe2\x80\x9d chuckled the\r\nJew, rubbing his hands, \xe2\x80\x9cit couldn\xe2\x80\x99t have happened better, if we had\r\nchosen our time!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course it couldn\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Sikes; \xe2\x80\x9cI know\xe2\x80\x99d that, directly I see\r\nhim coming through Clerkenwell, with the books under his arm. It\xe2\x80\x99s all\r\nright enough. They\xe2\x80\x99re soft-hearted psalm-singers, or they wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have\r\ntaken him in at all; and they\xe2\x80\x99ll ask no questions after him, fear they\r\nshould be obliged to prosecute, and so get him lagged. He\xe2\x80\x99s safe\r\nenough.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOliver had looked from one to the other, while these words were being\r\nspoken, as if he were bewildered, and could scarecely understand what\r\npassed; but when Bill Sikes concluded, he jumped suddenly to his feet,\r\nand tore wildly from the room: uttering shrieks for help, which made\r\nthe bare old house echo to the roof.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKeep back the dog, Bill!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Nancy, springing before the door, and\r\nclosing it, as the Jew and his two pupils darted out in pursuit. \xe2\x80\x9cKeep\r\nback the dog; he\xe2\x80\x99ll tear the boy to pieces.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cServe him right!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Sikes, struggling to disengage himself from\r\nthe girl\xe2\x80\x99s grasp. \xe2\x80\x9cStand off from me, or I\xe2\x80\x99ll split your head against\r\nthe wall.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t care for that, Bill, I don\xe2\x80\x99t care for that,\xe2\x80\x9d screamed the\r\ngirl, struggling violently with the man, \xe2\x80\x9cthe child shan\xe2\x80\x99t be torn down\r\nby the dog, unless you kill me first.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShan\xe2\x80\x99t he!\xe2\x80\x9d said Sikes, setting his teeth. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll soon do that, if you\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t keep off.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe housebreaker flung the girl from him to the further end of the\r\nroom, just as the Jew and the two boys returned, dragging Oliver among\r\nthem.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter here!\xe2\x80\x9d said Fagin, looking round.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe girl\xe2\x80\x99s gone mad, I think,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Sikes, savagely.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, she hasn\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nancy, pale and breathless from the scuffle;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cno, she hasn\xe2\x80\x99t, Fagin; don\xe2\x80\x99t think it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen keep quiet, will you?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, with a threatening look.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I won\xe2\x80\x99t do that, neither,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Nancy, speaking very loud.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome! What do you think of that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Fagin was sufficiently well acquainted with the manners and customs\r\nof that particular species of humanity to which Nancy belonged, to feel\r\ntolerably certain that it would be rather unsafe to prolong any\r\nconversation with her, at present. With the view of diverting the\r\nattention of the company, he turned to Oliver.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo you wanted to get away, my dear, did you?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, taking up\r\na jagged and knotted club which lay in a corner of the fireplace; \xe2\x80\x9ceh?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOliver made no reply. But he watched the Jew\xe2\x80\x99s motions, and breathed\r\nquickly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWanted to get assistance; called for the police; did you?\xe2\x80\x9d sneered the\r\nJew, catching the boy by the arm. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll cure you of that, my young\r\nmaster.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Jew inflicted a smart blow on Oliver\xe2\x80\x99s shoulders with the club; and\r\nwas raising it for a second, when the girl, rushing forward, wrested it\r\nfrom his hand. She flung it into the fire, with a force that brought\r\nsome of the glowing coals whirling out into the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI won\xe2\x80\x99t stand by and see it done, Fagin,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the girl. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve got\r\nthe boy, and what more would you have?\xe2\x80\x94Let him be\xe2\x80\x94let him be\xe2\x80\x94or I shall\r\nput that mark on some of you, that will bring me to the gallows before\r\nmy time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe girl stamped her foot violently on the floor as she vented this\r\nthreat; and with her lips compressed, and her hands clenched, looked\r\nalternately at the Jew and the other robber: her face quite colourless\r\nfrom the passion of rage into which she had gradually worked herself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, Nancy!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, in a soothing tone; after a pause, during\r\nwhich he and Mr. Sikes had stared at one another in a disconcerted\r\nmanner; \xe2\x80\x9cyou,\xe2\x80\x94you\xe2\x80\x99re more clever than ever to-night. Ha! ha! my dear,\r\nyou are acting beautifully.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAm I!\xe2\x80\x9d said the girl. \xe2\x80\x9cTake care I don\xe2\x80\x99t overdo it. You will be the\r\nworse for it, Fagin, if I do; and so I tell you in good time to keep\r\nclear of me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere is something about a roused woman: especially if she add to all\r\nher other strong passions, the fierce impulses of recklessness and\r\ndespair; which few men like to provoke. The Jew saw that it would be\r\nhopeless to affect any further mistake regarding the reality of Miss\r\nNancy\xe2\x80\x99s rage; and, shrinking involuntarily back a few paces, cast a\r\nglance, half imploring and half cowardly, at Sikes: as if to hint that\r\nhe was the fittest person to pursue the dialogue.\r\n\r\nMr. Sikes, thus mutely appealed to; and possibly feeling his personal\r\npride and influence interested in the immediate reduction of Miss Nancy\r\nto reason; gave utterance to about a couple of score of curses and\r\nthreats, the rapid production of which reflected great credit on the\r\nfertility of his invention. As they produced no visible effect on the\r\nobject against whom they were discharged, however, he resorted to more\r\ntangible arguments.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean by this?\xe2\x80\x9d said Sikes; backing the inquiry with a very\r\ncommon imprecation concerning the most beautiful of human features:\r\nwhich, if it were heard above, only once out of every fifty thousand\r\ntimes that it is uttered below, would render blindness as common a\r\ndisorder as measles: \xe2\x80\x9cwhat do you mean by it? Burn my body! Do you know\r\nwho you are, and what you are?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes, I know all about it,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the girl, laughing\r\nhysterically; and shaking her head from side to side, with a poor\r\nassumption of indifference.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, keep quiet,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined Sikes, with a growl like that he was\r\naccustomed to use when addressing his dog, \xe2\x80\x9cor I\xe2\x80\x99ll quiet you for a\r\ngood long time to come.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe girl laughed again: even less composedly than before; and, darting\r\na hasty look at Sikes, turned her face aside, and bit her lip till the\r\nblood came.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re a nice one,\xe2\x80\x9d added Sikes, as he surveyed her with a\r\ncontemptuous air, \xe2\x80\x9cto take up the humane and gen\xe2\x80\x94teel side! A pretty\r\nsubject for the child, as you call him, to make a friend of!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod Almighty help me, I am!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the girl passionately; \xe2\x80\x9cand I wish\r\nI had been struck dead in the street, or had changed places with them\r\nwe passed so near to-night, before I had lent a hand in bringing him\r\nhere. He\xe2\x80\x99s a thief, a liar, a devil, all that\xe2\x80\x99s bad, from this night\r\nforth. Isn\xe2\x80\x99t that enough for the old wretch, without blows?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, come, Sikes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew appealing to him in a remonstratory\r\ntone, and motioning towards the boys, who were eagerly attentive to all\r\nthat passed; \xe2\x80\x9cwe must have civil words; civil words, Bill.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCivil words!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the girl, whose passion was frightful to see.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCivil words, you villain! Yes, you deserve \xe2\x80\x99em from me. I thieved for\r\nyou when I was a child not half as old as this!\xe2\x80\x9d pointing to Oliver. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nhave been in the same trade, and in the same service, for twelve years\r\nsince. Don\xe2\x80\x99t you know it? Speak out! Don\xe2\x80\x99t you know it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, well,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Jew, with an attempt at pacification; \xe2\x80\x9cand,\r\nif you have, it\xe2\x80\x99s your living!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAye, it is!\xe2\x80\x9d returned the girl; not speaking, but pouring out the\r\nwords in one continuous and vehement scream. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is my living; and the\r\ncold, wet, dirty streets are my home; and you\xe2\x80\x99re the wretch that drove\r\nme to them long ago, and that\xe2\x80\x99ll keep me there, day and night, day and\r\nnight, till I die!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall do you a mischief!\xe2\x80\x9d interposed the Jew, goaded by these\r\nreproaches; \xe2\x80\x9ca mischief worse than that, if you say much more!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe girl said nothing more; but, tearing her hair and dress in a\r\ntransport of passion, made such a rush at the Jew as would probably\r\nhave left signal marks of her revenge upon him, had not her wrists been\r\nseized by Sikes at the right moment; upon which, she made a few\r\nineffectual struggles, and fainted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s all right now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sikes, laying her down in a corner. \xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nuncommon strong in the arms, when she\xe2\x80\x99s up in this way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Jew wiped his forehead: and smiled, as if it were a relief to have\r\nthe disturbance over; but neither he, nor Sikes, nor the dog, nor the\r\nboys, seemed to consider it in any other light than a common occurance\r\nincidental to business.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s the worst of having to do with women,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, replacing\r\nhis club; \xe2\x80\x9cbut they\xe2\x80\x99re clever, and we can\xe2\x80\x99t get on, in our line,\r\nwithout \xe2\x80\x99em. Charley, show Oliver to bed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI suppose he\xe2\x80\x99d better not wear his best clothes tomorrow, Fagin, had\r\nhe?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Charley Bates.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly not,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Jew, reciprocating the grin with which\r\nCharley put the question.\r\n\r\nMaster Bates, apparently much delighted with his commission, took the\r\ncleft stick: and led Oliver into an adjacent kitchen, where there were\r\ntwo or three of the beds on which he had slept before; and here, with\r\nmany uncontrollable bursts of laughter, he produced the identical old\r\nsuit of clothes which Oliver had so much congratulated himself upon\r\nleaving off at Mr. Brownlow\xe2\x80\x99s; and the accidental display of which, to\r\nFagin, by the Jew who purchased them, had been the very first clue\r\nreceived, of his whereabout.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPut off the smart ones,\xe2\x80\x9d said Charley, \xe2\x80\x9cand I\xe2\x80\x99ll give \xe2\x80\x99em to Fagin to\r\ntake care of. What fun it is!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPoor Oliver unwillingly complied. Master Bates rolling up the new\r\nclothes under his arm, departed from the room, leaving Oliver in the\r\ndark, and locking the door behind him.\r\n\r\nThe noise of Charley\xe2\x80\x99s laughter, and the voice of Miss Betsy, who\r\nopportunely arrived to throw water over her friend, and perform other\r\nfeminine offices for the promotion of her recovery, might have kept\r\nmany people awake under more happy circumstances than those in which\r\nOliver was placed. But he was sick and weary; and he soon fell sound\r\nasleep.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n CHAPTER XVII.\r\nOLIVER\xe2\x80\x99S DESTINY CONTINUING UNPROPITIOUS, BRINGS A GREAT MAN TO LONDON\r\nTO INJURE HIS REPUTATION\r\n\r\n\r\nIt is the custom on the stage, in all good murderous melodramas, to\r\npresent the tragic and the comic scenes, in as regular alternation, as\r\nthe layers of red and white in a side of streaky bacon. The hero sinks\r\nupon his straw bed, weighed down by fetters and misfortunes; in the\r\nnext scene, his faithful but unconscious squire regales the audience\r\nwith a comic song. We behold, with throbbing bosoms, the heroine in the\r\ngrasp of a proud and ruthless baron: her virtue and her life alike in\r\ndanger, drawing forth her dagger to preserve the one at the cost of the\r\nother; and just as our expectations are wrought up to the highest\r\npitch, a whistle is heard, and we are straightway transported to the\r\ngreat hall of the castle; where a grey-headed seneschal sings a funny\r\nchorus with a funnier body of vassals, who are free of all sorts of\r\nplaces, from church vaults to palaces, and roam about in company,\r\ncarolling perpetually.\r\n\r\nSuch changes appear absurd; but they are not so unnatural as they would\r\nseem at first sight. The transitions in real life from well-spread\r\nboards to death-beds, and from mourning-weeds to holiday garments, are\r\nnot a whit less startling; only, there, we are busy actors, instead of\r\npassive lookers-on, which makes a vast difference. The actors in the\r\nmimic life of the theatre, are blind to violent transitions and abrupt\r\nimpulses of passion or feeling, which, presented before the eyes of\r\nmere spectators, are at once condemned as outrageous and preposterous.\r\n\r\nAs sudden shiftings of the scene, and rapid changes of time and place,\r\nare not only sanctioned in books by long usage, but are by many\r\nconsidered as the great art of authorship: an author\xe2\x80\x99s skill in his\r\ncraft being, by such critics, chiefly estimated with relation to the\r\ndilemmas in which he leaves his characters at the end of every chapter:\r\nthis brief introduction to the present one may perhaps be deemed\r\nunnecessary. If so, let it be considered a delicate intimation on the\r\npart of the historian that he is going back to the town in which Oliver\r\nTwist was born; the reader taking it for granted that there are good\r\nand substantial reasons for making the journey, or he would not be\r\ninvited to proceed upon such an expedition.\r\n\r\nMr. Bumble emerged at early morning from the workhouse-gate, and walked\r\nwith portly carriage and commanding steps, up the High Street. He was\r\nin the full bloom and pride of beadlehood; his cocked hat and coat were\r\ndazzling in the morning sun; he clutched his cane with the vigorous\r\ntenacity of health and power. Mr. Bumble always carried his head high;\r\nbut this morning it was higher than usual. There was an abstraction in\r\nhis eye, an elevation in his air, which might have warned an observant\r\nstranger that thoughts were passing in the beadle\xe2\x80\x99s mind, too great for\r\nutterance.\r\n\r\nMr. Bumble stopped not to converse with the small shopkeepers and\r\nothers who spoke to him, deferentially, as he passed along. He merely\r\nreturned their salutations with a wave of his hand, and relaxed not in\r\nhis dignified pace, until he reached the farm where Mrs. Mann tended\r\nthe infant paupers with parochial care.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDrat that beadle!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Mann, hearing the well-known shaking at\r\nthe garden-gate. \xe2\x80\x9cIf it isn\xe2\x80\x99t him at this time in the morning! Lauk,\r\nMr. Bumble, only think of its being you! Well, dear me, it _is_ a\r\npleasure, this is! Come into the parlour, sir, please.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe first sentence was addressed to Susan; and the exclamations of\r\ndelight were uttered to Mr. Bumble: as the good lady unlocked the\r\ngarden-gate: and showed him, with great attention and respect, into the\r\nhouse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMrs. Mann,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Bumble; not sitting upon, or dropping himself\r\ninto a seat, as any common jackanapes would: but letting himself\r\ngradually and slowly down into a chair; \xe2\x80\x9cMrs. Mann, ma\xe2\x80\x99am, good\r\nmorning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, and good morning to _you_, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mrs. Mann, with many\r\nsmiles; \xe2\x80\x9cand hoping you find yourself well, sir!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo-so, Mrs. Mann,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the beadle. \xe2\x80\x9cA porochial life is not a bed\r\nof roses, Mrs. Mann.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, that it isn\xe2\x80\x99t indeed, Mr. Bumble,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined the lady. And all the\r\ninfant paupers might have chorussed the rejoinder with great propriety,\r\nif they had heard it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA porochial life, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Mr. Bumble, striking the table\r\nwith his cane, \xe2\x80\x9cis a life of worrit, and vexation, and hardihood; but\r\nall public characters, as I may say, must suffer prosecution.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Mann, not very well knowing what the beadle meant, raised her\r\nhands with a look of sympathy, and sighed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! You may well sigh, Mrs. Mann!\xe2\x80\x9d said the beadle.\r\n\r\nFinding she had done right, Mrs. Mann sighed again: evidently to the\r\nsatisfaction of the public character: who, repressing a complacent\r\nsmile by looking sternly at his cocked hat, said,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMrs. Mann, I am going to London.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLauk, Mr. Bumble!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mrs. Mann, starting back.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo London, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed the inflexible beadle, \xe2\x80\x9cby coach. I and two\r\npaupers, Mrs. Mann! A legal action is a coming on, about a settlement;\r\nand the board has appointed me\xe2\x80\x94me, Mrs. Mann\xe2\x80\x94to dispose to the matter\r\nbefore the quarter-sessions at Clerkinwell.\r\n\r\nAnd I very much question,\xe2\x80\x9d added Mr. Bumble, drawing himself up,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwhether the Clerkinwell Sessions will not find themselves in the wrong\r\nbox before they have done with me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! you mustn\xe2\x80\x99t be too hard upon them, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Mann,\r\ncoaxingly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Clerkinwell Sessions have brought it upon themselves, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nreplied Mr. Bumble; \xe2\x80\x9cand if the Clerkinwell Sessions find that they\r\ncome off rather worse than they expected, the Clerkinwell Sessions have\r\nonly themselves to thank.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was so much determination and depth of purpose about the menacing\r\nmanner in which Mr. Bumble delivered himself of these words, that Mrs.\r\nMann appeared quite awed by them. At length she said,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re going by coach, sir? I thought it was always usual to send them\r\npaupers in carts.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s when they\xe2\x80\x99re ill, Mrs. Mann,\xe2\x80\x9d said the beadle. \xe2\x80\x9cWe put the sick\r\npaupers into open carts in the rainy weather, to prevent their taking\r\ncold.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Mann.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe opposition coach contracts for these two; and takes them cheap,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Mr. Bumble. \xe2\x80\x9cThey are both in a very low state, and we find it\r\nwould come two pound cheaper to move \xe2\x80\x99em than to bury \xe2\x80\x99em\xe2\x80\x94that is, if\r\nwe can throw \xe2\x80\x99em upon another parish, which I think we shall be able to\r\ndo, if they don\xe2\x80\x99t die upon the road to spite us. Ha! ha! ha!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen Mr. Bumble had laughed a little while, his eyes again encountered\r\nthe cocked hat; and he became grave.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are forgetting business, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d said the beadle; \xe2\x80\x9chere is your\r\nporochial stipend for the month.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Bumble produced some silver money rolled up in paper, from his\r\npocket-book; and requested a receipt: which Mrs. Mann wrote.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s very much blotted, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said the farmer of infants; \xe2\x80\x9cbut it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nformal enough, I dare say. Thank you, Mr. Bumble, sir, I am very much\r\nobliged to you, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Bumble nodded, blandly, in acknowledgment of Mrs. Mann\xe2\x80\x99s curtsey;\r\nand inquired how the children were.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBless their dear little hearts!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Mann with emotion, \xe2\x80\x9cthey\xe2\x80\x99re\r\nas well as can be, the dears! Of course, except the two that died last\r\nweek. And little Dick.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIsn\xe2\x80\x99t that boy no better?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Mr. Bumble.\r\n\r\nMrs. Mann shook her head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s a ill-conditioned, wicious, bad-disposed porochial child that,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Mr. Bumble angrily. \xe2\x80\x9cWhere is he?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll bring him to you in one minute, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mrs. Mann. \xe2\x80\x9cHere,\r\nyou Dick!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAfter some calling, Dick was discovered. Having had his face put under\r\nthe pump, and dried upon Mrs. Mann\xe2\x80\x99s gown, he was led into the awful\r\npresence of Mr. Bumble, the beadle.\r\n\r\nThe child was pale and thin; his cheeks were sunken; and his eyes large\r\nand bright. The scanty parish dress, the livery of his misery, hung\r\nloosely on his feeble body; and his young limbs had wasted away, like\r\nthose of an old man.\r\n\r\nSuch was the little being who stood trembling beneath Mr. Bumble\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nglance; not daring to lift his eyes from the floor; and dreading even\r\nto hear the beadle\xe2\x80\x99s voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan\xe2\x80\x99t you look at the gentleman, you obstinate boy?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Mann.\r\n\r\nThe child meekly raised his eyes, and encountered those of Mr. Bumble.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter with you, porochial Dick?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Mr. Bumble, with\r\nwell-timed jocularity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the child faintly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should think not,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Mann, who had of course laughed very\r\nmuch at Mr. Bumble\xe2\x80\x99s humour.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou want for nothing, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should like\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d faltered the child.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHey-day!\xe2\x80\x9d interposed Mrs. Mann, \xe2\x80\x9cI suppose you\xe2\x80\x99re going to say that\r\nyou _do_ want for something, now? Why, you little wretch\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStop, Mrs. Mann, stop!\xe2\x80\x9d said the beadle, raising his hand with a show\r\nof authority. \xe2\x80\x9cLike what, sir, eh?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should like,\xe2\x80\x9d faltered the child, \xe2\x80\x9cif somebody that can write, would\r\nput a few words down for me on a piece of paper, and fold it up and\r\nseal it, and keep it for me, after I am laid in the ground.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, what does the boy mean?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Mr. Bumble, on whom the\r\nearnest manner and wan aspect of the child had made some impression:\r\naccustomed as he was to such things. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should like,\xe2\x80\x9d said the child, \xe2\x80\x9cto leave my dear love to poor Oliver\r\nTwist; and to let him know how often I have sat by myself and cried to\r\nthink of his wandering about in the dark nights with nobody to help\r\nhim. And I should like to tell him,\xe2\x80\x9d said the child pressing his small\r\nhands together, and speaking with great fervour, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I was glad to\r\ndie when I was very young; for, perhaps, if I had lived to be a man,\r\nand had grown old, my little sister who is in Heaven, might forget me,\r\nor be unlike me; and it would be so much happier if we were both\r\nchildren there together.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Bumble surveyed the little speaker, from head to foot, with\r\nindescribable astonishment; and, turning to his companion, said,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re all in one story, Mrs. Mann. That out-dacious Oliver had\r\ndemogalized them all!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI couldn\xe2\x80\x99t have believed it, sir\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Mann, holding up her hands,\r\nand looking malignantly at Dick. \xe2\x80\x9cI never see such a hardened little\r\nwretch!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake him away, ma\xe2\x80\x99am!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Bumble imperiously. \xe2\x80\x9cThis must be\r\nstated to the board, Mrs. Mann.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope the gentleman will understand that it isn\xe2\x80\x99t my fault, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Mrs. Mann, whimpering pathetically.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey shall understand that, ma\xe2\x80\x99am; they shall be acquainted with the\r\ntrue state of the case,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Bumble. \xe2\x80\x9cThere; take him away, I\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t bear the sight on him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDick was immediately taken away, and locked up in the coal-cellar. Mr.\r\nBumble shortly afterwards took himself off, to prepare for his journey.\r\n\r\nAt six o\xe2\x80\x99clock next morning, Mr. Bumble: having exchanged his cocked\r\nhat for a round one, and encased his person in a blue great-coat with a\r\ncape to it: took his place on the outside of the coach, accompanied by\r\nthe criminals whose settlement was disputed; with whom, in due course\r\nof time, he arrived in London.\r\n\r\nHe experienced no other crosses on the way, than those which originated\r\nin the perverse behaviour of the two paupers, who persisted in\r\nshivering, and complaining of the cold, in a manner which, Mr. Bumble\r\ndeclared, caused his teeth to chatter in his head, and made him feel\r\nquite uncomfortable; although he had a great-coat on.\r\n\r\nHaving disposed of these evil-minded persons for the night, Mr. Bumble\r\nsat himself down in the house at which the coach stopped; and took a\r\ntemperate dinner of steaks, oyster sauce, and porter. Putting a glass\r\nof hot gin-and-water on the chimney-piece, he drew his chair to the\r\nfire; and, with sundry moral reflections on the too-prevalent sin of\r\ndiscontent and complaining, composed himself to read the paper.\r\n\r\nThe very first paragraph upon which Mr. Bumble\xe2\x80\x99s eye rested, was the\r\nfollowing advertisement.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFIVE GUINEAS REWARD\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhereas a young boy, named Oliver Twist, absconded, or was enticed, on\r\nThursday evening last, from his home, at Pentonville; and has not since\r\nbeen heard of.
