He clasped his hands together, and\r\ninvoluntarily uttered a subdued exclamation of horror. A mist came\r\nbefore his eyes; the cold sweat stood upon his ashy face; his limbs\r\nfailed him; and he sank upon his knees.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGet up!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Sikes, trembling with rage, and drawing the pistol\r\nfrom his pocket; \xe2\x80\x9cGet up, or I\xe2\x80\x99ll strew your brains upon the grass.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! for God\xe2\x80\x99s sake let me go!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Oliver; \xe2\x80\x9clet me run away and die\r\nin the fields. I will never come near London; never, never! Oh! pray\r\nhave mercy on me, and do not make me steal. For the love of all the\r\nbright Angels that rest in Heaven, have mercy upon me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe man to whom this appeal was made, swore a dreadful oath, and had\r\ncocked the pistol, when Toby, striking it from his grasp, placed his\r\nhand upon the boy\xe2\x80\x99s mouth, and dragged him to the house.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHush!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the man; \xe2\x80\x9cit won\xe2\x80\x99t answer here. Say another word, and\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll do your business myself with a crack on the head. That makes no\r\nnoise, and is quite as certain, and more genteel. Here, Bill, wrench\r\nthe shutter open. He\xe2\x80\x99s game enough now, I\xe2\x80\x99ll engage. I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen older\r\nhands of his age took the same way, for a minute or two, on a cold\r\nnight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSikes, invoking terrific imprecations upon Fagin\xe2\x80\x99s head for sending\r\nOliver on such an errand, plied the crowbar vigorously, but with little\r\nnoise. After some delay, and some assistance from Toby, the shutter to\r\nwhich he had referred, swung open on its hinges.\r\n\r\nIt was a little lattice window, about five feet and a half above the\r\nground, at the back of the house: which belonged to a scullery, or\r\nsmall brewing-place, at the end of the passage. The aperture was so\r\nsmall, that the inmates had probably not thought it worth while to\r\ndefend it more securely; but it was large enough to admit a boy of\r\nOliver\xe2\x80\x99s size, nevertheless. A very brief exercise of Mr. Sike\xe2\x80\x99s art,\r\nsufficed to overcome the fastening of the lattice; and it soon stood\r\nwide open also.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow listen, you young limb,\xe2\x80\x9d whispered Sikes, drawing a dark lantern\r\nfrom his pocket, and throwing the glare full on Oliver\xe2\x80\x99s face; \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m a\r\ngoing to put you through there. Take this light; go softly up the steps\r\nstraight afore you, and along the little hall, to the street door;\r\nunfasten it, and let us in.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s a bolt at the top, you won\xe2\x80\x99t be able to reach,\xe2\x80\x9d interposed\r\nToby. \xe2\x80\x9cStand upon one of the hall chairs. There are three there, Bill,\r\nwith a jolly large blue unicorn and gold pitchfork on \xe2\x80\x99em: which is the\r\nold lady\xe2\x80\x99s arms.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKeep quiet, can\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d replied Sikes, with a threatening look. \xe2\x80\x9cThe\r\nroom-door is open, is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWide,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Toby, after peeping in to satisfy himself. \xe2\x80\x9cThe game of\r\nthat is, that they always leave it open with a catch, so that the dog,\r\nwho\xe2\x80\x99s got a bed in here, may walk up and down the passage when he feels\r\nwakeful. Ha! ha! Barney \xe2\x80\x99ticed him away to-night. So neat!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlthough Mr. Crackit spoke in a scarcely audible whisper, and laughed\r\nwithout noise, Sikes imperiously commanded him to be silent, and to get\r\nto work. Toby complied, by first producing his lantern, and placing it\r\non the ground; then by planting himself firmly with his head against\r\nthe wall beneath the window, and his hands upon his knees, so as to\r\nmake a step of his back. This was no sooner done, than Sikes, mounting\r\nupon him, put Oliver gently through the window with his feet first;\r\nand, without leaving hold of his collar, planted him safely on the\r\nfloor inside.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake this lantern,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sikes, looking into the room. \xe2\x80\x9cYou see the\r\nstairs afore you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOliver, more dead than alive, gasped out, \xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d Sikes, pointing to the\r\nstreet-door with the pistol-barrel, briefly advised him to take notice\r\nthat he was within shot all the way; and that if he faltered, he would\r\nfall dead that instant.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s done in a minute,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sikes, in the same low whisper. \xe2\x80\x9cDirectly\r\nI leave go of you, do your work. Hark!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s that?\xe2\x80\x9d whispered the other man.\r\n\r\nThey listened intently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sikes, releasing his hold of Oliver. \xe2\x80\x9cNow!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn the short time he had had to collect his senses, the boy had firmly\r\nresolved that, whether he died in the attempt or not, he would make one\r\neffort to dart upstairs from the hall, and alarm the family. Filled\r\nwith this idea, he advanced at once, but stealthily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome back!\xe2\x80\x9d suddenly cried Sikes aloud. \xe2\x80\x9cBack! back!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nScared by the sudden breaking of the dead stillness of the place, and\r\nby a loud cry which followed it, Oliver let his lantern fall, and knew\r\nnot whether to advance or fly.\r\n\r\nThe cry was repeated\xe2\x80\x94a light appeared\xe2\x80\x94a vision of two terrified\r\nhalf-dressed men at the top of the stairs swam before his eyes\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nflash\xe2\x80\x94a loud noise\xe2\x80\x94a smoke\xe2\x80\x94a crash somewhere, but where he knew\r\nnot,\xe2\x80\x94and he staggered back.\r\n\r\nSikes had disappeared for an instant; but he was up again, and had him\r\nby the collar before the smoke had cleared away. He fired his own\r\npistol after the men, who were already retreating; and dragged the boy\r\nup.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cClasp your arm tighter,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sikes, as he drew him through the\r\nwindow. \xe2\x80\x9cGive me a shawl here. They\xe2\x80\x99ve hit him. Quick! How the boy\r\nbleeds!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen came the loud ringing of a bell, mingled with the noise of\r\nfire-arms, and the shouts of men, and the sensation of being carried\r\nover uneven ground at a rapid pace. And then, the noises grew confused\r\nin the distance; and a cold deadly feeling crept over the boy\xe2\x80\x99s heart;\r\nand he saw or heard no more.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n CHAPTER XXIII.\r\nWHICH CONTAINS THE SUBSTANCE OF A PLEASANT CONVERSATION BETWEEN MR.\r\nBUMBLE AND A LADY; AND SHOWS THAT EVEN A BEADLE MAY BE SUSCEPTIBLE ON\r\nSOME POINTS\r\n\r\n\r\nThe night was bitter cold. The snow lay on the ground, frozen into a\r\nhard thick crust, so that only the heaps that had drifted into byways\r\nand corners were affected by the sharp wind that howled abroad: which,\r\nas if expending increased fury on such prey as it found, caught it\r\nsavagely up in clouds, and, whirling it into a thousand misty eddies,\r\nscattered it in air. Bleak, dark, and piercing cold, it was a night for\r\nthe well-housed and fed to draw round the bright fire and thank God\r\nthey were at home; and for the homeless, starving wretch to lay him\r\ndown and die. Many hunger-worn outcasts close their eyes in our bare\r\nstreets, at such times, who, let their crimes have been what they may,\r\ncan hardly open them in a more bitter world.\r\n\r\nSuch was the aspect of out-of-doors affairs, when Mrs. Corney, the\r\nmatron of the workhouse to which our readers have been already\r\nintroduced as the birthplace of Oliver Twist, sat herself down before a\r\ncheerful fire in her own little room, and glanced, with no small degree\r\nof complacency, at a small round table: on which stood a tray of\r\ncorresponding size, furnished with all necessary materials for the most\r\ngrateful meal that matrons enjoy. In fact, Mrs. Corney was about to\r\nsolace herself with a cup of tea. As she glanced from the table to the\r\nfireplace, where the smallest of all possible kettles was singing a\r\nsmall song in a small voice, her inward satisfaction evidently\r\nincreased,\xe2\x80\x94so much so, indeed, that Mrs. Corney smiled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell!\xe2\x80\x9d said the matron, leaning her elbow on the table, and looking\r\nreflectively at the fire; \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m sure we have all on us a great deal to\r\nbe grateful for! A great deal, if we did but know it. Ah!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Corney shook her head mournfully, as if deploring the mental\r\nblindness of those paupers who did not know it; and thrusting a silver\r\nspoon (private property) into the inmost recesses of a two-ounce tin\r\ntea-caddy, proceeded to make the tea.\r\n\r\nHow slight a thing will disturb the equanimity of our frail minds! The\r\nblack teapot, being very small and easily filled, ran over while Mrs.\r\nCorney was moralising; and the water slightly scalded Mrs. Corney\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDrat the pot!\xe2\x80\x9d said the worthy matron, setting it down very hastily on\r\nthe hob; \xe2\x80\x9ca little stupid thing, that only holds a couple of cups! What\r\nuse is it of, to anybody! Except,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Corney, pausing, \xe2\x80\x9cexcept\r\nto a poor desolate creature like me. Oh dear!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith these words, the matron dropped into her chair, and, once more\r\nresting her elbow on the table, thought of her solitary fate. The small\r\nteapot, and the single cup, had awakened in her mind sad recollections\r\nof Mr. Corney (who had not been dead more than five-and-twenty years);\r\nand she was overpowered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall never get another!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Corney, pettishly; \xe2\x80\x9cI shall\r\nnever get another\xe2\x80\x94like him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhether this remark bore reference to the husband, or the teapot, is\r\nuncertain. It might have been the latter; for Mrs. Corney looked at it\r\nas she spoke; and took it up afterwards. She had just tasted her first\r\ncup, when she was disturbed by a soft tap at the room-door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, come in with you!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Corney, sharply. \xe2\x80\x9cSome of the old\r\nwomen dying, I suppose. They always die when I\xe2\x80\x99m at meals. Don\xe2\x80\x99t stand\r\nthere, letting the cold air in, don\xe2\x80\x99t. What\xe2\x80\x99s amiss now, eh?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing, ma\xe2\x80\x99am, nothing,\xe2\x80\x9d replied a man\xe2\x80\x99s voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear me!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the matron, in a much sweeter tone, \xe2\x80\x9cis that Mr.\r\nBumble?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt your service, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Bumble, who had been stopping\r\noutside to rub his shoes clean, and to shake the snow off his coat; and\r\nwho now made his appearance, bearing the cocked hat in one hand and a\r\nbundle in the other. \xe2\x80\x9cShall I shut the door, ma\xe2\x80\x99am?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe lady modestly hesitated to reply, lest there should be any\r\nimpropriety in holding an interview with Mr. Bumble, with closed doors.\r\nMr. Bumble taking advantage of the hesitation, and being very cold\r\nhimself, shut it without permission.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHard weather, Mr. Bumble,\xe2\x80\x9d said the matron.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHard, indeed, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the beadle. \xe2\x80\x9cAnti-porochial weather\r\nthis, ma\xe2\x80\x99am. We have given away, Mrs. Corney, we have given away a\r\nmatter of twenty quartern loaves and a cheese and a half, this very\r\nblessed afternoon; and yet them paupers are not contented.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course not. When would they be, Mr. Bumble?\xe2\x80\x9d said the matron,\r\nsipping her tea.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen, indeed, ma\xe2\x80\x99am!\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined Mr. Bumble. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy here\xe2\x80\x99s one man that,\r\nin consideration of his wife and large family, has a quartern loaf and\r\na good pound of cheese, full weight. Is he grateful, ma\xe2\x80\x99am? Is he\r\ngrateful? Not a copper farthing\xe2\x80\x99s worth of it! What does he do, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\r\nbut ask for a few coals; if it\xe2\x80\x99s only a pocket handkerchief full, he\r\nsays! Coals! What would he do with coals? Toast his cheese with \xe2\x80\x99em and\r\nthen come back for more. That\xe2\x80\x99s the way with these people, ma\xe2\x80\x99am; give\r\n\xe2\x80\x99em a apron full of coals to-day, and they\xe2\x80\x99ll come back for another,\r\nthe day after to-morrow, as brazen as alabaster.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe matron expressed her entire concurrence in this intelligible\r\nsimile; and the beadle went on.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Bumble, \xe2\x80\x9csee anything like the pitch it\xe2\x80\x99s got to.\r\nThe day afore yesterday, a man\xe2\x80\x94you have been a married woman, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\r\nand I may mention it to you\xe2\x80\x94a man, with hardly a rag upon his back\r\n(here Mrs. Corney looked at the floor), goes to our overseer\xe2\x80\x99s door\r\nwhen he has got company coming to dinner; and says, he must be\r\nrelieved, Mrs. Corney. As he wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t go away, and shocked the company\r\nvery much, our overseer sent him out a pound of potatoes and half a\r\npint of oatmeal. \xe2\x80\x98My heart!\xe2\x80\x99 says the ungrateful villain, \xe2\x80\x98what\xe2\x80\x99s the\r\nuse of _this_ to me? You might as well give me a pair of iron\r\nspectacles!\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98Very good,\xe2\x80\x99 says our overseer, taking \xe2\x80\x99em away again,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98you won\xe2\x80\x99t get anything else here.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98Then I\xe2\x80\x99ll die in the streets!\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsays the vagrant. \xe2\x80\x98Oh no, you won\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x99 says our overseer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHa! ha! That was very good! So like Mr. Grannett, wasn\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ninterposed the matron. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, Mr. Bumble?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined the beadle, \xe2\x80\x9che went away; and he _did_ die in\r\nthe streets. There\xe2\x80\x99s a obstinate pauper for you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt beats anything I could have believed,\xe2\x80\x9d observed the matron\r\nemphatically. \xe2\x80\x9cBut don\xe2\x80\x99t you think out-of-door relief a very bad thing,\r\nany way, Mr. Bumble? You\xe2\x80\x99re a gentleman of experience, and ought to\r\nknow. Come.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMrs. Corney,\xe2\x80\x9d said the beadle, smiling as men smile who are conscious\r\nof superior information, \xe2\x80\x9cout-of-door relief, properly managed:\r\nproperly managed, ma\xe2\x80\x99am: is the porochial safeguard. The great\r\nprinciple of out-of-door relief is, to give the paupers exactly what\r\nthey don\xe2\x80\x99t want; and then they get tired of coming.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear me!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Mrs. Corney. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, that is a good one, too!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. Betwixt you and me, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Mr. Bumble, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s the\r\ngreat principle; and that\xe2\x80\x99s the reason why, if you look at any cases\r\nthat get into them owdacious newspapers, you\xe2\x80\x99ll always observe that\r\nsick families have been relieved with slices of cheese. That\xe2\x80\x99s the rule\r\nnow, Mrs. Corney, all over the country. But, however,\xe2\x80\x9d said the beadle,\r\nstopping to unpack his bundle, \xe2\x80\x9cthese are official secrets, ma\xe2\x80\x99am; not\r\nto be spoken of; except, as I may say, among the porochial officers,\r\nsuch as ourselves. This is the port wine, ma\xe2\x80\x99am, that the board ordered\r\nfor the infirmary; real, fresh, genuine port wine; only out of the cask\r\nthis forenoon; clear as a bell, and no sediment!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHaving held the first bottle up to the light, and shaken it well to\r\ntest its excellence, Mr. Bumble placed them both on top of a chest of\r\ndrawers; folded the handkerchief in which they had been wrapped; put it\r\ncarefully in his pocket; and took up his hat, as if to go.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll have a very cold walk, Mr. Bumble,\xe2\x80\x9d said the matron.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt blows, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mr. Bumble, turning up his coat-collar,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cenough to cut one\xe2\x80\x99s ears off.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe matron looked, from the little kettle, to the beadle, who was\r\nmoving towards the door; and as the beadle coughed, preparatory to\r\nbidding her good-night, bashfully inquired whether\xe2\x80\x94whether he wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ntake a cup of tea?\r\n\r\nMr. Bumble instantaneously turned back his collar again; laid his hat\r\nand stick upon a chair; and drew another chair up to the table. As he\r\nslowly seated himself, he looked at the lady. She fixed her eyes upon\r\nthe little teapot. Mr. Bumble coughed again, and slightly smiled.\r\n\r\nMrs. Corney rose to get another cup and saucer from the closet. As she\r\nsat down, her eyes once again encountered those of the gallant beadle;\r\nshe coloured, and applied herself to the task of making his tea. Again\r\nMr. Bumble coughed\xe2\x80\x94louder this time than he had coughed yet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSweet? Mr. Bumble?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the matron, taking up the sugar-basin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery sweet, indeed, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mr. Bumble. He fixed his eyes on\r\nMrs. Corney as he said this; and if ever a beadle looked tender, Mr.\r\nBumble was that beadle at that moment.\r\n\r\nThe tea was made, and handed in silence. Mr. Bumble, having spread a\r\nhandkerchief over his knees to prevent the crumbs from sullying the\r\nsplendour of his shorts, began to eat and drink; varying these\r\namusements, occasionally, by fetching a deep sigh; which, however, had\r\nno injurious effect upon his appetite, but, on the contrary, rather\r\nseemed to facilitate his operations in the tea and toast department.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have a cat, ma\xe2\x80\x99am, I see,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Bumble, glancing at one who,\r\nin the centre of her family, was basking before the fire; \xe2\x80\x9cand kittens\r\ntoo, I declare!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am so fond of them, Mr. Bumble, you can\xe2\x80\x99t think,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the\r\nmatron. \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re _so_ happy, _so_ frolicsome, and _so_ cheerful, that\r\nthey are quite companions for me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery nice animals, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mr. Bumble, approvingly; \xe2\x80\x9cso very\r\ndomestic.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes!\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined the matron with enthusiasm; \xe2\x80\x9cso fond of their home\r\ntoo, that it\xe2\x80\x99s quite a pleasure, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMrs. Corney, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Bumble, slowly, and marking the time\r\nwith his teaspoon, \xe2\x80\x9cI mean to say this, ma\xe2\x80\x99am; that any cat, or kitten,\r\nthat could live with you, ma\xe2\x80\x99am, and _not_ be fond of its home, must be\r\na ass, ma\xe2\x80\x99am.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Mr. Bumble!\xe2\x80\x9d remonstrated Mrs. Corney.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s of no use disguising facts, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Bumble, slowly\r\nflourishing the teaspoon with a kind of amorous dignity which made him\r\ndoubly impressive; \xe2\x80\x9cI would drown it myself, with pleasure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you\xe2\x80\x99re a cruel man,\xe2\x80\x9d said the matron vivaciously, as she held out\r\nher hand for the beadle\xe2\x80\x99s cup; \xe2\x80\x9cand a very hard-hearted man besides.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHard-hearted, ma\xe2\x80\x99am?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Bumble. \xe2\x80\x9cHard?\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Bumble resigned his\r\ncup without another word; squeezed Mrs. Corney\xe2\x80\x99s little finger as she\r\ntook it; and inflicting two open-handed slaps upon his laced waistcoat,\r\ngave a mighty sigh, and hitched his chair a very little morsel farther\r\nfrom the fire.\r\n\r\nIt was a round table; and as Mrs. Corney and Mr. Bumble had been\r\nsitting opposite each other, with no great space between them, and\r\nfronting the fire, it will be seen that Mr. Bumble, in receding from\r\nthe fire, and still keeping at the table, increased the distance\r\nbetween himself and Mrs. Corney; which proceeding, some prudent readers\r\nwill doubtless be disposed to admire, and to consider an act of great\r\nheroism on Mr. Bumble\xe2\x80\x99s part: he being in some sort tempted by time,\r\nplace, and opportunity, to give utterance to certain soft nothings,\r\nwhich however well they may become the lips of the light and\r\nthoughtless, do seem immeasurably beneath the dignity of judges of the\r\nland, members of parliament, ministers of state, lord mayors, and other\r\ngreat public functionaries, but more particularly beneath the\r\nstateliness and gravity of a beadle: who (as is well known) should be\r\nthe sternest and most inflexible among them all.\r\n\r\nWhatever were Mr. Bumble\xe2\x80\x99s intentions, however (and no doubt they were\r\nof the best): it unfortunately happened, as has been twice before\r\nremarked, that the table was a round one; consequently Mr. Bumble,\r\nmoving his chair by little and little, soon began to diminish the\r\ndistance between himself and the matron; and, continuing to travel\r\nround the outer edge of the circle, brought his chair, in time, close\r\nto that in which the matron was seated.\r\n\r\nIndeed, the two chairs touched; and when they did so, Mr. Bumble\r\nstopped.\r\n\r\nNow, if the matron had moved her chair to the right, she would have\r\nbeen scorched by the fire; and if to the left, she must have fallen\r\ninto Mr. Bumble\xe2\x80\x99s arms; so (being a discreet matron, and no doubt\r\nforeseeing these consequences at a glance) she remained where she was,\r\nand handed Mr. Bumble another cup of tea.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHard-hearted, Mrs. Corney?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Bumble, stirring his tea, and\r\nlooking up into the matron\xe2\x80\x99s face; \xe2\x80\x9care _you_ hard-hearted, Mrs.\r\nCorney?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear me!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the matron, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat a very curious question from a\r\nsingle man. What can you want to know for, Mr. Bumble?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe beadle drank his tea to the last drop; finished a piece of toast;\r\nwhisked the crumbs off his knees; wiped his lips; and deliberately\r\nkissed the matron.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Bumble!\xe2\x80\x9d cried that discreet lady in a whisper; for the fright was\r\nso great, that she had quite lost her voice, \xe2\x80\x9cMr. Bumble, I shall\r\nscream!\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Bumble made no reply; but in a slow and dignified manner,\r\nput his arm round the matron\xe2\x80\x99s waist.\r\n\r\nAs the lady had stated her intention of screaming, of course she would\r\nhave screamed at this additional boldness, but that the exertion was\r\nrendered unnecessary by a hasty knocking at the door: which was no\r\nsooner heard, than Mr. Bumble darted, with much agility, to the wine\r\nbottles, and began dusting them with great violence: while the matron\r\nsharply demanded who was there.\r\n\r\nIt is worthy of remark, as a curious physical instance of the efficacy\r\nof a sudden surprise in counteracting the effects of extreme fear, that\r\nher voice had quite recovered all its official asperity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you please, mistress,\xe2\x80\x9d said a withered old female pauper, hideously\r\nugly: putting her head in at the door, \xe2\x80\x9cOld Sally is a-going fast.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, what\xe2\x80\x99s that to me?\xe2\x80\x9d angrily demanded the matron. \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t keep\r\nher alive, can I?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no, mistress,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the old woman, \xe2\x80\x9cnobody can; she\xe2\x80\x99s far\r\nbeyond the reach of help. I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen a many people die; little babes and\r\ngreat strong men; and I know when death\xe2\x80\x99s a-coming, well enough. But\r\nshe\xe2\x80\x99s troubled in her mind: and when the fits are not on her,\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nthat\xe2\x80\x99s not often, for she is dying very hard,\xe2\x80\x94she says she has got\r\nsomething to tell, which you must hear. She\xe2\x80\x99ll never die quiet till you\r\ncome, mistress.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this intelligence, the worthy Mrs. Corney muttered a variety of\r\ninvectives against old women who couldn\xe2\x80\x99t even die without purposely\r\nannoying their betters; and, muffling herself in a thick shawl which\r\nshe hastily caught up, briefly requested Mr. Bumble to stay till she\r\ncame back, lest anything particular should occur. Bidding the messenger\r\nwalk fast, and not be all night hobbling up the stairs, she followed\r\nher from the room with a very ill grace, scolding all the way.\r\n\r\nMr. Bumble\xe2\x80\x99s conduct on being left to himself, was rather inexplicable.\r\nHe opened the closet, counted the teaspoons, weighed the sugar-tongs,\r\nclosely inspected a silver milk-pot to ascertain that it was of the\r\ngenuine metal, and, having satisfied his curiosity on these points, put\r\non his cocked hat corner-wise, and danced with much gravity four\r\ndistinct times round the table.\r\n\r\nHaving gone through this very extraordinary performance, he took off\r\nthe cocked hat again, and, spreading himself before the fire with his\r\nback towards it, seemed to be mentally engaged in taking an exact\r\ninventory of the furniture.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n CHAPTER XXIV.\r\nTREATS ON A VERY POOR SUBJECT. BUT IS A SHORT ONE, AND MAY BE FOUND OF\r\nIMPORTANCE IN THIS HISTORY\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was no unfit messenger of death, who had disturbed the quiet of the\r\nmatron\xe2\x80\x99s room. Her body was bent by age; her limbs trembled with palsy;\r\nher face, distorted into a mumbling leer, resembled more the grotesque\r\nshaping of some wild pencil, than the work of Nature\xe2\x80\x99s hand.\r\n\r\nAlas! How few of Nature\xe2\x80\x99s faces are left alone to gladden us with their\r\nbeauty! The cares, and sorrows, and hungerings, of the world, change\r\nthem as they change hearts; and it is only when those passions sleep,\r\nand have lost their hold for ever, that the troubled clouds pass off,\r\nand leave Heaven\xe2\x80\x99s surface clear. It is a common thing for the\r\ncountenances of the dead, even in that fixed and rigid state, to\r\nsubside into the long-forgotten expression of sleeping infancy, and\r\nsettle into the very look of early life; so calm, so peaceful, do they\r\ngrow again, that those who knew them in their happy childhood, kneel by\r\nthe coffin\xe2\x80\x99s side in awe, and see the Angel even upon earth.\r\n\r\nThe old crone tottered along the passages, and up the stairs, muttering\r\nsome indistinct answers to the chidings of her companion; being at\r\nlength compelled to pause for breath, she gave the light into her hand,\r\nand remained behind to follow as she might: while the more nimble\r\nsuperior made her way to the room where the sick woman lay.\r\n\r\nIt was a bare garret-room, with a dim light burning at the farther end.\r\nThere was another old woman watching by the bed; the parish\r\napothecary\xe2\x80\x99s apprentice was standing by the fire, making a toothpick\r\nout of a quill.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCold night, Mrs. Corney,\xe2\x80\x9d said this young gentleman, as the matron\r\nentered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery cold, indeed, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the mistress, in her most civil\r\ntones, and dropping a curtsey as she spoke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou should get better coals out of your contractors,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\napothecary\xe2\x80\x99s deputy, breaking a lump on the top of the fire with the\r\nrusty poker; \xe2\x80\x9cthese are not at all the sort of thing for a cold night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re the board\xe2\x80\x99s choosing, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the matron. \xe2\x80\x9cThe least\r\nthey could do, would be to keep us pretty warm: for our places are hard\r\nenough.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe conversation was here interrupted by a moan from the sick woman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man, turning his face towards the bed, as if he\r\nhad previously quite forgotten the patient, \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s all U.P. there, Mrs.\r\nCorney.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is, is it, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the matron.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf she lasts a couple of hours, I shall be surprised,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\napothecary\xe2\x80\x99s apprentice, intent upon the toothpick\xe2\x80\x99s point. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\nbreak-up of the system altogether. Is she dozing, old lady?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe attendant stooped over the bed, to ascertain; and nodded in the\r\naffirmative.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen perhaps she\xe2\x80\x99ll go off in that way, if you don\xe2\x80\x99t make a row,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nthe young man. \xe2\x80\x9cPut the light on the floor. She won\xe2\x80\x99t see it there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe attendant did as she was told: shaking her head meanwhile, to\r\nintimate that the woman would not die so easily; having done so, she\r\nresumed her seat by the side of the other nurse, who had by this time\r\nreturned. The mistress, with an expression of impatience, wrapped\r\nherself in her shawl, and sat at the foot of the bed.\r\n\r\nThe apothecary\xe2\x80\x99s apprentice, having completed the manufacture of the\r\ntoothpick, planted himself in front of the fire and made good use of it\r\nfor ten minutes or so: when apparently growing rather dull, he wished\r\nMrs. Corney joy of her job, and took himself off on tiptoe.\r\n\r\nWhen they had sat in silence for some time, the two old women rose from\r\nthe bed, and crouching over the fire, held out their withered hands to\r\ncatch the heat. The flame threw a ghastly light on their shrivelled\r\nfaces, and made their ugliness appear terrible, as, in this position,\r\nthey began to converse in a low voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid she say any more, Anny dear, while I was gone?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the\r\nmessenger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot a word,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the other. \xe2\x80\x9cShe plucked and tore at her arms for\r\na little time; but I held her hands, and she soon dropped off. She\r\nhasn\xe2\x80\x99t much strength in her, so I easily kept her quiet. I ain\xe2\x80\x99t so\r\nweak for an old woman, although I am on parish allowance; no, no!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid she drink the hot wine the doctor said she was to have?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded\r\nthe first.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI tried to get it down,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined the other. \xe2\x80\x9cBut her teeth were tight\r\nset, and she clenched the mug so hard that it was as much as I could do\r\nto get it back again. So I drank it; and it did me good!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLooking cautiously round, to ascertain that they were not overheard,\r\nthe two hags cowered nearer to the fire, and chuckled heartily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI mind the time,\xe2\x80\x9d said the first speaker, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen she would have done\r\nthe same, and made rare fun of it afterwards.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, that she would,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined the other; \xe2\x80\x9cshe had a merry heart. \xe2\x80\x9cA\r\nmany, many, beautiful corpses she laid out, as nice and neat as\r\nwaxwork. My old eyes have seen them\xe2\x80\x94ay, and those old hands touched\r\nthem too; for I have helped her, scores of times.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nStretching forth her trembling fingers as she spoke, the old creature\r\nshook them exultingly before her face, and fumbling in her pocket,\r\nbrought out an old time-discoloured tin snuff-box, from which she shook\r\na few grains into the outstretched palm of her companion, and a few\r\nmore into her own. While they were thus employed, the matron, who had\r\nbeen impatiently watching until the dying woman should awaken from her\r\nstupor, joined them by the fire, and sharply asked how long she was to\r\nwait?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot long, mistress,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the second woman, looking up into her\r\nface. \xe2\x80\x9cWe have none of us long to wait for Death. Patience, patience!\r\nHe\xe2\x80\x99ll be here soon enough for us all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold your tongue, you doting idiot!\xe2\x80\x9d said the matron sternly. \xe2\x80\x9cYou,\r\nMartha, tell me; has she been in this way before?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOften,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the first woman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut will never be again,\xe2\x80\x9d added the second one; \xe2\x80\x9cthat is, she\xe2\x80\x99ll never\r\nwake again but once\xe2\x80\x94and mind, mistress, that won\xe2\x80\x99t be for long!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLong or short,\xe2\x80\x9d said the matron, snappishly, \xe2\x80\x9cshe won\xe2\x80\x99t find me here\r\nwhen she does wake; take care, both of you, how you worry me again for\r\nnothing. It\xe2\x80\x99s no part of my duty to see all the old women in the house\r\ndie, and I won\xe2\x80\x99t\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s more. Mind that, you impudent old harridans. If\r\nyou make a fool of me again, I\xe2\x80\x99ll soon cure you, I warrant you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe was bouncing away, when a cry from the two women, who had turned\r\ntowards the bed, caused her to look round. The patient had raised\r\nherself upright, and was stretching her arms towards them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho\xe2\x80\x99s that?\xe2\x80\x9d she cried, in a hollow voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHush, hush!\xe2\x80\x9d said one of the women, stooping over her. \xe2\x80\x9cLie down, lie\r\ndown!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll never lie down again alive!\xe2\x80\x9d said the woman, struggling. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\n_will_ tell her! Come here! Nearer! Let me whisper in your ear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe clutched the matron by the arm, and forcing her into a chair by the\r\nbedside, was about to speak, when looking round, she caught sight of\r\nthe two old women bending forward in the attitude of eager listeners.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTurn them away,\xe2\x80\x9d said the woman, drowsily; \xe2\x80\x9cmake haste! make haste!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe two old crones, chiming in together, began pouring out many piteous\r\nlamentations that the poor dear was too far gone to know her best\r\nfriends; and were uttering sundry protestations that they would never\r\nleave her, when the superior pushed them from the room, closed the\r\ndoor, and returned to the bedside. On being excluded, the old ladies\r\nchanged their tone, and cried through the keyhole that old Sally was\r\ndrunk; which, indeed, was not unlikely; since, in addition to a\r\nmoderate dose of opium prescribed by the apothecary, she was labouring\r\nunder the effects of a final taste of gin-and-water which had been\r\nprivily administered, in the openness of their hearts, by the worthy\r\nold ladies themselves.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow listen to me,\xe2\x80\x9d said the dying woman aloud, as if making a great\r\neffort to revive one latent spark of energy. \xe2\x80\x9cIn this very room\xe2\x80\x94in this\r\nvery bed\xe2\x80\x94I once nursed a pretty young creetur\xe2\x80\x99, that was brought into\r\nthe house with her feet cut and bruised with walking, and all soiled\r\nwith dust and blood. She gave birth to a boy, and died. Let me\r\nthink\xe2\x80\x94what was the year again!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind the year,\xe2\x80\x9d said the impatient auditor; \xe2\x80\x9cwhat about her?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the sick woman, relapsing into her former drowsy state,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwhat about her?\xe2\x80\x94what about\xe2\x80\x94I know!\xe2\x80\x9d she cried, jumping fiercely up:\r\nher face flushed, and her eyes starting from her head\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI robbed her, so\r\nI did! She wasn\xe2\x80\x99t cold\xe2\x80\x94I tell you she wasn\xe2\x80\x99t cold, when I stole it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStole what, for God\xe2\x80\x99s sake?\xe2\x80\x9d cried the matron, with a gesture as if\r\nshe would call for help.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_It_!\xe2\x80\x9d replied the woman, laying her hand over the other\xe2\x80\x99s mouth. \xe2\x80\x9cThe\r\nonly thing she had. She wanted clothes to keep her warm, and food to\r\neat; but she had kept it safe, and had it in her bosom. It was gold, I\r\ntell you! Rich gold, that might have saved her life!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGold!\xe2\x80\x9d echoed the matron, bending eagerly over the woman as she fell\r\nback. \xe2\x80\x9cGo on, go on\xe2\x80\x94yes\xe2\x80\x94what of it? Who was the mother? When was it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe charged me to keep it safe,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the woman with a groan, \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\ntrusted me as the only woman about her. I stole it in my heart when she\r\nfirst showed it me hanging round her neck; and the child\xe2\x80\x99s death,\r\nperhaps, is on me besides! They would have treated him better, if they\r\nhad known it all!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKnown what?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the other. \xe2\x80\x9cSpeak!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe boy grew so like his mother,\xe2\x80\x9d said the woman, rambling on, and not\r\nheeding the question, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I could never forget it when I saw his\r\nface. Poor girl! poor girl! She was so young, too! Such a gentle lamb!\r\nWait; there\xe2\x80\x99s more to tell. I have not told you all, have I?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the matron, inclining her head to catch the words, as\r\nthey came more faintly from the dying woman. \xe2\x80\x9cBe quick, or it may be\r\ntoo late!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe mother,\xe2\x80\x9d said the woman, making a more violent effort than before;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthe mother, when the pains of death first came upon her, whispered in\r\nmy ear that if her baby was born alive, and thrived, the day might come\r\nwhen it would not feel so much disgraced to hear its poor young mother\r\nnamed. \xe2\x80\x98And oh, kind Heaven!\xe2\x80\x99 she said, folding her thin hands\r\ntogether, \xe2\x80\x98whether it be boy or girl, raise up some friends for it in\r\nthis troubled world, and take pity upon a lonely desolate child,\r\nabandoned to its mercy!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe boy\xe2\x80\x99s name?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded the matron.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey _called_ him Oliver,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the woman, feebly. \xe2\x80\x9cThe gold I\r\nstole was\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes\xe2\x80\x94what?\xe2\x80\x9d cried the other.\r\n\r\nShe was bending eagerly over the woman to hear her reply; but drew\r\nback, instinctively, as she once again rose, slowly and stiffly, into a\r\nsitting posture; then, clutching the coverlid with both hands, muttered\r\nsome indistinct sounds in her throat, and fell lifeless on the bed.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStone dead!\xe2\x80\x9d said one of the old women, hurrying in as soon as the\r\ndoor was opened.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd nothing to tell, after all,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined the matron, walking\r\ncarelessly away.\r\n\r\nThe two crones, to all appearance, too busily occupied in the\r\npreparations for their dreadful duties to make any reply, were left\r\nalone, hovering about the body.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n CHAPTER XXV.\r\nWHEREIN THIS HISTORY REVERTS TO MR. FAGIN AND COMPANY\r\n\r\n\r\nWhile these things were passing in the country workhouse, Mr. Fagin sat\r\nin the old den\xe2\x80\x94the same from which Oliver had been removed by the\r\ngirl\xe2\x80\x94brooding over a dull, smoky fire. He held a pair of bellows upon\r\nhis knee, with which he had apparently been endeavouring to rouse it\r\ninto more cheerful action; but he had fallen into deep thought; and\r\nwith his arms folded on them, and his chin resting on his thumbs, fixed\r\nhis eyes, abstractedly, on the rusty bars.\r\n\r\nAt a table behind him sat the Artful Dodger, Master Charles Bates, and\r\nMr. Chitling: all intent upon a game of whist; the Artful taking dummy\r\nagainst Master Bates and Mr. Chitling. The countenance of the\r\nfirst-named gentleman, peculiarly intelligent at all times, acquired\r\ngreat additional interest from his close observance of the game, and\r\nhis attentive perusal of Mr. Chitling\xe2\x80\x99s hand; upon which, from time to\r\ntime, as occasion served, he bestowed a variety of earnest glances:\r\nwisely regulating his own play by the result of his observations upon\r\nhis neighbour\xe2\x80\x99s cards. It being a cold night, the Dodger wore his hat,\r\nas, indeed, was often his custom within doors. He also sustained a clay\r\npipe between his teeth, which he only removed for a brief space when he\r\ndeemed it necessary to apply for refreshment to a quart pot upon the\r\ntable, which stood ready filled with gin-and-water for the\r\naccommodation of the company.\r\n\r\nMaster Bates was also attentive to the play; but being of a more\r\nexcitable nature than his accomplished friend, it was observable that\r\nhe more frequently applied himself to the gin-and-water, and moreover\r\nindulged in many jests and irrelevant remarks, all highly unbecoming a\r\nscientific rubber. Indeed, the Artful, presuming upon their close\r\nattachment, more than once took occasion to reason gravely with his\r\ncompanion upon these improprieties; all of which remonstrances, Master\r\nBates received in extremely good part; merely requesting his friend to\r\nbe \xe2\x80\x9cblowed,\xe2\x80\x9d or to insert his head in a sack, or replying with some\r\nother neatly-turned witticism of a similar kind, the happy application\r\nof which, excited considerable admiration in the mind of Mr. Chitling.\r\nIt was remarkable that the latter gentleman and his partner invariably\r\nlost; and that the circumstance, so far from angering Master Bates,\r\nappeared to afford him the highest amusement, inasmuch as he laughed\r\nmost uproariously at the end of every deal, and protested that he had\r\nnever seen such a jolly game in all his born days.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s two doubles and the rub,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Chitling, with a very long\r\nface, as he drew half-a-crown from his waistcoat-pocket. \xe2\x80\x9cI never see\r\nsuch a feller as you, Jack; you win everything. Even when we\xe2\x80\x99ve good\r\ncards, Charley and I can\xe2\x80\x99t make nothing of \xe2\x80\x99em.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEither the master or the manner of this remark, which was made very\r\nruefully, delighted Charley Bates so much, that his consequent shout of\r\nlaughter roused the Jew from his reverie, and induced him to inquire\r\nwhat was the matter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMatter, Fagin!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Charley. \xe2\x80\x9cI wish you had watched the play. Tommy\r\nChitling hasn\xe2\x80\x99t won a point; and I went partners with him against the\r\nArtfull and dumb.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, ay!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, with a grin, which sufficiently demonstrated\r\nthat he was at no loss to understand the reason. \xe2\x80\x9cTry \xe2\x80\x99em again, Tom;\r\ntry \xe2\x80\x99em again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo more of it for me, thank \xe2\x80\x99ee, Fagin,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mr. Chitling; \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nhad enough. That \xe2\x80\x99ere Dodger has such a run of luck that there\xe2\x80\x99s no\r\nstanding again\xe2\x80\x99 him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHa! ha! my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Jew, \xe2\x80\x9cyou must get up very early in the\r\nmorning, to win against the Dodger.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMorning!\xe2\x80\x9d said Charley Bates; \xe2\x80\x9cyou must put your boots on over-night,\r\nand have a telescope at each eye, and a opera-glass between your\r\nshoulders, if you want to come over him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Dawkins received these handsome compliments with much philosophy,\r\nand offered to cut any gentleman in company, for the first\r\npicture-card, at a shilling at a time. Nobody accepting the challenge,\r\nand his pipe being by this time smoked out, he proceeded to amuse\r\nhimself by sketching a ground-plan of Newgate on the table with the\r\npiece of chalk which had served him in lieu of counters; whistling,\r\nmeantime, with peculiar shrillness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow precious dull you are, Tommy!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Dodger, stopping short\r\nwhen there had been a long silence; and addressing Mr. Chitling. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\r\ndo you think he\xe2\x80\x99s thinking of, Fagin?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow should I know, my dear?\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Jew, looking round as he\r\nplied the bellows. \xe2\x80\x9cAbout his losses, maybe; or the little retirement\r\nin the country that he\xe2\x80\x99s just left, eh? Ha! ha! Is that it, my dear?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot a bit of it,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Dodger, stopping the subject of\r\ndiscourse as Mr. Chitling was about to reply. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat do _you_ say,\r\nCharley?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_I_ should say,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Master Bates, with a grin, \xe2\x80\x9cthat he was\r\nuncommon sweet upon Betsy. See how he\xe2\x80\x99s a-blushing! Oh, my eye! here\xe2\x80\x99s\r\na merry-go-rounder! Tommy Chitling\xe2\x80\x99s in love! Oh, Fagin, Fagin! what a\r\nspree!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThoroughly overpowered with the notion of Mr. Chitling being the victim\r\nof the tender passion, Master Bates threw himself back in his chair\r\nwith such violence, that he lost his balance, and pitched over upon the\r\nfloor; where (the accident abating nothing of his merriment) he lay at\r\nfull length until his laugh was over, when he resumed his former\r\nposition, and began another laugh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind him, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, winking at Mr. Dawkins, and\r\ngiving Master Bates a reproving tap with the nozzle of the bellows.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBetsy\xe2\x80\x99s a fine girl. Stick up to her, Tom. Stick up to her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat I mean to say, Fagin,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mr. Chitling, very red in the\r\nface, \xe2\x80\x9cis, that that isn\xe2\x80\x99t anything to anybody here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo more it is,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Jew; \xe2\x80\x9cCharley will talk. Don\xe2\x80\x99t mind him,\r\nmy dear; don\xe2\x80\x99t mind him. Betsy\xe2\x80\x99s a fine girl. Do as she bids you, Tom,\r\nand you will make your fortune.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo I _do_ do as she bids me,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mr. Chitling; \xe2\x80\x9cI shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have\r\nbeen milled, if it hadn\xe2\x80\x99t been for her advice. But it turned out a good\r\njob for you; didn\xe2\x80\x99t it, Fagin! And what\xe2\x80\x99s six weeks of it? It must\r\ncome, some time or another, and why not in the winter time when you\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t want to go out a-walking so much; eh, Fagin?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, to be sure, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Jew.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t mind it again, Tom, would you,\xe2\x80\x9d asked the Dodger, winking\r\nupon Charley and the Jew, \xe2\x80\x9cif Bet was all right?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI mean to say that I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Tom, angrily. \xe2\x80\x9cThere, now.\r\nAh! Who\xe2\x80\x99ll say as much as that, I should like to know; eh, Fagin?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNobody, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Jew; \xe2\x80\x9cnot a soul, Tom. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know one\r\nof \xe2\x80\x99em that would do it besides you; not one of \xe2\x80\x99em, my dear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI might have got clear off, if I\xe2\x80\x99d split upon her; mightn\xe2\x80\x99t I, Fagin?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nangrily pursued the poor half-witted dupe. \xe2\x80\x9cA word from me would have\r\ndone it; wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t it, Fagin?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be sure it would, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Jew.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I didn\xe2\x80\x99t blab it; did I, Fagin?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded Tom, pouring question\r\nupon question with great volubility.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no, to be sure,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Jew; \xe2\x80\x9cyou were too stout-hearted for\r\nthat. A deal too stout, my dear!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps I was,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined Tom, looking round; \xe2\x80\x9cand if I was, what\xe2\x80\x99s to\r\nlaugh at, in that; eh, Fagin?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Jew, perceiving that Mr. Chitling was considerably roused, hastened\r\nto assure him that nobody was laughing; and to prove the gravity of the\r\ncompany, appealed to Master Bates, the principal offender. But,\r\nunfortunately, Charley, in opening his mouth to reply that he was never\r\nmore serious in his life, was unable to prevent the escape of such a\r\nviolent roar, that the abused Mr. Chitling, without any preliminary\r\nceremonies, rushed across the room and aimed a blow at the offender;\r\nwho, being skilful in evading pursuit, ducked to avoid it, and chose\r\nhis time so well that it lighted on the chest of the merry old\r\ngentleman, and caused him to stagger to the wall, where he stood\r\npanting for breath, while Mr. Chitling looked on in intense dismay.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHark!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the Dodger at this moment, \xe2\x80\x9cI heard the tinkler.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nCatching up the light, he crept softly upstairs.\r\n\r\nThe bell was rung again, with some impatience, while the party were in\r\ndarkness. After a short pause, the Dodger reappeared, and whispered\r\nFagin mysteriously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the Jew, \xe2\x80\x9calone?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Dodger nodded in the affirmative, and, shading the flame of the\r\ncandle with his hand, gave Charley Bates a private intimation, in dumb\r\nshow, that he had better not be funny just then. Having performed this\r\nfriendly office, he fixed his eyes on the Jew\xe2\x80\x99s face, and awaited his\r\ndirections.\r\n\r\nThe old man bit his yellow fingers, and meditated for some seconds; his\r\nface working with agitation the while, as if he dreaded something, and\r\nfeared to know the worst. At length he raised his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is he?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\nThe Dodger pointed to the floor above, and made a gesture, as if to\r\nleave the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, answering the mute inquiry; \xe2\x80\x9cbring him down. Hush!\r\nQuiet, Charley! Gently, Tom! Scarce, scarce!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis brief direction to Charley Bates, and his recent antagonist, was\r\nsoftly and immediately obeyed. There was no sound of their whereabout,\r\nwhen the Dodger descended the stairs, bearing the light in his hand,\r\nand followed by a man in a coarse smock-frock; who, after casting a\r\nhurried glance round the room, pulled off a large wrapper which had\r\nconcealed the lower portion of his face, and disclosed: all haggard,\r\nunwashed, and unshorn: the features of flash Toby Crackit.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow are you, Faguey?\xe2\x80\x9d said this worthy, nodding to the Jew. \xe2\x80\x9cPop that\r\nshawl away in my castor, Dodger, so that I may know where to find it\r\nwhen I cut; that\xe2\x80\x99s the time of day! You\xe2\x80\x99ll be a fine young cracksman\r\nafore the old file now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith these words he pulled up the smock-frock; and, winding it round\r\nhis middle, drew a chair to the fire, and placed his feet upon the hob.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee there, Faguey,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, pointing disconsolately to his top boots;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cnot a drop of Day and Martin since you know when; not a bubble of\r\nblacking, by Jove! But don\xe2\x80\x99t look at me in that way, man. All in good\r\ntime. I can\xe2\x80\x99t talk about business till I\xe2\x80\x99ve eat and drank; so produce\r\nthe sustainance, and let\xe2\x80\x99s have a quiet fill-out for the first time\r\nthese three days!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Jew motioned to the Dodger to place what eatables there were, upon\r\nthe table; and, seating himself opposite the housebreaker, waited his\r\nleisure.\r\n\r\nTo judge from appearances, Toby was by no means in a hurry to open the\r\nconversation. At first, the Jew contented himself with patiently\r\nwatching his countenance, as if to gain from its expression some clue\r\nto the intelligence he brought; but in vain.\r\n\r\nHe looked tired and worn, but there was the same complacent repose upon\r\nhis features that they always wore: and through dirt, and beard, and\r\nwhisker, there still shone, unimpaired, the self-satisfied smirk of\r\nflash Toby Crackit. Then the Jew, in an agony of impatience, watched\r\nevery morsel he put into his mouth; pacing up and down the room,\r\nmeanwhile, in irrepressible excitement. It was all of no use. Toby\r\ncontinued to eat with the utmost outward indifference, until he could\r\neat no more; then, ordering the Dodger out, he closed the door, mixed a\r\nglass of spirits and water, and composed himself for talking.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFirst and foremost, Faguey,\xe2\x80\x9d said Toby.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes!\xe2\x80\x9d interposed the Jew, drawing up his chair.\r\n\r\nMr. Crackit stopped to take a draught of spirits and water, and to\r\ndeclare that the gin was excellent; then placing his feet against the\r\nlow mantelpiece, so as to bring his boots to about the level of his\r\neye, he quietly resumed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFirst and foremost, Faguey,\xe2\x80\x9d said the housebreaker, \xe2\x80\x9chow\xe2\x80\x99s Bill?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat!\xe2\x80\x9d screamed the Jew, starting from his seat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, you don\xe2\x80\x99t mean to say\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d began Toby, turning pale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMean!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the Jew, stamping furiously on the ground. \xe2\x80\x9cWhere are\r\nthey? Sikes and the boy! Where are they? Where have they been? Where\r\nare they hiding? Why have they not been here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe crack failed,\xe2\x80\x9d said Toby faintly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know it,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Jew, tearing a newspaper from his pocket and\r\npointing to it. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat more?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey fired and hit the boy. We cut over the fields at the back, with\r\nhim between us\xe2\x80\x94straight as the crow flies\xe2\x80\x94through hedge and ditch. They\r\ngave chase. Damme! the whole country was awake, and the dogs upon us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe boy!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBill had him on his back, and scudded like the wind. We stopped to\r\ntake him between us; his head hung down, and he was cold. They were\r\nclose upon our heels; every man for himself, and each from the gallows!\r\nWe parted company, and left the youngster lying in a ditch. Alive or\r\ndead, that\xe2\x80\x99s all I know about him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Jew stopped to hear no more; but uttering a loud yell, and twining\r\nhis hands in his hair, rushed from the room, and from the house.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n CHAPTER XXVI.\r\nIN WHICH A MYSTERIOUS CHARACTER APPEARS UPON THE SCENE; AND MANY\r\nTHINGS, INSEPARABLE FROM THIS HISTORY, ARE DONE AND PERFORMED\r\n\r\n\r\nThe old man had gained the street corner, before he began to recover\r\nthe effect of Toby Crackit\xe2\x80\x99s intelligence. He had relaxed nothing of\r\nhis unusual speed; but was still pressing onward, in the same wild and\r\ndisordered manner, when the sudden dashing past of a carriage: and a\r\nboisterous cry from the foot passengers, who saw his danger: drove him\r\nback upon the pavement. Avoiding, as much as was possible, all the main\r\nstreets, and skulking only through the by-ways and alleys, he at length\r\nemerged on Snow Hill. Here he walked even faster than before; nor did\r\nhe linger until he had again turned into a court; when, as if conscious\r\nthat he was now in his proper element, he fell into his usual shuffling\r\npace, and seemed to breathe more freely.\r\n\r\nNear to the spot on which Snow Hill and Holborn Hill meet, opens, upon\r\nthe right hand as you come out of the City, a narrow and dismal alley,\r\nleading to Saffron Hill. In its filthy shops are exposed for sale huge\r\nbunches of second-hand silk handkerchiefs, of all sizes and patterns;\r\nfor here reside the traders who purchase them from pick-pockets.\r\nHundreds of these handkerchiefs hang dangling from pegs outside the\r\nwindows or flaunting from the door-posts; and the shelves, within, are\r\npiled with them. Confined as the limits of Field Lane are, it has its\r\nbarber, its coffee-shop, its beer-shop, and its fried-fish warehouse.\r\nIt is a commercial colony of itself: the emporium of petty larceny:\r\nvisited at early morning, and setting-in of dusk, by silent merchants,\r\nwho traffic in dark back-parlours, and who go as strangely as they\r\ncome. Here, the clothesman, the shoe-vamper, and the rag-merchant,\r\ndisplay their goods, as sign-boards to the petty thief; here, stores of\r\nold iron and bones, and heaps of mildewy fragments of woollen-stuff and\r\nlinen, rust and rot in the grimy cellars.\r\n\r\nIt was into this place that the Jew turned. He was well known to the\r\nsallow denizens of the lane; for such of them as were on the look-out\r\nto buy or sell, nodded, familiarly, as he passed along. He replied to\r\ntheir salutations in the same way; but bestowed no closer recognition\r\nuntil he reached the further end of the alley; when he stopped, to\r\naddress a salesman of small stature, who had squeezed as much of his\r\nperson into a child\xe2\x80\x99s chair as the chair would hold, and was smoking a\r\npipe at his warehouse door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, the sight of you, Mr. Fagin, would cure the hoptalmy!\xe2\x80\x9d said this\r\nrespectable trader, in acknowledgment of the Jew\xe2\x80\x99s inquiry after his\r\nhealth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe neighbourhood was a little too hot, Lively,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fagin, elevating\r\nhis eyebrows, and crossing his hands upon his shoulders.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I\xe2\x80\x99ve heerd that complaint of it, once or twice before,\xe2\x80\x9d replied\r\nthe trader; \xe2\x80\x9cbut it soon cools down again; don\xe2\x80\x99t you find it so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFagin nodded in the affirmative. Pointing in the direction of Saffron\r\nHill, he inquired whether any one was up yonder to-night.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt the Cripples?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the man.\r\n\r\nThe Jew nodded.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me see,\xe2\x80\x9d pursued the merchant, reflecting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, there\xe2\x80\x99s some half-dozen of \xe2\x80\x99em gone in, that I knows. I don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nthink your friend\xe2\x80\x99s there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSikes is not, I suppose?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the Jew, with a disappointed\r\ncountenance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Non istwentus_, as the lawyers say,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the little man, shaking\r\nhis head, and looking amazingly sly. \xe2\x80\x9cHave you got anything in my line\r\nto-night?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing to-night,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, turning away.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you going up to the Cripples, Fagin?\xe2\x80\x9d cried the little man,\r\ncalling after him. \xe2\x80\x9cStop! I don\xe2\x80\x99t mind if I have a drop there with\r\nyou!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut as the Jew, looking back, waved his hand to intimate that he\r\npreferred being alone; and, moreover, as the little man could not very\r\neasily disengage himself from the chair; the sign of the Cripples was,\r\nfor a time, bereft of the advantage of Mr. Lively\xe2\x80\x99s presence. By the\r\ntime he had got upon his legs, the Jew had disappeared; so Mr. Lively,\r\nafter ineffectually standing on tiptoe, in the hope of catching sight\r\nof him, again forced himself into the little chair, and, exchanging a\r\nshake of the head with a lady in the opposite shop, in which doubt and\r\nmistrust were plainly mingled, resumed his pipe with a grave demeanour.\r\n\r\nThe Three Cripples, or rather the Cripples; which was the sign by which\r\nthe establishment was familiarly known to its patrons: was the\r\npublic-house in which Mr. Sikes and his dog have already figured.\r\nMerely making a sign to a man at the bar, Fagin walked straight\r\nupstairs, and opening the door of a room, and softly insinuating\r\nhimself into the chamber, looked anxiously about: shading his eyes with\r\nhis hand, as if in search of some particular person.\r\n\r\nThe room was illuminated by two gas-lights; the glare of which was\r\nprevented by the barred shutters, and closely-drawn curtains of faded\r\nred, from being visible outside. The ceiling was blackened, to prevent\r\nits colour from being injured by the flaring of the lamps; and the\r\nplace was so full of dense tobacco smoke, that at first it was scarcely\r\npossible to discern anything more. By degrees, however, as some of it\r\ncleared away through the open door, an assemblage of heads, as confused\r\nas the noises that greeted the ear, might be made out; and as the eye\r\ngrew more accustomed to the scene, the spectator gradually became aware\r\nof the presence of a numerous company, male and female, crowded round a\r\nlong table: at the upper end of which, sat a chairman with a hammer of\r\noffice in his hand; while a professional gentleman with a bluish nose,\r\nand his face tied up for the benefit of a toothache, presided at a\r\njingling piano in a remote corner.\r\n\r\nAs Fagin stepped softly in, the professional gentleman, running over\r\nthe keys by way of prelude, occasioned a general cry of order for a\r\nsong; which having subsided, a young lady proceeded to entertain the\r\ncompany with a ballad in four verses, between each of which the\r\naccompanyist played the melody all through, as loud as he could. When\r\nthis was over, the chairman gave a sentiment, after which, the\r\nprofessional gentleman on the chairman\xe2\x80\x99s right and left volunteered a\r\nduet, and sang it, with great applause.\r\n\r\nIt was curious to observe some faces which stood out prominently from\r\namong the group. There was the chairman himself, (the landlord of the\r\nhouse,) a coarse, rough, heavy built fellow, who, while the songs were\r\nproceeding, rolled his eyes hither and thither, and, seeming to give\r\nhimself up to joviality, had an eye for everything that was done, and\r\nan ear for everything that was said\xe2\x80\x94and sharp ones, too. Near him were\r\nthe singers: receiving, with professional indifference, the compliments\r\nof the company, and applying themselves, in turn, to a dozen proffered\r\nglasses of spirits and water, tendered by their more boisterous\r\nadmirers; whose countenances, expressive of almost every vice in almost\r\nevery grade, irresistibly attracted the attention, by their very\r\nrepulsiveness. Cunning, ferocity, and drunkeness in all its stages,\r\nwere there, in their strongest aspect; and women: some with the last\r\nlingering tinge of their early freshness almost fading as you looked:\r\nothers with every mark and stamp of their sex utterly beaten out, and\r\npresenting but one loathsome blank of profligacy and crime; some mere\r\ngirls, others but young women, and none past the prime of life; formed\r\nthe darkest and saddest portion of this dreary picture.\r\n\r\nFagin, troubled by no grave emotions, looked eagerly from face to face\r\nwhile these proceedings were in progress; but apparently without\r\nmeeting that of which he was in search. Succeeding, at length, in\r\ncatching the eye of the man who occupied the chair, he beckoned to him\r\nslightly, and left the room, as quietly as he had entered it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat can I do for you, Mr. Fagin?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the man, as he followed\r\nhim out to the landing. \xe2\x80\x9cWon\xe2\x80\x99t you join us? They\xe2\x80\x99ll be delighted, every\r\none of \xe2\x80\x99em.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Jew shook his head impatiently, and said in a whisper, \xe2\x80\x9cIs _he_\r\nhere?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd no news of Barney?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Fagin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNone,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the landlord of the Cripples; for it was he. \xe2\x80\x9cHe won\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nstir till it\xe2\x80\x99s all safe. Depend on it, they\xe2\x80\x99re on the scent down there;\r\nand that if he moved, he\xe2\x80\x99d blow upon the thing at once. He\xe2\x80\x99s all right\r\nenough, Barney is, else I should have heard of him. I\xe2\x80\x99ll pound it, that\r\nBarney\xe2\x80\x99s managing properly. Let him alone for that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill _he_ be here to-night?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the Jew, laying the same emphasis\r\non the pronoun as before.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonks, do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the landlord, hesitating.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHush!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew. \xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertain,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the man, drawing a gold watch from his fob; \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nexpected him here before now. If you\xe2\x80\x99ll wait ten minutes, he\xe2\x80\x99ll be\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, hastily; as though, however desirous he might\r\nbe to see the person in question, he was nevertheless relieved by his\r\nabsence. \xe2\x80\x9cTell him I came here to see him; and that he must come to me\r\nto-night. No, say to-morrow. As he is not here, to-morrow will be time\r\nenough.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood!\xe2\x80\x9d said the man. \xe2\x80\x9cNothing more?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot a word now,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, descending the stairs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say,\xe2\x80\x9d said the other, looking over the rails, and speaking in a\r\nhoarse whisper; \xe2\x80\x9cwhat a time this would be for a sell! I\xe2\x80\x99ve got Phil\r\nBarker here: so drunk, that a boy might take him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! But it\xe2\x80\x99s not Phil Barker\xe2\x80\x99s time,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, looking up. \xe2\x80\x9cPhil\r\nhas something more to do, before we can afford to part with him; so go\r\nback to the company, my dear, and tell them to lead merry lives\xe2\x80\x94_while\r\nthey last_. Ha! ha! ha!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe landlord reciprocated the old man\xe2\x80\x99s laugh; and returned to his\r\nguests. The Jew was no sooner alone, than his countenance resumed its\r\nformer expression of anxiety and thought. After a brief reflection, he\r\ncalled a hack-cabriolet, and bade the man drive towards Bethnal Green.\r\nHe dismissed him within some quarter of a mile of Mr. Sikes\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nresidence, and performed the short remainder of the distance, on foot.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d muttered the Jew, as he knocked at the door, \xe2\x80\x9cif there is any\r\ndeep play here, I shall have it out of you, my girl, cunning as you\r\nare.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe was in her room, the woman said. Fagin crept softly upstairs, and\r\nentered it without any previous ceremony. The girl was alone; lying\r\nwith her head upon the table, and her hair straggling over it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe has been drinking,\xe2\x80\x9d thought the Jew, cooly, \xe2\x80\x9cor perhaps she is\r\nonly miserable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe old man turned to close the door, as he made this reflection; the\r\nnoise thus occasioned, roused the girl. She eyed his crafty face\r\nnarrowly, as she inquired to his recital of Toby Crackit\xe2\x80\x99s story. When\r\nit was concluded, she sank into her former attitude, but spoke not a\r\nword. She pushed the candle impatiently away; and once or twice as she\r\nfeverishly changed her position, shuffled her feet upon the ground; but\r\nthis was all.\r\n\r\nDuring the silence, the Jew looked restlessly about the room, as if to\r\nassure himself that there were no appearances of Sikes having covertly\r\nreturned. Apparently satisfied with his inspection, he coughed twice or\r\nthrice, and made as many efforts to open a conversation; but the girl\r\nheeded him no more than if he had been made of stone. At length he made\r\nanother attempt; and rubbing his hands together, said, in his most\r\nconciliatory tone,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd where should you think Bill was now, my dear?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe girl moaned out some half intelligible reply, that she could not\r\ntell; and seemed, from the smothered noise that escaped her, to be\r\ncrying.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the boy, too,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, straining his eyes to catch a glimpse\r\nof her face. \xe2\x80\x9cPoor leetle child! Left in a ditch, Nance; only think!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe child,\xe2\x80\x9d said the girl, suddenly looking up, \xe2\x80\x9cis better where he\r\nis, than among us; and if no harm comes to Bill from it, I hope he lies\r\ndead in the ditch and that his young bones may rot there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the Jew, in amazement.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, I do,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the girl, meeting his gaze. \xe2\x80\x9cI shall be glad to\r\nhave him away from my eyes, and to know that the worst is over. I can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nbear to have him about me. The sight of him turns me against myself,\r\nand all of you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPooh!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, scornfully. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re drunk.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAm I?\xe2\x80\x9d cried the girl bitterly. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s no fault of yours, if I am not!\r\nYou\xe2\x80\x99d never have me anything else, if you had your will, except\r\nnow;\xe2\x80\x94the humour doesn\xe2\x80\x99t suit you, doesn\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo!\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined the Jew, furiously. \xe2\x80\x9cIt does not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cChange it, then!\xe2\x80\x9d responded the girl, with a laugh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cChange it!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the Jew, exasperated beyond all bounds by his\r\ncompanion\xe2\x80\x99s unexpected obstinacy, and the vexation of the night, \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\n_will_ change it! Listen to me, you drab. Listen to me, who with six\r\nwords, can strangle Sikes as surely as if I had his bull\xe2\x80\x99s throat\r\nbetween my fingers now. If he comes back, and leaves the boy behind\r\nhim; if he gets off free, and dead or alive, fails to restore him to\r\nme; murder him yourself if you would have him escape Jack Ketch. And do\r\nit the moment he sets foot in this room, or mind me, it will be too\r\nlate!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is all this?\xe2\x80\x9d cried the girl involuntarily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d pursued Fagin, mad with rage. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen the boy\xe2\x80\x99s worth\r\nhundreds of pounds to me, am I to lose what chance threw me in the way\r\nof getting safely, through the whims of a drunken gang that I could\r\nwhistle away the lives of! And me bound, too, to a born devil that only\r\nwants the will, and has the power to, to\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPanting for breath, the old man stammered for a word; and in that\r\ninstant checked the torrent of his wrath, and changed his whole\r\ndemeanour. A moment before, his clenched hands had grasped the air; his\r\neyes had dilated; and his face grown livid with passion; but now, he\r\nshrunk into a chair, and, cowering together, trembled with the\r\napprehension of having himself disclosed some hidden villainy. After a\r\nshort silence, he ventured to look round at his companion. He appeared\r\nsomewhat reassured, on beholding her in the same listless attitude from\r\nwhich he had first roused her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNancy, dear!\xe2\x80\x9d croaked the Jew, in his usual voice. \xe2\x80\x9cDid you mind me,\r\ndear?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t worry me now, Fagin!\xe2\x80\x9d replied the girl, raising her head\r\nlanguidly. \xe2\x80\x9cIf Bill has not done it this time, he will another. He has\r\ndone many a good job for you, and will do many more when he can; and\r\nwhen he can\xe2\x80\x99t he won\xe2\x80\x99t; so no more about that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRegarding this boy, my dear?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, rubbing the palms of his\r\nhands nervously together.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe boy must take his chance with the rest,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Nancy,\r\nhastily; \xe2\x80\x9cand I say again, I hope he is dead, and out of harm\xe2\x80\x99s way,\r\nand out of yours,\xe2\x80\x94that is, if Bill comes to no harm. And if Toby got\r\nclear off, Bill\xe2\x80\x99s pretty sure to be safe; for Bill\xe2\x80\x99s worth two of Toby\r\nany time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd about what I was saying, my dear?\xe2\x80\x9d observed the Jew, keeping his\r\nglistening eye steadily upon her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must say it all over again, if it\xe2\x80\x99s anything you want me to do,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nrejoined Nancy; \xe2\x80\x9cand if it is, you had better wait till to-morrow. You\r\nput me up for a minute; but now I\xe2\x80\x99m stupid again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFagin put several other questions: all with the same drift of\r\nascertaining whether the girl had profited by his unguarded hints; but,\r\nshe answered them so readily, and was withal so utterly unmoved by his\r\nsearching looks, that his original impression of her being more than a\r\ntrifle in liquor, was confirmed. Nancy, indeed, was not exempt from a\r\nfailing which was very common among the Jew\xe2\x80\x99s female pupils; and in\r\nwhich, in their tenderer years, they were rather encouraged than\r\nchecked. Her disordered appearance, and a wholesale perfume of Geneva\r\nwhich pervaded the apartment, afforded strong confirmatory evidence of\r\nthe justice of the Jew\xe2\x80\x99s supposition; and when, after indulging in the\r\ntemporary display of violence above described, she subsided, first into\r\ndullness, and afterwards into a compound of feelings: under the\r\ninfluence of which she shed tears one minute, and in the next gave\r\nutterance to various exclamations of \xe2\x80\x9cNever say die!\xe2\x80\x9d and divers\r\ncalculations as to what might be the amount of the odds so long as a\r\nlady or gentleman was happy, Mr. Fagin, who had had considerable\r\nexperience of such matters in his time, saw, with great satisfaction,\r\nthat she was very far gone indeed.\r\n\r\nHaving eased his mind by this discovery; and having accomplished his\r\ntwofold object of imparting to the girl what he had, that night, heard,\r\nand of ascertaining, with his own eyes, that Sikes had not returned,\r\nMr. Fagin again turned his face homeward: leaving his young friend\r\nasleep, with her head upon the table.\r\n\r\nIt was within an hour of midnight. The weather being dark, and piercing\r\ncold, he had no great temptation to loiter. The sharp wind that scoured\r\nthe streets, seemed to have cleared them of passengers, as of dust and\r\nmud, for few people were abroad, and they were to all appearance\r\nhastening fast home. It blew from the right quarter for the Jew,\r\nhowever, and straight before it he went: trembling, and shivering, as\r\nevery fresh gust drove him rudely on his way.\r\n\r\nHe had reached the corner of his own street, and was already fumbling\r\nin his pocket for the door-key, when a dark figure emerged from a\r\nprojecting entrance which lay in deep shadow, and, crossing the road,\r\nglided up to him unperceived.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFagin!\xe2\x80\x9d whispered a voice close to his ear.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, turning quickly round, \xe2\x80\x9cis that\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes!\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted the stranger. \xe2\x80\x9cI have been lingering here these two\r\nhours. As he\r\nspoke, it closed with a loud noise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat wasn\xe2\x80\x99t my doing,\xe2\x80\x9d said the other man, feeling his way. \xe2\x80\x9cThe wind\r\nblew it to, or it shut of its own accord: one or the other. Look sharp\r\nwith the light, or I shall knock my brains out against something in\r\nthis confounded hole.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFagin stealthily descended the kitchen stairs. After a short absence,\r\nhe returned with a lighted candle, and the intelligence that Toby\r\nCrackit was asleep in the back room below, and that the boys were in\r\nthe front one. Beckoning the man to follow him, he led the way\r\nupstairs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe can say the few words we\xe2\x80\x99ve got to say in here, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nJew, throwing open a door on the first floor; \xe2\x80\x9cand as there are holes\r\nin the shutters, and we never show lights to our neighbours, we\xe2\x80\x99ll set\r\nthe candle on the stairs. There!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith those words, the Jew, stooping down, placed the candle on an upper\r\nflight of stairs, exactly opposite to the room door. This done, he led\r\nthe way into the apartment; which was destitute of all movables save a\r\nbroken arm-chair, and an old couch or sofa without covering, which\r\nstood behind the door. Upon this piece of furniture, the stranger sat\r\nhimself with the air of a weary man; and the Jew, drawing up the\r\narm-chair opposite, they sat face to face. It was not quite dark; the\r\ndoor was partially open; and the candle outside, threw a feeble\r\nreflection on the opposite wall.\r\n\r\nThey conversed for some time in whispers. Though nothing of the\r\nconversation was distinguishable beyond a few disjointed words here and\r\nthere, a listener might easily have perceived that Fagin appeared to be\r\ndefending himself against some remarks of the stranger; and that the\r\nlatter was in a state of considerable irritation. They might have been\r\ntalking, thus, for a quarter of an hour or more, when Monks\xe2\x80\x94by which\r\nname the Jew had designated the strange man several times in the course\r\nof their colloquy\xe2\x80\x94said, raising his voice a little,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI tell you again, it was badly planned. Why not have kept him here\r\namong the rest, and made a sneaking, snivelling pickpocket of him at\r\nonce?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly hear him!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the Jew, shrugging his shoulders.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, do you mean to say you couldn\xe2\x80\x99t have done it, if you had chosen?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ndemanded Monks, sternly. \xe2\x80\x9cHaven\xe2\x80\x99t you done it, with other boys, scores\r\nof times? If you had had patience for a twelvemonth, at most, couldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nyou have got him convicted, and sent safely out of the kingdom; perhaps\r\nfor life?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhose turn would that have served, my dear?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the Jew humbly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMine,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut not mine,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, submissively. \xe2\x80\x9cHe might have become of\r\nuse to me. When there are two parties to a bargain, it is only\r\nreasonable that the interests of both should be consulted; is it, my\r\ngood friend?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat then?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded Monks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI saw it was not easy to train him to the business,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Jew;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9che was not like other boys in the same circumstances.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCurse him, no!\xe2\x80\x9d muttered the man, \xe2\x80\x9cor he would have been a thief, long\r\nago.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI had no hold upon him to make him worse,\xe2\x80\x9d pursued the Jew, anxiously\r\nwatching the countenance of his companion. \xe2\x80\x9cHis hand was not in. I had\r\nnothing to frighten him with; which we always must have in the\r\nbeginning, or we labour in vain. What could I do? Send him out with the\r\nDodger and Charley?
