The gate at which they had\r\nentered, was softly unfastened and opened by Monks; merely exchanging a\r\nnod with their mysterious acquaintance, the married couple emerged into\r\nthe wet and darkness outside.\r\n\r\nThey were no sooner gone, than Monks, who appeared to entertain an\r\ninvincible repugnance to being left alone, called to a boy who had been\r\nhidden somewhere below. Bidding him go first, and bear the light, he\r\nreturned to the chamber he had just quitted.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n CHAPTER XXXIX.\r\nINTRODUCES SOME RESPECTABLE CHARACTERS WITH WHOM THE READER IS ALREADY\r\nACQUAINTED, AND SHOWS HOW MONKS AND THE JEW LAID THEIR WORTHY HEADS\r\nTOGETHER\r\n\r\n\r\nOn the evening following that upon which the three worthies mentioned\r\nin the last chapter, disposed of their little matter of business as\r\ntherein narrated, Mr. William Sikes, awakening from a nap, drowsily\r\ngrowled forth an inquiry what time of night it was.\r\n\r\nThe room in which Mr. Sikes propounded this question, was not one of\r\nthose he had tenanted, previous to the Chertsey expedition, although it\r\nwas in the same quarter of the town, and was situated at no great\r\ndistance from his former lodgings. It was not, in appearance, so\r\ndesirable a habitation as his old quarters: being a mean and\r\nbadly-furnished apartment, of very limited size; lighted only by one\r\nsmall window in the shelving roof, and abutting on a close and dirty\r\nlane. Nor were there wanting other indications of the good gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhaving gone down in the world of late: for a great scarcity of\r\nfurniture, and total absence of comfort, together with the\r\ndisappearance of all such small moveables as spare clothes and linen,\r\nbespoke a state of extreme poverty; while the meagre and attenuated\r\ncondition of Mr. Sikes himself would have fully confirmed these\r\nsymptoms, if they had stood in any need of corroboration.\r\n\r\nThe housebreaker was lying on the bed, wrapped in his white great-coat,\r\nby way of dressing-gown, and displaying a set of features in no degree\r\nimproved by the cadaverous hue of illness, and the addition of a soiled\r\nnightcap, and a stiff, black beard of a week\xe2\x80\x99s growth. The dog sat at\r\nthe bedside: now eyeing his master with a wistful look, and now\r\npricking his ears, and uttering a low growl as some noise in the\r\nstreet, or in the lower part of the house, attracted his attention.\r\nSeated by the window, busily engaged in patching an old waistcoat which\r\nformed a portion of the robber\xe2\x80\x99s ordinary dress, was a female: so pale\r\nand reduced with watching and privation, that there would have been\r\nconsiderable difficulty in recognising her as the same Nancy who has\r\nalready figured in this tale, but for the voice in which she replied to\r\nMr. Sikes\xe2\x80\x99s question.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot long gone seven,\xe2\x80\x9d said the girl. \xe2\x80\x9cHow do you feel to-night, Bill?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs weak as water,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mr. Sikes, with an imprecation on his eyes\r\nand limbs. \xe2\x80\x9cHere; lend us a hand, and let me get off this thundering\r\nbed anyhow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIllness had not improved Mr. Sikes\xe2\x80\x99s temper; for, as the girl raised\r\nhim up and led him to a chair, he muttered various curses on her\r\nawkwardness, and struck her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhining are you?\xe2\x80\x9d said Sikes. \xe2\x80\x9cCome! Don\xe2\x80\x99t stand snivelling there. If\r\nyou can\xe2\x80\x99t do anything better than that, cut off altogether. D\xe2\x80\x99ye hear\r\nme?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hear you,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the girl, turning her face aside, and forcing a\r\nlaugh. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat fancy have you got in your head now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! you\xe2\x80\x99ve thought better of it, have you?\xe2\x80\x9d growled Sikes, marking the\r\ntear which trembled in her eye. \xe2\x80\x9cAll the better for you, you have.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, you don\xe2\x80\x99t mean to say, you\xe2\x80\x99d be hard upon me to-night, Bill,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid the girl, laying her hand upon his shoulder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mr. Sikes. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuch a number of nights,\xe2\x80\x9d said the girl, with a touch of woman\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ntenderness, which communicated something like sweetness of tone, even\r\nto her voice: \xe2\x80\x9csuch a number of nights as I\xe2\x80\x99ve been patient with you,\r\nnursing and caring for you, as if you had been a child: and this the\r\nfirst that I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen you like yourself; you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have served me as\r\nyou did just now, if you\xe2\x80\x99d thought of that, would you? Come, come; say\r\nyou wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined Mr. Sikes, \xe2\x80\x9cI wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t. Why, damme, now, the\r\ngirls\xe2\x80\x99s whining again!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s nothing,\xe2\x80\x9d said the girl, throwing herself into a chair. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nyou seem to mind me. It\xe2\x80\x99ll soon be over.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99ll be over?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded Mr. Sikes in a savage voice. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat foolery\r\nare you up to, now, again? Get up and bustle about, and don\xe2\x80\x99t come over\r\nme with your woman\xe2\x80\x99s nonsense.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt any other time, this remonstrance, and the tone in which it was\r\ndelivered, would have had the desired effect; but the girl being really\r\nweak and exhausted, dropped her head over the back of the chair, and\r\nfainted, before Mr. Sikes could get out a few of the appropriate oaths\r\nwith which, on similar occasions, he was accustomed to garnish his\r\nthreats. Not knowing, very well, what to do, in this uncommon\r\nemergency; for Miss Nancy\xe2\x80\x99s hysterics were usually of that violent kind\r\nwhich the patient fights and struggles out of, without much assistance;\r\nMr. Sikes tried a little blasphemy: and finding that mode of treatment\r\nwholly ineffectual, called for assistance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter here, my dear?\xe2\x80\x9d said Fagin, looking in.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLend a hand to the girl, can\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d replied Sikes impatiently. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nstand chattering and grinning at me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith an exclamation of surprise, Fagin hastened to the girl\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nassistance, while Mr. John Dawkins (otherwise the Artful Dodger), who\r\nhad followed his venerable friend into the room, hastily deposited on\r\nthe floor a bundle with which he was laden; and snatching a bottle from\r\nthe grasp of Master Charles Bates who came close at his heels, uncorked\r\nit in a twinkling with his teeth, and poured a portion of its contents\r\ndown the patient\xe2\x80\x99s throat: previously taking a taste, himself, to\r\nprevent mistakes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive her a whiff of fresh air with the bellows, Charley,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr.\r\nDawkins; \xe2\x80\x9cand you slap her hands, Fagin, while Bill undoes the\r\npetticuts.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThese united restoratives, administered with great energy: especially\r\nthat department consigned to Master Bates, who appeared to consider his\r\nshare in the proceedings, a piece of unexampled pleasantry: were not\r\nlong in producing the desired effect. The girl gradually recovered her\r\nsenses; and, staggering to a chair by the bedside, hid her face upon\r\nthe pillow: leaving Mr. Sikes to confront the new comers, in some\r\nastonishment at their unlooked-for appearance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, what evil wind has blowed you here?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked Fagin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo evil wind at all, my dear, for evil winds blow nobody any good; and\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ve brought something good with me, that you\xe2\x80\x99ll be glad to see.\r\nDodger, my dear, open the bundle; and give Bill the little trifles that\r\nwe spent all our money on, this morning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn compliance with Mr. Fagin\xe2\x80\x99s request, the Artful untied this bundle,\r\nwhich was of large size, and formed of an old table-cloth; and handed\r\nthe articles it contained, one by one, to Charley Bates: who placed\r\nthem on the table, with various encomiums on their rarity and\r\nexcellence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSitch a rabbit pie, Bill,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed that young gentleman, disclosing\r\nto view a huge pasty; \xe2\x80\x9csitch delicate creeturs, with sitch tender\r\nlimbs, Bill, that the wery bones melt in your mouth, and there\xe2\x80\x99s no\r\noccasion to pick \xe2\x80\x99em; half a pound of seven and six-penny green, so\r\nprecious strong that if you mix it with biling water, it\xe2\x80\x99ll go nigh to\r\nblow the lid of the tea-pot off; a pound and a half of moist sugar that\r\nthe niggers didn\xe2\x80\x99t work at all at, afore they got it up to sitch a\r\npitch of goodness,\xe2\x80\x94oh no! Two half-quartern brans; pound of best fresh;\r\npiece of double Glo\xe2\x80\x99ster; and, to wind up all, some of the richest sort\r\nyou ever lushed!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nUttering this last panegyric, Master Bates produced, from one of his\r\nextensive pockets, a full-sized wine-bottle, carefully corked; while\r\nMr. Dawkins, at the same instant, poured out a wine-glassful of raw\r\nspirits from the bottle he carried: which the invalid tossed down his\r\nthroat without a moment\xe2\x80\x99s hesitation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x9d said Fagin, rubbing his hands with great satisfaction. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\ndo, Bill; you\xe2\x80\x99ll do now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Mr. Sikes; \xe2\x80\x9cI might have been done for, twenty times\r\nover, afore you\xe2\x80\x99d have done anything to help me. He\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nmake his fortun\xe2\x80\x99 on the stage that dog would, and rewive the drayma\r\nbesides.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold your din,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Sikes, as the dog retreated under the bed: still\r\ngrowling angrily. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat have you got to say for yourself, you withered\r\nold fence, eh?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was away from London, a week and more, my dear, on a plant,\xe2\x80\x9d replied\r\nthe Jew.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what about the other fortnight?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded Sikes. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat about the\r\nother fortnight that you\xe2\x80\x99ve left me lying here, like a sick rat in his\r\nhole?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI couldn\xe2\x80\x99t help it, Bill. I can\xe2\x80\x99t go into a long explanation before\r\ncompany; but I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t help it, upon my honour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUpon your what?\xe2\x80\x9d growled Sikes, with excessive disgust. \xe2\x80\x9cHere! Cut me\r\noff a piece of that pie, one of you boys, to take the taste of that out\r\nof my mouth, or it\xe2\x80\x99ll choke me dead.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t be out of temper, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d urged Fagin, submissively. \xe2\x80\x9cI have\r\nnever forgot you, Bill; never once.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo! Who but poor ould Fagin was the means\r\nof your having such a handy girl about you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe says true enough there!\xe2\x80\x9d said Nancy, coming hastily forward. \xe2\x80\x9cLet\r\nhim be; and that\xe2\x80\x99s flat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, well,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fagin, with a sigh, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll send the Artful round\r\npresently.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou won\xe2\x80\x99t do nothing of the kind,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined Mr. Sikes. \xe2\x80\x9cThe Artful\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\ndeal too artful, and would forget to come, or lose his way, or get\r\ndodged by traps and so be perwented, or anything for an excuse, if you\r\nput him up to it. Nancy shall go to the ken and fetch it, to make all\r\nsure; and I\xe2\x80\x99ll lie down and have a snooze while she\xe2\x80\x99s gone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAfter a great deal of haggling and squabbling, Fagin beat down the\r\namount of the required advance from five pounds to three pounds four\r\nand sixpence: protesting with many solemn asseverations that that would\r\nonly leave him eighteen-pence to keep house with; Mr. Sikes sullenly\r\nremarking that if he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t get any more he must accompany him home;\r\nwith the Dodger and Master Bates put the eatables in the cupboard. The\r\nJew then, taking leave of his affectionate friend, returned homeward,\r\nattended by Nancy and the boys: Mr. Sikes, meanwhile, flinging himself\r\non the bed, and composing himself to sleep away the time until the\r\nyoung lady\xe2\x80\x99s return.\r\n\r\nIn due course, they arrived at Fagin\xe2\x80\x99s abode, where they found Toby\r\nCrackit and Mr. Chitling intent upon their fifteenth game at cribbage,\r\nwhich it is scarcely necessary to say the latter gentleman lost, and\r\nwith it, his fifteenth and last sixpence: much to the amusement of his\r\nyoung friends. Mr. Crackit, apparently somewhat ashamed at being found\r\nrelaxing himself with a gentleman so much his inferior in station and\r\nmental endowments, yawned, and inquiring after Sikes, took up his hat\r\nto go.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas nobody been, Toby?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Fagin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot a living leg,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Mr. Crackit, pulling up his collar; \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbeen as dull as swipes. You ought to stand something handsome, Fagin,\r\nto recompense me for keeping house so long. Damme, I\xe2\x80\x99m as flat as a\r\njuryman; and should have gone to sleep, as fast as Newgate, if I hadn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nhad the good natur\xe2\x80\x99 to amuse this youngster. Horrid dull, I\xe2\x80\x99m blessed\r\nif I an\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith these and other ejaculations of the same kind, Mr. Toby Crackit\r\nswept up his winnings, and crammed them into his waistcoat pocket with\r\na haughty air, as though such small pieces of silver were wholly\r\nbeneath the consideration of a man of his figure; this done, he\r\nswaggered out of the room, with so much elegance and gentility, that\r\nMr. Chitling, bestowing numerous admiring glances on his legs and boots\r\ntill they were out of sight, assured the company that he considered his\r\nacquaintance cheap at fifteen sixpences an interview, and that he\r\ndidn\xe2\x80\x99t value his losses the snap of his little finger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWot a rum chap you are, Tom!\xe2\x80\x9d said Master Bates, highly amused by this\r\ndeclaration.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot a bit of it,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mr. Chitling. \xe2\x80\x9cAm I, Fagin?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA very clever fellow, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fagin, patting him on the\r\nshoulder, and winking to his other pupils.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd Mr. Crackit is a heavy swell; an\xe2\x80\x99t he, Fagin?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Tom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo doubt at all of that, my dear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd it is a creditable thing to have his acquaintance; an\xe2\x80\x99t it,\r\nFagin?\xe2\x80\x9d pursued Tom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery much so, indeed, my dear. They\xe2\x80\x99re only jealous, Tom, because he\r\nwon\xe2\x80\x99t give it to them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Tom, triumphantly, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s where it is! He has cleaned me\r\nout. But I can go and earn some more, when I like; can\xe2\x80\x99t I, Fagin?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be sure you can, and the sooner you go the better, Tom; so make up\r\nyour loss at once, and don\xe2\x80\x99t lose any more time.
