It\xe2\x80\x99s near ten, and nothing done yet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn obedience to this hint, the boys, nodding to Nancy, took up their\r\nhats, and left the room; the Dodger and his vivacious friend indulging,\r\nas they went, in many witticisms at the expense of Mr. Chitling; in\r\nwhose conduct, it is but justice to say, there was nothing very\r\nconspicuous or peculiar: inasmuch as there are a great number of\r\nspirited young bloods upon town, who pay a much higher price than Mr.\r\nChitling for being seen in good society: and a great number of fine\r\ngentlemen (composing the good society aforesaid) who established their\r\nreputation upon very much the same footing as flash Toby Crackit.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fagin, when they had left the room, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll go and get you\r\nthat cash, Nancy. This is only the key of a little cupboard where I\r\nkeep a few odd things the boys get, my dear. I never lock up my money,\r\nfor I\xe2\x80\x99ve got none to lock up, my dear\xe2\x80\x94ha! ha! ha!\xe2\x80\x94none to lock up. It\xe2\x80\x99s\r\na poor trade, Nancy, and no thanks; but I\xe2\x80\x99m fond of seeing the young\r\npeople about me; and I bear it all, I bear it all. Hush!\xe2\x80\x9d he said,\r\nhastily concealing the key in his breast; \xe2\x80\x9cwho\xe2\x80\x99s that? Listen!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe girl, who was sitting at the table with her arms folded, appeared\r\nin no way interested in the arrival: or to care whether the person,\r\nwhoever he was, came or went: until the murmur of a man\xe2\x80\x99s voice reached\r\nher ears. The instant she caught the sound, she tore off her bonnet and\r\nshawl, with the rapidity of lightning, and thrust them under the table.\r\nThe Jew, turning round immediately afterwards, she muttered a complaint\r\nof the heat: in a tone of languor that contrasted, very remarkably,\r\nwith the extreme haste and violence of this action: which, however, had\r\nbeen unobserved by Fagin, who had his back towards her at the time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBah!\xe2\x80\x9d he whispered, as though nettled by the interruption; \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s the\r\nman I expected before; he\xe2\x80\x99s coming downstairs. Not a word about the\r\nmoney while he\xe2\x80\x99s here, Nance. He won\xe2\x80\x99t stop long. Not ten minutes, my\r\ndear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLaying his skinny forefinger upon his lip, the Jew carried a candle to\r\nthe door, as a man\xe2\x80\x99s step was heard upon the stairs without. He reached\r\nit, at the same moment as the visitor, who, coming hastily into the\r\nroom, was close upon the girl before he observed her.\r\n\r\nIt was Monks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly one of my young people,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fagin, observing that Monks drew\r\nback, on beholding a stranger. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t move, Nancy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe girl drew closer to the table, and glancing at Monks with an air of\r\ncareless levity, withdrew her eyes; but as he turned towards Fagin, she\r\nstole another look; so keen and searching, and full of purpose, that if\r\nthere had been any bystander to observe the change, he could hardly\r\nhave believed the two looks to have proceeded from the same person.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAny news?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Fagin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGreat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd\xe2\x80\x94and\xe2\x80\x94good?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Fagin, hesitating as though he feared to vex the\r\nother man by being too sanguine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot bad, any way,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monks with a smile. \xe2\x80\x9cI have been prompt\r\nenough this time. Let me have a word with you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe girl drew closer to the table, and made no offer to leave the room,\r\nalthough she could see that Monks was pointing to her. The Jew: perhaps\r\nfearing she might say something aloud about the money, if he\r\nendeavoured to get rid of her: pointed upward, and took Monks out of\r\nthe room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot that infernal hole we were in before,\xe2\x80\x9d she could hear the man say\r\nas they went upstairs. Fagin laughed; and making some reply which did\r\nnot reach her, seemed, by the creaking of the boards, to lead his\r\ncompanion to the second story.\r\n\r\nBefore the sound of their footsteps had ceased to echo through the\r\nhouse, the girl had slipped off her shoes; and drawing her gown loosely\r\nover her head, and muffling her arms in it, stood at the door,\r\nlistening with breathless interest. The moment the noise ceased, she\r\nglided from the room; ascended the stairs with incredible softness and\r\nsilence; and was lost in the gloom above.\r\n\r\nThe room remained deserted for a quarter of an hour or more; the girl\r\nglided back with the same unearthly tread; and, immediately afterwards,\r\nthe two men were heard descending. Monks went at once into the street;\r\nand the Jew crawled upstairs again for the money. When he returned, the\r\ngirl was adjusting her shawl and bonnet, as if preparing to be gone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, Nance!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the Jew, starting back as he put down the\r\ncandle, \xe2\x80\x9chow pale you are!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPale!\xe2\x80\x9d echoed the girl, shading her eyes with her hands, as if to look\r\nsteadily at him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cQuite horrible. What have you been doing to yourself?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing that I know of, except sitting in this close place for I don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nknow how long and all,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the girl carelessly. \xe2\x80\x9cCome! Let me get\r\nback; that\xe2\x80\x99s a dear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith a sigh for every piece of money, Fagin told the amount into her\r\nhand. They parted without more conversation, merely interchanging a\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cgood-night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen the girl got into the open street, she sat down upon a doorstep;\r\nand seemed, for a few moments, wholly bewildered and unable to pursue\r\nher way. Suddenly she arose; and hurrying on, in a direction quite\r\nopposite to that in which Sikes was awaiting her returned, quickened\r\nher pace, until it gradually resolved into a violent run. After\r\ncompletely exhausting herself, she stopped to take breath: and, as if\r\nsuddenly recollecting herself, and deploring her inability to do\r\nsomething she was bent upon, wrung her hands, and burst into tears.\r\n\r\nIt might be that her tears relieved her, or that she felt the full\r\nhopelessness of her condition; but she turned back; and hurrying with\r\nnearly as great rapidity in the contrary direction; partly to recover\r\nlost time, and partly to keep pace with the violent current of her own\r\nthoughts: soon reached the dwelling where she had left the\r\nhousebreaker.\r\n\r\nIf she betrayed any agitation, when she presented herself to Mr. Sikes,\r\nhe did not observe it; for merely inquiring if she had brought the\r\nmoney, and receiving a reply in the affirmative, he uttered a growl of\r\nsatisfaction, and replacing his head upon the pillow, resumed the\r\nslumbers which her arrival had interrupted.\r\n\r\nIt was fortunate for her that the possession of money occasioned him so\r\nmuch employment next day in the way of eating and drinking; and withal\r\nhad so beneficial an effect in smoothing down the asperities of his\r\ntemper; that he had neither time nor inclination to be very critical\r\nupon her behaviour and deportment. That she had all the abstracted and\r\nnervous manner of one who is on the eve of some bold and hazardous\r\nstep, which it has required no common struggle to resolve upon, would\r\nhave been obvious to the lynx-eyed Fagin, who would most probably have\r\ntaken the alarm at once; but Mr. Sikes lacking the niceties of\r\ndiscrimination, and being troubled with no more subtle misgivings than\r\nthose which resolve themselves into a dogged roughness of behaviour\r\ntowards everybody; and being, furthermore, in an unusually amiable\r\ncondition, as has been already observed; saw nothing unusual in her\r\ndemeanor, and indeed, troubled himself so little about her, that, had\r\nher agitation been far more perceptible than it was, it would have been\r\nvery unlikely to have awakened his suspicions.\r\n\r\nAs that day closed in, the girl\xe2\x80\x99s excitement increased; and, when night\r\ncame on, and she sat by, watching until the housebreaker should drink\r\nhimself asleep, there was an unusual paleness in her cheek, and a fire\r\nin her eye, that even Sikes observed with astonishment.\r\n\r\nMr. Sikes being weak from the fever, was lying in bed, taking hot water\r\nwith his gin to render it less inflammatory; and had pushed his glass\r\ntowards Nancy to be replenished for the third or fourth time, when\r\nthese symptoms first struck him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, burn my body!\xe2\x80\x9d said the man, raising himself on his hands as he\r\nstared the girl in the face. \xe2\x80\x9cYou look like a corpse come to life\r\nagain. What\xe2\x80\x99s the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMatter!\xe2\x80\x9d replied the girl. \xe2\x80\x9cNothing. What do you look at me so hard\r\nfor?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat foolery is this?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded Sikes, grasping her by the arm, and\r\nshaking her roughly. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it? What do you mean? What are you\r\nthinking of?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf many things, Bill,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the girl, shivering, and as she did so,\r\npressing her hands upon her eyes. \xe2\x80\x9cBut, Lord! What odds in that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe tone of forced gaiety in which the last words were spoken, seemed\r\nto produce a deeper impression on Sikes than the wild and rigid look\r\nwhich had preceded them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI tell you wot it is,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sikes; \xe2\x80\x9cif you haven\xe2\x80\x99t caught the fever,\r\nand got it comin\xe2\x80\x99 on, now, there\xe2\x80\x99s something more than usual in the\r\nwind, and something dangerous too. You\xe2\x80\x99re not a-going to\xe2\x80\x94. No, damme!\r\nyou wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t do that!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo what?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the girl.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere ain\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sikes, fixing his eyes upon her, and muttering the\r\nwords to himself; \xe2\x80\x9cthere ain\xe2\x80\x99t a stauncher-hearted gal going, or I\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nhave cut her throat three months ago. She\xe2\x80\x99s got the fever coming on;\r\nthat\xe2\x80\x99s it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFortifying himself with this assurance, Sikes drained the glass to the\r\nbottom, and then, with many grumbling oaths, called for his physic. The\r\ngirl jumped up, with great alacrity; poured it quickly out, but with\r\nher back towards him; and held the vessel to his lips, while he drank\r\noff the contents.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d said the robber, \xe2\x80\x9ccome and sit aside of me, and put on your own\r\nface; or I\xe2\x80\x99ll alter it so, that you won\xe2\x80\x99t know it agin when you do want\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe girl obeyed. Sikes, locking her hand in his, fell back upon the\r\npillow: turning his eyes upon her face. They closed; opened again;\r\nclosed once more; again opened. He shifted his position restlessly;\r\nand, after dozing again, and again, for two or three minutes, and as\r\noften springing up with a look of terror, and gazing vacantly about\r\nhim, was suddenly stricken, as it were, while in the very attitude of\r\nrising, into a deep and heavy sleep. The grasp of his hand relaxed; the\r\nupraised arm fell languidly by his side; and he lay like one in a\r\nprofound trance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe laudanum has taken effect at last,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the girl, as she rose\r\nfrom the bedside. \xe2\x80\x9cI may be too late, even now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe hastily dressed herself in her bonnet and shawl: looking fearfully\r\nround, from time to time, as if, despite the sleeping draught, she\r\nexpected every moment to feel the pressure of Sikes\xe2\x80\x99s heavy hand upon\r\nher shoulder; then, stooping softly over the bed, she kissed the\r\nrobber\xe2\x80\x99s lips; and then opening and closing the room-door with\r\nnoiseless touch, hurried from the house.\r\n\r\nA watchman was crying half-past nine, down a dark passage through which\r\nshe had to pass, in gaining the main thoroughfare.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas it long gone the half-hour?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the girl.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99ll strike the hour in another quarter,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man: raising his\r\nlantern to her face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I cannot get there in less than an hour or more,\xe2\x80\x9d muttered Nancy:\r\nbrushing swiftly past him, and gliding rapidly down the street.\r\n\r\nMany of the shops were already closing in the back lanes and avenues\r\nthrough which she tracked her way, in making from Spitalfields towards\r\nthe West-End of London. The clock struck ten, increasing her\r\nimpatience. She tore along the narrow pavement: elbowing the passengers\r\nfrom side to side; and darting almost under the horses\xe2\x80\x99 heads, crossed\r\ncrowded streets, where clusters of persons were eagerly watching their\r\nopportunity to do the like.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe woman is mad!\xe2\x80\x9d said the people, turning to look after her as she\r\nrushed away.\r\n\r\nWhen she reached the more wealthy quarter of the town, the streets were\r\ncomparatively deserted; and here her headlong progress excited a still\r\ngreater curiosity in the stragglers whom she hurried past. Some\r\nquickened their pace behind, as though to see whither she was hastening\r\nat such an unusual rate; and a few made head upon her, and looked back,\r\nsurprised at her undiminished speed; but they fell off one by one; and\r\nwhen she neared her place of destination, she was alone.\r\n\r\nIt was a family hotel in a quiet but handsome street near Hyde Park. As\r\nthe brilliant light of the lamp which burnt before its door, guided her\r\nto the spot, the clock struck eleven. She had loitered for a few paces\r\nas though irresolute, and making up her mind to advance; but the sound\r\ndetermined her, and she stepped into the hall. The porter\xe2\x80\x99s seat was\r\nvacant. She looked round with an air of incertitude, and advanced\r\ntowards the stairs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, young woman!\xe2\x80\x9d said a smartly-dressed female, looking out from a\r\ndoor behind her, \xe2\x80\x9cwho do you want here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA lady who is stopping in this house,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the girl.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA lady!\xe2\x80\x9d was the reply, accompanied with a scornful look. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat lady?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Maylie,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nancy.\r\n\r\nThe young woman, who had by this time, noted her appearance, replied\r\nonly by a look of virtuous disdain; and summoned a man to answer her.\r\nTo him, Nancy repeated her request.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat name am I to say?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the waiter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s of no use saying any,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Nancy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNor business?\xe2\x80\x9d said the man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, nor that neither,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined the girl. \xe2\x80\x9cI must see the lady.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome!\xe2\x80\x9d said the man, pushing her towards the door. \xe2\x80\x9cNone of this. Take\r\nyourself off.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall be carried out if I go!\xe2\x80\x9d said the girl violently; \xe2\x80\x9cand I can\r\nmake that a job that two of you won\xe2\x80\x99t like to do. Isn\xe2\x80\x99t there anybody\r\nhere,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, looking round, \xe2\x80\x9cthat will see a simple message carried\r\nfor a poor wretch like me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis appeal produced an effect on a good-tempered-faced man-cook, who\r\nwith some of the other servants was looking on, and who stepped forward\r\nto interfere.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake it up for her, Joe; can\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d said this person.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the good?\xe2\x80\x9d replied the man. \xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t suppose the young lady\r\nwill see such as her; do you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis allusion to Nancy\xe2\x80\x99s doubtful character, raised a vast quantity of\r\nchaste wrath in the bosoms of four housemaids, who remarked, with great\r\nfervour, that the creature was a disgrace to her sex; and strongly\r\nadvocated her being thrown, ruthlessly, into the kennel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo what you like with me,\xe2\x80\x9d said the girl, turning to the men again;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cbut do what I ask you first, and I ask you to give this message for\r\nGod Almighty\xe2\x80\x99s sake.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe soft-hearted cook added his intercession, and the result was that\r\nthe man who had first appeared undertook its delivery.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s it to be?\xe2\x80\x9d said the man, with one foot on the stairs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat a young woman earnestly asks to speak to Miss Maylie alone,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nNancy; \xe2\x80\x9cand that if the lady will only hear the first word she has to\r\nsay, she will know whether to hear her business, or to have her turned\r\nout of doors as an impostor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99re coming it strong!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou give the message,\xe2\x80\x9d said the girl firmly; \xe2\x80\x9cand let me hear the\r\nanswer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe man ran upstairs. Nancy remained, pale and almost breathless,\r\nlistening with quivering lip to the very audible expressions of scorn,\r\nof which the chaste housemaids were very prolific; and of which they\r\nbecame still more so, when the man returned, and said the young woman\r\nwas to walk upstairs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s no good being proper in this world,\xe2\x80\x9d said the first housemaid.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBrass can do better than the gold what has stood the fire,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nsecond.\r\n\r\nThe third contented herself with wondering \xe2\x80\x9cwhat ladies was made of\xe2\x80\x9d;\r\nand the fourth took the first in a quartette of \xe2\x80\x9cShameful!\xe2\x80\x9d with which\r\nthe Dianas concluded.\r\n\r\nRegardless of all this: for she had weightier matters at heart: Nancy\r\nfollowed the man, with trembling limbs, to a small ante-chamber,\r\nlighted by a lamp from the ceiling. Here he left her, and retired.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n CHAPTER XL.\r\nA STRANGE INTERVIEW, WHICH IS A SEQUEL TO THE LAST CHAMBER\r\n\r\n\r\nThe girl\xe2\x80\x99s life had been squandered in the streets, and among the most\r\nnoisome of the stews and dens of London, but there was something of the\r\nwoman\xe2\x80\x99s original nature left in her still; and when she heard a light\r\nstep approaching the door opposite to that by which she had entered,\r\nand thought of the wide contrast which the small room would in another\r\nmoment contain, she felt burdened with the sense of her own deep shame,\r\nand shrunk as though she could scarcely bear the presence of her with\r\nwhom she had sought this interview.\r\n\r\nBut struggling with these better feelings was pride,\xe2\x80\x94the vice of the\r\nlowest and most debased creatures no less than of the high and\r\nself-assured. The miserable companion of thieves and ruffians, the\r\nfallen outcast of low haunts, the associate of the scourings of the\r\njails and hulks, living within the shadow of the gallows itself,\xe2\x80\x94even\r\nthis degraded being felt too proud to betray a feeble gleam of the\r\nwomanly feeling which she thought a weakness, but which alone connected\r\nher with that humanity, of which her wasting life had obliterated so\r\nmany, many traces when a very child.\r\n\r\nShe raised her eyes sufficiently to observe that the figure which\r\npresented itself was that of a slight and beautiful girl; then, bending\r\nthem on the ground, she tossed her head with affected carelessness as\r\nshe said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a hard matter to get to see you, lady. If I had taken offence,\r\nand gone away, as many would have done, you\xe2\x80\x99d have been sorry for it\r\none day, and not without reason either.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am very sorry if any one has behaved harshly to you,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Rose.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not think of that. Tell me why you wished to see me. I am the\r\nperson you inquired for.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe kind tone of this answer, the sweet voice, the gentle manner, the\r\nabsence of any accent of haughtiness or displeasure, took the girl\r\ncompletely by surprise, and she burst into tears.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, lady, lady!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, clasping her hands passionately before her\r\nface, \xe2\x80\x9cif there was more like you, there would be fewer like me,\xe2\x80\x94there\r\nwould\xe2\x80\x94there would!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSit down,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rose, earnestly. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you are in poverty or affliction\r\nI shall be truly glad to relieve you if I can,\xe2\x80\x94I shall indeed. Sit\r\ndown.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me stand, lady,\xe2\x80\x9d said the girl, still weeping, \xe2\x80\x9cand do not speak\r\nto me so kindly till you know me better. It is growing late. Is\xe2\x80\x94is\xe2\x80\x94that\r\ndoor shut?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rose, recoiling a few steps, as if to be nearer assistance\r\nin case she should require it. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause,\xe2\x80\x9d said the girl, \xe2\x80\x9cI am about to put my life and the lives of\r\nothers in your hands. I am the girl that dragged little Oliver back to\r\nold Fagin\xe2\x80\x99s on the night he went out from the house in Pentonville.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou!\xe2\x80\x9d said Rose Maylie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI, lady!\xe2\x80\x9d replied the girl. \xe2\x80\x9cI am the infamous creature you have heard\r\nof, that lives among the thieves, and that never from the first moment\r\nI can recollect my eyes and senses opening on London streets have known\r\nany better life, or kinder words than they have given me, so help me\r\nGod! Do not mind shrinking openly from me, lady. I am younger than you\r\nwould think, to look at me, but I am well used to it. The poorest women\r\nfall back, as I make my way along the crowded pavement.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat dreadful things are these!\xe2\x80\x9d said Rose, involuntarily falling from\r\nher strange companion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank Heaven upon your knees, dear lady,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the girl, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you\r\nhad friends to care for and keep you in your childhood, and that you\r\nwere never in the midst of cold and hunger, and riot and drunkenness,\r\nand\xe2\x80\x94and\xe2\x80\x94something worse than all\xe2\x80\x94as I have been from my cradle. I may\r\nuse the word, for the alley and the gutter were mine, as they will be\r\nmy deathbed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI pity you!\xe2\x80\x9d said Rose, in a broken voice. \xe2\x80\x9cIt wrings my heart to hear\r\nyou!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHeaven bless you for your goodness!\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined the girl. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you knew\r\nwhat I am sometimes, you would pity me, indeed. But I have stolen away\r\nfrom those who would surely murder me, if they knew I had been here, to\r\ntell you what I have overheard. Do you know a man named Monks?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe knows you,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the girl; \xe2\x80\x9cand knew you were here, for it was\r\nby hearing him tell the place that I found you out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never heard the name,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen he goes by some other amongst us,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined the girl, \xe2\x80\x9cwhich I\r\nmore than thought before. Some time ago, and soon after Oliver was put\r\ninto your house on the night of the robbery, I\xe2\x80\x94suspecting this\r\nman\xe2\x80\x94listened to a conversation held between him and Fagin in the dark.\r\nI found out, from what I heard, that Monks\xe2\x80\x94the man I asked you about,\r\nyou know\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rose, \xe2\x80\x9cI understand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x94That Monks,\xe2\x80\x9d pursued the girl, \xe2\x80\x9chad seen him accidently with two of\r\nour boys on the day we first lost him, and had known him directly to be\r\nthe same child that he was watching for, though I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t make out\r\nwhy. A bargain was struck with Fagin, that if Oliver was got back he\r\nshould have a certain sum; and he was to have more for making him a\r\nthief, which this Monks wanted for some purpose of his own.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor what purpose?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Rose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe caught sight of my shadow on the wall as I listened, in the hope of\r\nfinding out,\xe2\x80\x9d said the girl; \xe2\x80\x9cand there are not many people besides me\r\nthat could have got out of their way in time to escape discovery. But I\r\ndid; and I saw him no more till last night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what occurred then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you, lady. Last night he came again. Again they went\r\nupstairs, and I, wrapping myself up so that my shadow would not betray\r\nme, again listened at the door. The first words I heard Monks say were\r\nthese: \xe2\x80\x98So the only proofs of the boy\xe2\x80\x99s identity lie at the bottom of\r\nthe river, and the old hag that received them from the mother is\r\nrotting in her coffin.\xe2\x80\x99 They laughed, and talked of his success in\r\ndoing this; and Monks, talking on about the boy, and getting very wild,\r\nsaid that though he had got the young devil\xe2\x80\x99s money safely now, he\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nrather have had it the other way; for, what a game it would have been\r\nto have brought down the boast of the father\xe2\x80\x99s will, by driving him\r\nthrough every jail in town, and then hauling him up for some capital\r\nfelony which Fagin could easily manage, after having made a good profit\r\nof him besides.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is all this!\xe2\x80\x9d said Rose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe truth, lady, though it comes from my lips,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the girl.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, he said, with oaths common enough in my ears, but strange to\r\nyours, that if he could gratify his hatred by taking the boy\xe2\x80\x99s life\r\nwithout bringing his own neck in danger, he would; but, as he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t,\r\nhe\xe2\x80\x99d be upon the watch to meet him at every turn in life; and if he\r\ntook advantage of his birth and history, he might harm him yet. \xe2\x80\x98In\r\nshort, Fagin,\xe2\x80\x99 he says, \xe2\x80\x98Jew as you are, you never laid such snares as\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll contrive for my young brother, Oliver.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis brother!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Rose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThose were his words,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nancy, glancing uneasily round, as she had\r\nscarcely ceased to do, since she began to speak, for a vision of Sikes\r\nhaunted her perpetually. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd more. When he spoke of you and the other\r\nlady, and said it seemed contrived by Heaven, or the devil, against\r\nhim, that Oliver should come into your hands, he laughed, and said\r\nthere was some comfort in that too, for how many thousands and hundreds\r\nof thousands of pounds would you not give, if you had them, to know who\r\nyour two-legged spaniel was.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou do not mean,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rose, turning very pale, \xe2\x80\x9cto tell me that this\r\nwas said in earnest?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe spoke in hard and angry earnest, if a man ever did,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the\r\ngirl, shaking her head. \xe2\x80\x9cHe is an earnest man when his hatred is up. I\r\nknow many who do worse things; but I\xe2\x80\x99d rather listen to them all a\r\ndozen times, than to that Monks once. It is growing late, and I have to\r\nreach home without suspicion of having been on such an errand as this.\r\nI must get back quickly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what can I do?\xe2\x80\x9d said Rose. \xe2\x80\x9cTo what use can I turn this\r\ncommunication without you? Back! Why do you wish to return to\r\ncompanions you paint in such terrible colors? If you repeat this\r\ninformation to a gentleman whom I can summon in an instant from the\r\nnext room, you can be consigned to some place of safety without half an\r\nhour\xe2\x80\x99s delay.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish to go back,\xe2\x80\x9d said the girl. \xe2\x80\x9cI must go back, because\xe2\x80\x94how can I\r\ntell such things to an innocent lady like you?\xe2\x80\x94because among the men I\r\nhave told you of, there is one: the most desperate among them all; that\r\nI can\xe2\x80\x99t leave: no, not even to be saved from the life I am leading\r\nnow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour having interfered in this dear boy\xe2\x80\x99s behalf before,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rose;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cyour coming here, at so great a risk, to tell me what you have heard;\r\nyour manner, which convinces me of the truth of what you say; your\r\nevident contrition, and sense of shame; all lead me to believe that you\r\nmight yet be reclaimed. Oh!\xe2\x80\x9d said the earnest girl, folding her hands\r\nas the tears coursed down her face, \xe2\x80\x9cdo not turn a deaf ear to the\r\nentreaties of one of your own sex; the first\xe2\x80\x94the first, I do believe,\r\nwho ever appealed to you in the voice of pity and compassion. Do hear\r\nmy words, and let me save you yet, for better things.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLady,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the girl, sinking on her knees, \xe2\x80\x9cdear, sweet, angel lady,\r\nyou _are_ the first that ever blessed me with such words as these, and\r\nif I had heard them years ago, they might have turned me from a life of\r\nsin and sorrow; but it is too late, it is too late!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is never too late,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rose, \xe2\x80\x9cfor penitence and atonement.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the girl, writhing in agony of her mind; \xe2\x80\x9cI cannot leave\r\nhim now! I could not be his death.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy should you be?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Rose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing could save him,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the girl. \xe2\x80\x9cIf I told others what I have\r\ntold you, and led to their being taken, he would be sure to die. He is\r\nthe boldest, and has been so cruel!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it possible,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Rose, \xe2\x80\x9cthat for such a man as this, you can\r\nresign every future hope, and the certainty of immediate rescue? It is\r\nmadness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know what it is,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the girl; \xe2\x80\x9cI only know that it is\r\nso, and not with me alone, but with hundreds of others as bad and\r\nwretched as myself. I must go back. Whether it is God\xe2\x80\x99s wrath for the\r\nwrong I have done, I do not know; but I am drawn back to him through\r\nevery suffering and ill usage; and I should be, I believe, if I knew\r\nthat I was to die by his hand at last.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat am I to do?\xe2\x80\x9d said Rose. \xe2\x80\x9cI should not let you depart from me\r\nthus.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou should, lady, and I know you will,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined the girl, rising.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will not stop my going because I have trusted in your goodness,\r\nand forced no promise from you, as I might have done.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf what use, then, is the communication you have made?\xe2\x80\x9d said Rose.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis mystery must be investigated, or how will its disclosure to me,\r\nbenefit Oliver, whom you are anxious to serve?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must have some kind gentleman about you that will hear it as a\r\nsecret, and advise you what to do,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined the girl.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut where can I find you again when it is necessary?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Rose. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\ndo not seek to know where these dreadful people live, but where will\r\nyou be walking or passing at any settled period from this time?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill you promise me that you will have my secret strictly kept, and\r\ncome alone, or with the only other person that knows it; and that I\r\nshall not be watched or followed?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the girl.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI promise you solemnly,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Rose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEvery Sunday night, from eleven until the clock strikes twelve,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nthe girl without hesitation, \xe2\x80\x9cI will walk on London Bridge if I am\r\nalive.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStay another moment,\xe2\x80\x9d interposed Rose, as the girl moved hurriedly\r\ntowards the door. \xe2\x80\x9cThink once again on your own condition, and the\r\nopportunity you have of escaping from it. You have a claim on me: not\r\nonly as the voluntary bearer of this intelligence, but as a woman lost\r\nalmost beyond redemption. Will you return to this gang of robbers, and\r\nto this man, when a word can save you? What fascination is it that can\r\ntake you back, and make you cling to wickedness and misery? Oh! is\r\nthere no chord in your heart that I can touch! Is there nothing left,\r\nto which I can appeal against this terrible infatuation!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen ladies as young, and good, and beautiful as you are,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the\r\ngirl steadily, \xe2\x80\x9cgive away your hearts, love will carry you all\r\nlengths\xe2\x80\x94even such as you, who have home, friends, other admirers,\r\neverything, to fill them. When such as I, who have no certain roof but\r\nthe coffinlid, and no friend in sickness or death but the hospital\r\nnurse, set our rotten hearts on any man, and let him fill the place\r\nthat has been a blank through all our wretched lives, who can hope to\r\ncure us? Pity us, lady\xe2\x80\x94pity us for having only one feeling of the woman\r\nleft, and for having that turned, by a heavy judgment, from a comfort\r\nand a pride, into a new means of violence and suffering.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rose, after a pause, \xe2\x80\x9ctake some money from me, which\r\nmay enable you to live without dishonesty\xe2\x80\x94at all events until we meet\r\nagain?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot a penny,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the girl, waving her hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not close your heart against all my efforts to help you,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nRose, stepping gently forward. \xe2\x80\x9cI wish to serve you indeed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou would serve me best, lady,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the girl, wringing her hands,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cif you could take my life at once; for I have felt more grief to think\r\nof what I am, to-night, than I ever did before, and it would be\r\nsomething not to die in the hell in which I have lived. God bless you,\r\nsweet lady, and send as much happiness on your head as I have brought\r\nshame on mine!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThus speaking, and sobbing aloud, the unhappy creature turned away;\r\nwhile Rose Maylie, overpowered by this extraordinary interview, which\r\nhad more the semblance of a rapid dream than an actual occurrence, sank\r\ninto a chair, and endeavoured to collect her wandering thoughts.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n CHAPTER XLI.\r\nCONTAINING FRESH DISCOVERIES, AND SHOWING THAT SUPRISES, LIKE\r\nMISFORTUNES, SELDOM COME ALONE\r\n\r\n\r\nHer situation was, indeed, one of no common trial and difficulty. While\r\nshe felt the most eager and burning desire to penetrate the mystery in\r\nwhich Oliver\xe2\x80\x99s history was enveloped, she could not but hold sacred the\r\nconfidence which the miserable woman with whom she had just conversed,\r\nhad reposed in her, as a young and guileless girl. Her words and manner\r\nhad touched Rose Maylie\xe2\x80\x99s heart; and, mingled with her love for her\r\nyoung charge, and scarcely less intense in its truth and fervour, was\r\nher fond wish to win the outcast back to repentance and hope.\r\n\r\nThey purposed remaining in London only three days, prior to departing\r\nfor some weeks to a distant part of the coast. It was now midnight of\r\nthe first day. What course of action could she determine upon, which\r\ncould be adopted in eight-and-forty hours? Or how could she postpone\r\nthe journey without exciting suspicion?\r\n\r\nMr. Losberne was with them, and would be for the next two days; but\r\nRose was too well acquainted with the excellent gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nimpetuosity, and foresaw too clearly the wrath with which, in the first\r\nexplosion of his indignation, he would regard the instrument of\r\nOliver\xe2\x80\x99s recapture, to trust him with the secret, when her\r\nrepresentations in the girl\xe2\x80\x99s behalf could be seconded by no\r\nexperienced person. These were all reasons for the greatest caution and\r\nmost circumspect behaviour in communicating it to Mrs. Maylie, whose\r\nfirst impulse would infallibly be to hold a conference with the worthy\r\ndoctor on the subject. As to resorting to any legal adviser, even if\r\nshe had known how to do so, it was scarcely to be thought of, for the\r\nsame reason. Once the thought occurred to her of seeking assistance\r\nfrom Harry; but this awakened the recollection of their last parting,\r\nand it seemed unworthy of her to call him back, when\xe2\x80\x94the tears rose to\r\nher eyes as she pursued this train of reflection\xe2\x80\x94he might have by this\r\ntime learnt to forget her, and to be happier away.\r\n\r\nDisturbed by these different reflections; inclining now to one course\r\nand then to another, and again recoiling from all, as each successive\r\nconsideration presented itself to her mind; Rose passed a sleepless and\r\nanxious night. After more communing with herself next day, she arrived\r\nat the desperate conclusion of consulting Harry.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf it be painful to him,\xe2\x80\x9d she thought, \xe2\x80\x9cto come back here, how painful\r\nit will be to me! But perhaps he will not come; he may write, or he may\r\ncome himself, and studiously abstain from meeting me\xe2\x80\x94he did when he\r\nwent away. I hardly thought he would; but it was better for us both.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nAnd here Rose dropped the pen, and turned away, as though the very\r\npaper which was to be her messenger should not see her weep.\r\n\r\nShe had taken up the same pen, and laid it down again fifty times, and\r\nhad considered and reconsidered the first line of her letter without\r\nwriting the first word, when Oliver, who had been walking in the\r\nstreets, with Mr. Giles for a body-guard, entered the room in such\r\nbreathless haste and violent agitation, as seemed to betoken some new\r\ncause of alarm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat makes you look so flurried?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Rose, advancing to meet him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hardly know how; I feel as if I should be choked,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the boy.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh dear! To think that I should see him at last, and you should be\r\nable to know that I have told you the truth!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never thought you had told us anything but the truth,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rose,\r\nsoothing him. \xe2\x80\x9cBut what is this?\xe2\x80\x94of whom do you speak?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have seen the gentleman,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Oliver, scarcely able to\r\narticulate, \xe2\x80\x9cthe gentleman who was so good to me\xe2\x80\x94Mr. Brownlow, that we\r\nhave so often talked about.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Rose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGetting out of a coach,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Oliver, shedding tears of delight,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cand going into a house. I didn\xe2\x80\x99t speak to him\xe2\x80\x94I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t speak to him,\r\nfor he didn\xe2\x80\x99t see me, and I trembled so, that I was not able to go up\r\nto him. But Giles asked, for me, whether he lived there, and they said\r\nhe did. Look here,\xe2\x80\x9d said Oliver, opening a scrap of paper, \xe2\x80\x9chere it is;\r\nhere\xe2\x80\x99s where he lives\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99m going there directly! Oh, dear me, dear me!\r\nWhat shall I do when I come to see him and hear him speak again!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith her attention not a little distracted by these and a great many\r\nother incoherent exclamations of joy, Rose read the address, which was\r\nCraven Street, in the Strand. She very soon determined upon turning the\r\ndiscovery to account.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cQuick!\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cTell them to fetch a hackney-coach, and be ready to\r\ngo with me. I will take you there directly, without a minute\xe2\x80\x99s loss of\r\ntime. I will only tell my aunt that we are going out for an hour, and\r\nbe ready as soon as you are.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOliver needed no prompting to despatch, and in little more than five\r\nminutes they were on their way to Craven Street. When they arrived\r\nthere, Rose left Oliver in the coach, under pretence of preparing the\r\nold gentleman to receive him; and sending up her card by the servant,\r\nrequested to see Mr. Brownlow on very pressing business. The servant\r\nsoon returned, to beg that she would walk upstairs; and following him\r\ninto an upper room, Miss Maylie was presented to an elderly gentleman\r\nof benevolent appearance, in a bottle-green coat. At no great distance\r\nfrom whom, was seated another old gentleman, in nankeen breeches and\r\ngaiters; who did not look particularly benevolent, and who was sitting\r\nwith his hands clasped on the top of a thick stick, and his chin\r\npropped thereupon.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear me,\xe2\x80\x9d said the gentleman, in the bottle-green coat, hastily rising\r\nwith great politeness, \xe2\x80\x9cI beg your pardon, young lady\xe2\x80\x94I imagined it was\r\nsome importunate person who\xe2\x80\x94I beg you will excuse me. Be seated, pray.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Brownlow, I believe, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d said Rose, glancing from the other\r\ngentleman to the one who had spoken.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is my name,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old gentleman. \xe2\x80\x9cThis is my friend, Mr.\r\nGrimwig. Grimwig, will you leave us for a few minutes?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe,\xe2\x80\x9d interposed Miss Maylie, \xe2\x80\x9cthat at this period of our\r\ninterview, I need not give that gentleman the trouble of going away. If\r\nI am correctly informed, he is cognizant of the business on which I\r\nwish to speak to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Brownlow inclined his head. Mr. Grimwig, who had made one very\r\nstiff bow, and risen from his chair, made another very stiff bow, and\r\ndropped into it again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall surprise you very much, I have no doubt,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rose, naturally\r\nembarrassed; \xe2\x80\x9cbut you once showed great benevolence and goodness to a\r\nvery dear young friend of mine, and I am sure you will take an interest\r\nin hearing of him again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Brownlow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOliver Twist you knew him as,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Rose.\r\n\r\nThe words no sooner escaped her lips, than Mr. Grimwig, who had been\r\naffecting to dip into a large book that lay on the table, upset it with\r\na great crash, and falling back in his chair, discharged from his\r\nfeatures every expression but one of unmitigated wonder, and indulged\r\nin a prolonged and vacant stare; then, as if ashamed of having betrayed\r\nso much emotion, he jerked himself, as it were, by a convulsion into\r\nhis former attitude, and looking out straight before him emitted a long\r\ndeep whistle, which seemed, at last, not to be discharged on empty air,\r\nbut to die away in the innermost recesses of his stomach.\r\n\r\nMr. Browlow was no less surprised, although his astonishment was not\r\nexpressed in the same eccentric manner. He drew his chair nearer to\r\nMiss Maylie\xe2\x80\x99s, and said,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo me the favour, my dear young lady, to leave entirely out of the\r\nquestion that goodness and benevolence of which you speak, and of which\r\nnobody else knows anything; and if you have it in your power to produce\r\nany evidence which will alter the unfavourable opinion I was once\r\ninduced to entertain of that poor child, in Heaven\xe2\x80\x99s name put me in\r\npossession of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA bad one! I\xe2\x80\x99ll eat my head if he is not a bad one,\xe2\x80\x9d growled Mr.\r\nGrimwig, speaking by some ventriloquial power, without moving a muscle\r\nof his face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is a child of a noble nature and a warm heart,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rose,\r\ncolouring; \xe2\x80\x9cand that Power which has thought fit to try him beyond his\r\nyears, has planted in his breast affections and feelings which would do\r\nhonour to many who have numbered his days six times over.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m only sixty-one,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Grimwig, with the same rigid face. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd,\r\nas the devil\xe2\x80\x99s in it if this Oliver is not twelve years old at least, I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t see the application of that remark.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not heed my friend, Miss Maylie,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Brownlow; \xe2\x80\x9che does not\r\nmean what he says.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, he does,\xe2\x80\x9d growled Mr. Grimwig.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, he does not,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Brownlow, obviously rising in wrath as he\r\nspoke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99ll eat his head, if he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d growled Mr. Grimwig.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe would deserve to have it knocked off, if he does,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr.\r\nBrownlow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd he\xe2\x80\x99d uncommonly like to see any man offer to do it,\xe2\x80\x9d responded Mr.\r\nGrimwig, knocking his stick upon the floor.\r\n\r\nHaving gone thus far, the two old gentlemen severally took snuff, and\r\nafterwards shook hands, according to their invariable custom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, Miss Maylie,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Brownlow, \xe2\x80\x9cto return to the subject in\r\nwhich your humanity is so much interested. Will you let me know what\r\nintelligence you have of this poor child: allowing me to promise that I\r\nexhausted every means in my power of discovering him, and that since I\r\nhave been absent from this country, my first impression that he had\r\nimposed upon me, and had been persuaded by his former associates to rob\r\nme, has been considerably shaken.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nRose, who had had time to collect her thoughts, at once related, in a\r\nfew natural words, all that had befallen Oliver since he left Mr.\r\nBrownlow\xe2\x80\x99s house; reserving Nancy\xe2\x80\x99s information for that gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nprivate ear, and concluding with the assurance that his only sorrow,\r\nfor some months past, had been not being able to meet with his former\r\nbenefactor and friend.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank God!\xe2\x80\x9d said the old gentleman. \xe2\x80\x9cThis is great happiness to me,\r\ngreat happiness. But you have not told me where he is now, Miss Maylie.\r\nYou must pardon my finding fault with you,\xe2\x80\x94but why not have brought\r\nhim?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is waiting in a coach at the door,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Rose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt this door!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the old gentleman. With which he hurried out of\r\nthe room, down the stairs, up the coachsteps, and into the coach,\r\nwithout another word.\r\n\r\nWhen the room-door closed behind him, Mr. Grimwig lifted up his head,\r\nand converting one of the hind legs of his chair into a pivot,\r\ndescribed three distinct circles with the assistance of his stick and\r\nthe table; sitting in it all the time. After performing this evolution,\r\nhe rose and limped as fast as he could up and down the room at least a\r\ndozen times, and then stopping suddenly before Rose, kissed her without\r\nthe slightest preface.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHush!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, as the young lady rose in some alarm at this unusual\r\nproceeding. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t be afraid. I\xe2\x80\x99m old enough to be your grandfather.\r\nYou\xe2\x80\x99re a sweet girl. I like you. Here they are!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn fact, as he threw himself at one dexterous dive into his former\r\nseat, Mr. Brownlow returned, accompanied by Oliver, whom Mr. Grimwig\r\nreceived very graciously; and if the gratification of that moment had\r\nbeen the only reward for all her anxiety and care in Oliver\xe2\x80\x99s behalf,\r\nRose Maylie would have been well repaid.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is somebody else who should not be forgotten, by the bye,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nMr. Brownlow, ringing the bell. \xe2\x80\x9cSend Mrs. Bedwin here, if you please.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe old housekeeper answered the summons with all dispatch; and\r\ndropping a curtsey at the door, waited for orders.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, you get blinder every day, Bedwin,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Brownlow, rather\r\ntestily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, that I do, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the old lady. \xe2\x80\x9cPeople\xe2\x80\x99s eyes, at my\r\ntime of life, don\xe2\x80\x99t improve with age, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI could have told you that,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined Mr. Brownlow; \xe2\x80\x9cbut put on your\r\nglasses, and see if you can\xe2\x80\x99t find out what you were wanted for, will\r\nyou?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe old lady began to rummage in her pocket for her spectacles. But\r\nOliver\xe2\x80\x99s patience was not proof against this new trial; and yielding to\r\nhis first impulse, he sprang into her arms.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod be good to me!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the old lady, embracing him; \xe2\x80\x9cit is my\r\ninnocent boy!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear old nurse!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Oliver.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe would come back\xe2\x80\x94I knew he would,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old lady, holding him in\r\nher arms. \xe2\x80\x9cHow well he looks, and how like a gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s son he is\r\ndressed again! Where have you been, this long, long while? Ah! the same\r\nsweet face, but not so pale; the same soft eye, but not so sad. I have\r\nnever forgotten them or his quiet smile, but have seen them every day,\r\nside by side with those of my own dear children, dead and gone since I\r\nwas a lightsome young creature.\xe2\x80\x9d Running on thus, and now holding\r\nOliver from her to mark how he had grown, now clasping him to her and\r\npassing her fingers fondly through his hair, the good soul laughed and\r\nwept upon his neck by turns.\r\n\r\nLeaving her and Oliver to compare notes at leisure, Mr. Brownlow led\r\nthe way into another room; and there, heard from Rose a full narration\r\nof her interview with Nancy, which occasioned him no little surprise\r\nand perplexity. Rose also explained her reasons for not confiding in\r\nher friend Mr. Losberne in the first instance. The old gentleman\r\nconsidered that she had acted prudently, and readily undertook to hold\r\nsolemn conference with the worthy doctor himself. To afford him an\r\nearly opportunity for the execution of this design, it was arranged\r\nthat he should call at the hotel at eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock that evening, and\r\nthat in the meantime Mrs. Maylie should be cautiously informed of all\r\nthat had occurred. These preliminaries adjusted, Rose and Oliver\r\nreturned home.\r\n\r\nRose had by no means overrated the measure of the good doctor\xe2\x80\x99s wrath.\r\nNancy\xe2\x80\x99s history was no sooner unfolded to him, than he poured forth a\r\nshower of mingled threats and execrations; threatened to make her the\r\nfirst victim of the combined ingenuity of Messrs. Blathers and Duff;\r\nand actually put on his hat preparatory to sallying forth to obtain the\r\nassistance of those worthies. And, doubtless, he would, in this first\r\noutbreak, have carried the intention into effect without a moment\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nconsideration of the consequences, if he had not been restrained, in\r\npart, by corresponding violence on the side of Mr. Brownlow, who was\r\nhimself of an irascible temperament, and party by such arguments and\r\nrepresentations as seemed best calculated to dissuade him from his\r\nhotbrained purpose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen what the devil is to be done?\xe2\x80\x9d said the impetuous doctor, when\r\nthey had rejoined the two ladies. \xe2\x80\x9cAre we to pass a vote of thanks to\r\nall these vagabonds, male and female, and beg them to accept a hundred\r\npounds, or so, apiece, as a trifling mark of our esteem, and some\r\nslight acknowledgment of their kindness to Oliver?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot exactly that,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined Mr. Brownlow, laughing; \xe2\x80\x9cbut we must\r\nproceed gently and with great care.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentleness and care,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the doctor. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d send them one and all\r\nto\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind where,\xe2\x80\x9d interposed Mr. Brownlow. \xe2\x80\x9cBut reflect whether\r\nsending them anywhere is likely to attain the object we have in view.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat object?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the doctor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSimply, the discovery of Oliver\xe2\x80\x99s parentage, and regaining for him the\r\ninheritance of which, if this story be true, he has been fraudulently\r\ndeprived.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Losberne, cooling himself with his pocket-handkerchief;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI almost forgot that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see,\xe2\x80\x9d pursued Mr. Brownlow; \xe2\x80\x9cplacing this poor girl entirely out\r\nof the question, and supposing it were possible to bring these\r\nscoundrels to justice without compromising her safety, what good should\r\nwe bring about?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHanging a few of them at least, in all probability,\xe2\x80\x9d suggested the\r\ndoctor, \xe2\x80\x9cand transporting the rest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery good,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mr. Brownlow, smiling; \xe2\x80\x9cbut no doubt they will\r\nbring that about for themselves in the fulness of time, and if we step\r\nin to forestall them, it seems to me that we shall be performing a very\r\nQuixotic act, in direct opposition to our own interest\xe2\x80\x94or at least to\r\nOliver\xe2\x80\x99s, which is the same thing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the doctor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThus. It is quite clear that we shall have extreme difficulty in\r\ngetting to the bottom of this mystery, unless we can bring this man,\r\nMonks, upon his knees. That can only be done by stratagem, and by\r\ncatching him when he is not surrounded by these people. For, suppose he\r\nwere apprehended, we have no proof against him. He is not even (so far\r\nas we know, or as the facts appear to us) concerned with the gang in\r\nany of their robberies. If he were not discharged, it is very unlikely\r\nthat he could receive any further punishment than being committed to\r\nprison as a rogue and vagabond; and of course ever afterwards his mouth\r\nwould be so obstinately closed that he might as well, for our purposes,\r\nbe deaf, dumb, blind, and an idiot.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d said the doctor impetuously, \xe2\x80\x9cI put it to you again, whether\r\nyou think it reasonable that this promise to the girl should be\r\nconsidered binding; a promise made with the best and kindest\r\nintentions, but really\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not discuss the point, my dear young lady, pray,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr.\r\nBrownlow, interrupting Rose as she was about to speak. \xe2\x80\x9cThe promise\r\nshall be kept. I don\xe2\x80\x99t think it will, in the slightest degree,\r\ninterfere with our proceedings. But, before we can resolve upon any\r\nprecise course of action, it will be necessary to see the girl; to\r\nascertain from her whether she will point out this Monks, on the\r\nunderstanding that he is to be dealt with by us, and not by the law;\r\nor, if she will not, or cannot do that, to procure from her such an\r\naccount of his haunts and description of his person, as will enable us\r\nto identify him. She cannot be seen until next Sunday night; this is\r\nTuesday. I would suggest that in the meantime, we remain perfectly\r\nquiet, and keep these matters secret even from Oliver himself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlthough Mr. Losberne received with many wry faces a proposal involving\r\na delay of five whole days, he was fain to admit that no better course\r\noccurred to him just then; and as both Rose and Mrs. Maylie sided very\r\nstrongly with Mr. Brownlow, that gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s proposition was carried\r\nunanimously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should like,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cto call in the aid of my friend Grimwig. He\r\nis a strange creature, but a shrewd one, and might prove of material\r\nassistance to us; I should say that he was bred a lawyer, and quitted\r\nthe Bar in disgust because he had only one brief and a motion of\r\ncourse, in twenty years, though whether that is recommendation or not,\r\nyou must determine for yourselves.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have no objection to your calling in your friend if I may call in\r\nmine,\xe2\x80\x9d said the doctor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe must put it to the vote,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mr. Brownlow, \xe2\x80\x9cwho may he be?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat lady\xe2\x80\x99s son, and this young lady\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x94very old friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\ndoctor, motioning towards Mrs. Maylie, and concluding with an\r\nexpressive glance at her niece.\r\n\r\nRose blushed deeply, but she did not make any audible objection to this\r\nmotion (possibly she felt in a hopeless minority); and Harry Maylie and\r\nMr. Grimwig were accordingly added to the committee.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe stay in town, of course,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Maylie, \xe2\x80\x9cwhile there remains\r\nthe slightest prospect of prosecuting this inquiry with a chance of\r\nsuccess. I will spare neither trouble nor expense in behalf of the\r\nobject in which we are all so deeply interested, and I am content to\r\nremain here, if it be for twelve months, so long as you assure me that\r\nany hope remains.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood!\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined Mr. Brownlow. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd as I see on the faces about me, a\r\ndisposition to inquire how it happened that I was not in the way to\r\ncorroborate Oliver\xe2\x80\x99s tale, and had so suddenly left the kingdom, let me\r\nstipulate that I shall be asked no questions until such time as I may\r\ndeem it expedient to forestall them by telling my own story. Believe\r\nme, I make this request with good reason, for I might otherwise excite\r\nhopes destined never to be realised, and only increase difficulties and\r\ndisappointments already quite numerous enough. Come! Supper has been\r\nannounced, and young Oliver, who is all alone in the next room, will\r\nhave begun to think, by this time, that we have wearied of his company,\r\nand entered into some dark conspiracy to thrust him forth upon the\r\nworld.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith these words, the old gentleman gave his hand to Mrs. Maylie, and\r\nescorted her into the supper-room. Mr. Losberne followed, leading Rose;\r\nand the council was, for the present, effectually broken up.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n CHAPTER XLII.\r\nAN OLD ACQUAINTANCE OF OLIVER\xe2\x80\x99S, EXHIBITING DECIDED MARKS OF GENIUS,\r\nBECOMES A PUBLIC CHARACTER IN THE METROPOLIS\r\n\r\n\r\nUpon the night when Nancy, having lulled Mr. Sikes to sleep, hurried on\r\nher self-imposed mission to Rose Maylie, there advanced towards London,\r\nby the Great North Road, two persons, upon whom it is expedient that\r\nthis history should bestow some attention.\r\n\r\nThey were a man and woman; or perhaps they would be better described as\r\na male and female: for the former was one of those long-limbed,\r\nknock-kneed, shambling, bony people, to whom it is difficult to assign\r\nany precise age,\xe2\x80\x94looking as they do, when they are yet boys, like\r\nundergrown men, and when they are almost men, like overgrown boys. The\r\nwoman was young, but of a robust and hardy make, as she need have been\r\nto bear the weight of the heavy bundle which was strapped to her back.\r\nHer companion was not encumbered with much luggage, as there merely\r\ndangled from a stick which he carried over his shoulder, a small parcel\r\nwrapped in a common handkerchief, and apparently light enough. This\r\ncircumstance, added to the length of his legs, which were of unusual\r\nextent, enabled him with much ease to keep some half-dozen paces in\r\nadvance of his companion, to whom he occasionally turned with an\r\nimpatient jerk of the head: as if reproaching her tardiness, and urging\r\nher to greater exertion.\r\n\r\nThus, they had toiled along the dusty road, taking little heed of any\r\nobject within sight, save when they stepped aside to allow a wider\r\npassage for the mail-coaches which were whirling out of town, until\r\nthey passed through Highgate archway; when the foremost traveller\r\nstopped and called impatiently to his companion,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome on, can\xe2\x80\x99t yer? What a lazybones yer are, Charlotte.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a heavy load, I can tell you,\xe2\x80\x9d said the female, coming up, almost\r\nbreathless with fatigue.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHeavy! What are yer talking about? What are yer made for?\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined\r\nthe male traveller, changing his own little bundle as he spoke, to the\r\nother shoulder. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, there yer are, resting again! Well, if yer ain\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nenough to tire anybody\xe2\x80\x99s patience out, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what is!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it much farther?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the woman, resting herself against a bank,\r\nand looking up with the perspiration streaming from her face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMuch farther! Yer as good as there,\xe2\x80\x9d said the long-legged tramper,\r\npointing out before him. \xe2\x80\x9cLook there! Those are the lights of London.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re a good two mile off, at least,\xe2\x80\x9d said the woman despondingly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind whether they\xe2\x80\x99re two mile off, or twenty,\xe2\x80\x9d said Noah\r\nClaypole; for he it was; \xe2\x80\x9cbut get up and come on, or I\xe2\x80\x99ll kick yer, and\r\nso I give yer notice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs Noah\xe2\x80\x99s red nose grew redder with anger, and as he crossed the road\r\nwhile speaking, as if fully prepared to put his threat into execution,\r\nthe woman rose without any further remark, and trudged onward by his\r\nside.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere do you mean to stop for the night, Noah?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked, after they\r\nhad walked a few hundred yards.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow should I know?\xe2\x80\x9d replied Noah, whose temper had been considerably\r\nimpaired by walking.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNear, I hope,\xe2\x80\x9d said Charlotte.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, not near,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mr. Claypole. \xe2\x80\x9cThere! Not near; so don\xe2\x80\x99t think\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen I tell yer that I don\xe2\x80\x99t mean to do a thing, that\xe2\x80\x99s enough,\r\nwithout any why or because either,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mr. Claypole with dignity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you needn\xe2\x80\x99t be so cross,\xe2\x80\x9d said his companion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA pretty thing it would be, wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t it to go and stop at the very\r\nfirst public-house outside the town, so that Sowerberry, if he come up\r\nafter us, might poke in his old nose, and have us taken back in a cart\r\nwith handcuffs on,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Claypole in a jeering tone. \xe2\x80\x9cNo! I shall\r\ngo and lose myself among the narrowest streets I can find, and not stop\r\ntill we come to the very out-of-the-wayest house I can set eyes on.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCod, yer may thanks yer stars I\xe2\x80\x99ve got a head; for if we hadn\xe2\x80\x99t gone,\r\nat first, the wrong road a purpose, and come back across country, yer\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nhave been locked up hard and fast a week ago, my lady. And serve yer\r\nright for being a fool.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know I ain\xe2\x80\x99t as cunning as you are,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Charlotte; \xe2\x80\x9cbut don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nput all the blame on me, and say I should have been locked up. You\r\nwould have been if I had been, any way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYer took the money from the till, yer know yer did,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr.\r\nClaypole.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI took it for you, Noah, dear,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined Charlotte.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid I keep it?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Mr. Claypole.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; you trusted in me, and let me carry it like a dear, and so you\r\nare,\xe2\x80\x9d said the lady, chucking him under the chin, and drawing her arm\r\nthrough his.\r\n\r\nThis was indeed the case; but as it was not Mr. Claypole\xe2\x80\x99s habit to\r\nrepose a blind and foolish confidence in anybody, it should be\r\nobserved, in justice to that gentleman, that he had trusted Charlotte\r\nto this extent, in order that, if they were pursued, the money might be\r\nfound on her: which would leave him an opportunity of asserting his\r\ninnocence of any theft, and would greatly facilitate his chances of\r\nescape. Of course, he entered at this juncture, into no explanation of\r\nhis motives, and they walked on very lovingly together.\r\n\r\nIn pursuance of this cautious plan, Mr. Claypole went on, without\r\nhalting, until he arrived at the Angel at Islington, where he wisely\r\njudged, from the crowd of passengers and numbers of vehicles, that\r\nLondon began in earnest. Just pausing to observe which appeared the\r\nmost crowded streets, and consequently the most to be avoided, he\r\ncrossed into Saint John\xe2\x80\x99s Road, and was soon deep in the obscurity of\r\nthe intricate and dirty ways, which, lying between Gray\xe2\x80\x99s Inn Lane and\r\nSmithfield, render that part of the town one of the lowest and worst\r\nthat improvement has left in the midst of London.\r\n\r\nThrough these streets, Noah Claypole walked, dragging Charlotte after\r\nhim; now stepping into the kennel to embrace at a glance the whole\r\nexternal character of some small public-house; now jogging on again, as\r\nsome fancied appearance induced him to believe it too public for his\r\npurpose. At length, he stopped in front of one, more humble in\r\nappearance and more dirty than any he had yet seen; and, having crossed\r\nover and surveyed it from the opposite pavement, graciously announced\r\nhis intention of putting up there, for the night.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo give us the bundle,\xe2\x80\x9d said Noah, unstrapping it from the woman\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nshoulders, and slinging it over his own; \xe2\x80\x9cand don\xe2\x80\x99t yer speak, except\r\nwhen yer spoke to. What\xe2\x80\x99s the name of the house\xe2\x80\x94t-h-r\xe2\x80\x94three what?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCripples,\xe2\x80\x9d said Charlotte.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThree Cripples,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Noah, \xe2\x80\x9cand a very good sign too. Now, then!\r\nKeep close at my heels, and come along.\xe2\x80\x9d With these injunctions, he\r\npushed the rattling door with his shoulder, and entered the house,\r\nfollowed by his companion.\r\n\r\nThere was nobody in the bar but a young Jew, who, with his two elbows\r\non the counter, was reading a dirty newspaper. He stared very hard at\r\nNoah, and Noah stared very hard at him.\r\n\r\nIf Noah had been attired in his charity-boy\xe2\x80\x99s dress, there might have\r\nbeen some reason for the Jew opening his eyes so wide; but as he had\r\ndiscarded the coat and badge, and wore a short smock-frock over his\r\nleathers, there seemed no particular reason for his appearance exciting\r\nso much attention in a public-house.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs this the Three Cripples?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Noah.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is the dabe of this \xe2\x80\x99ouse,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Jew.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA gentleman we met on the road, coming up from the country,\r\nrecommended us here,\xe2\x80\x9d said Noah, nudging Charlotte, perhaps to call her\r\nattention to this most ingenious device for attracting respect, and\r\nperhaps to warn her to betray no surprise. \xe2\x80\x9cWe want to sleep here\r\nto-night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99b dot certaid you cad,\xe2\x80\x9d said Barney, who was the attendant sprite;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cbut I\xe2\x80\x99ll idquire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShow us the tap, and give us a bit of cold meat and a drop of beer\r\nwhile yer inquiring, will yer?\xe2\x80\x9d said Noah.\r\n\r\nBarney complied by ushering them into a small back-room, and setting\r\nthe required viands before them; having done which, he informed the\r\ntravellers that they could be lodged that night, and left the amiable\r\ncouple to their refreshment.\r\n\r\nNow, this back-room was immediately behind the bar, and some steps\r\nlower, so that any person connected with the house, undrawing a small\r\ncurtain which concealed a single pane of glass fixed in the wall of the\r\nlast-named apartment, about five feet from its flooring, could not only\r\nlook down upon any guests in the back-room without any great hazard of\r\nbeing observed (the glass being in a dark angle of the wall, between\r\nwhich and a large upright beam the observer had to thrust himself), but\r\ncould, by applying his ear to the partition, ascertain with tolerable\r\ndistinctness, their subject of conversation. The landlord of the house\r\nhad not withdrawn his eye from this place of espial for five minutes,\r\nand Barney had only just returned from making the communication above\r\nrelated, when Fagin, in the course of his evening\xe2\x80\x99s business, came into\r\nthe bar to inquire after some of his young pupils.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHush!\xe2\x80\x9d said Barney: \xe2\x80\x9cstradegers id the next roob.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStrangers!\xe2\x80\x9d repeated the old man in a whisper.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! Ad rub uds too,\xe2\x80\x9d added Barney. \xe2\x80\x9cFrob the cuttry, but subthig in\r\nyour way, or I\xe2\x80\x99b bistaked.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFagin appeared to receive this communication with great interest.\r\n\r\nMounting a stool, he cautiously applied his eye to the pane of glass,\r\nfrom which secret post he could see Mr. Claypole taking cold beef from\r\nthe dish, and porter from the pot, and administering homeopathic doses\r\nof both to Charlotte, who sat patiently by, eating and drinking at his\r\npleasure.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAha!\xe2\x80\x9d he whispered, looking round to Barney, \xe2\x80\x9cI like that fellow\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nlooks. He\xe2\x80\x99d be of use to us; he knows how to train the girl already.\r\nDon\xe2\x80\x99t make as much noise as a mouse, my dear, and let me hear \xe2\x80\x99em\r\ntalk\xe2\x80\x94let me hear \xe2\x80\x99em.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe again applied his eye to the glass, and turning his ear to the\r\npartition, listened attentively: with a subtle and eager look upon his\r\nface, that might have appertained to some old goblin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo I mean to be a gentleman,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Claypole, kicking out his legs,\r\nand continuing a conversation, the commencement of which Fagin had\r\narrived too late to hear. \xe2\x80\x9cNo more jolly old coffins, Charlotte, but a\r\ngentleman\xe2\x80\x99s life for me: and, if yer like, yer shall be a lady.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should like that well enough, dear,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Charlotte; \xe2\x80\x9cbut tills\r\nain\xe2\x80\x99t to be emptied every day, and people to get clear off after it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTills be blowed!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Claypole; \xe2\x80\x9cthere\xe2\x80\x99s more things besides\r\ntills to be emptied.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d asked his companion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPockets, women\xe2\x80\x99s ridicules, houses, mail-coaches, banks!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr.\r\nClaypole, rising with the porter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you can\xe2\x80\x99t do all that, dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said Charlotte.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall look out to get into company with them as can,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Noah.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99ll be able to make us useful some way or another. Why, you\r\nyourself are worth fifty women; I never see such a precious sly and\r\ndeceitful creetur as yer can be when I let yer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLor, how nice it is to hear yer say so!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Charlotte,\r\nimprinting a kiss upon his ugly face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere, that\xe2\x80\x99ll do: don\xe2\x80\x99t yer be too affectionate, in case I\xe2\x80\x99m cross\r\nwith yer,\xe2\x80\x9d said Noah, disengaging himself with great gravity. \xe2\x80\x9cI should\r\nlike to be the captain of some band, and have the whopping of \xe2\x80\x99em, and\r\nfollering \xe2\x80\x99em about, unbeknown to themselves. That would suit me, if\r\nthere was good profit; and if we could only get in with some gentleman\r\nof this sort, I say it would be cheap at that twenty-pound note you\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\ngot,\xe2\x80\x94especially as we don\xe2\x80\x99t very well know how to get rid of it\r\nourselves.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAfter expressing this opinion, Mr. Claypole looked into the porter-pot\r\nwith an aspect of deep wisdom; and having well shaken its contents,\r\nnodded condescendingly to Charlotte, and took a draught, wherewith he\r\nappeared greatly refreshed. He was meditating another, when the sudden\r\nopening of the door, and the appearance of a stranger, interrupted him.\r\n\r\nThe stranger was Mr. Fagin. And very amiable he looked, and a very low\r\nbow he made, as he advanced, and setting himself down at the nearest\r\ntable, ordered something to drink of the grinning Barney.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA pleasant night, sir, but cool for the time of year,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fagin,\r\nrubbing his hands. \xe2\x80\x9cFrom the country, I see, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow do yer see that?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Noah Claypole.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe have not so much dust as that in London,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Fagin, pointing\r\nfrom Noah\xe2\x80\x99s shoes to those of his companion, and from them to the two\r\nbundles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYer a sharp feller,\xe2\x80\x9d said Noah. \xe2\x80\x9cHa! ha! only hear that, Charlotte!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, one need be sharp in this town, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Jew,\r\nsinking his voice to a confidential whisper; \xe2\x80\x9cand that\xe2\x80\x99s the truth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFagin followed up this remark by striking the side of his nose with his\r\nright forefinger,\xe2\x80\x94a gesture which Noah attempted to imitate, though not\r\nwith complete success, in consequence of his own nose not being large\r\nenough for the purpose. By Fagin\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndirections, he immediately substituted for his own attire, a waggoner\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfrock, velveteen breeches, and leather leggings: all of which articles\r\nthe Jew had at hand.
