Thus equipped, he\r\nwas to saunter into the office, as some country fellow from Covent\r\nGarden market might be supposed to do for the gratification of his\r\ncuriousity; and as he was as awkward, ungainly, and raw-boned a fellow\r\nas need be, Mr. Fagin had no fear but that he would look the part to\r\nperfection.\r\n\r\nThese arrangements completed, he was informed of the necessary signs\r\nand tokens by which to recognise the Artful Dodger, and was conveyed by\r\nMaster Bates through dark and winding ways to within a very short\r\ndistance of Bow Street. Having described the precise situation of the\r\noffice, and accompanied it with copious directions how he was to walk\r\nstraight up the passage, and when he got into the side, and pull off\r\nhis hat as he went into the room, Charley Bates bade him hurry on\r\nalone, and promised to bide his return on the spot of their parting.\r\n\r\nNoah Claypole, or Morris Bolter as the reader pleases, punctually\r\nfollowed the directions he had received, which\xe2\x80\x94Master Bates being\r\npretty well acquainted with the locality\xe2\x80\x94were so exact that he was\r\nenabled to gain the magisterial presence without asking any question,\r\nor meeting with any interruption by the way.\r\n\r\nHe found himself jostled among a crowd of people, chiefly women, who\r\nwere huddled together in a dirty frowsy room, at the upper end of which\r\nwas a raised platform railed off from the rest, with a dock for the\r\nprisoners on the left hand against the wall, a box for the witnesses in\r\nthe middle, and a desk for the magistrates on the right; the awful\r\nlocality last named, being screened off by a partition which concealed\r\nthe bench from the common gaze, and left the vulgar to imagine (if they\r\ncould) the full majesty of justice.\r\n\r\nThere were only a couple of women in the dock, who were nodding to\r\ntheir admiring friends, while the clerk read some depositions to a\r\ncouple of policemen and a man in plain clothes who leant over the\r\ntable. A jailer stood reclining against the dock-rail, tapping his nose\r\nlistlessly with a large key, except when he repressed an undue tendency\r\nto conversation among the idlers, by proclaiming silence; or looked\r\nsternly up to bid some woman \xe2\x80\x9cTake that baby out,\xe2\x80\x9d when the gravity of\r\njustice was disturbed by feeble cries, half-smothered in the mother\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nshawl, from some meagre infant. The room smelt close and unwholesome;\r\nthe walls were dirt-discoloured; and the ceiling blackened. There was\r\nan old smoky bust over the mantel-shelf, and a dusty clock above the\r\ndock\xe2\x80\x94the only thing present, that seemed to go on as it ought; for\r\ndepravity, or poverty, or an habitual acquaintance with both, had left\r\na taint on all the animate matter, hardly less unpleasant than the\r\nthick greasy scum on every inanimate object that frowned upon it.\r\n\r\nNoah looked eagerly about him for the Dodger; but although there were\r\nseveral women who would have done very well for that distinguished\r\ncharacter\xe2\x80\x99s mother or sister, and more than one man who might be\r\nsupposed to bear a strong resemblance to his father, nobody at all\r\nanswering the description given him of Mr. Dawkins was to be seen. He\r\nwaited in a state of much suspense and uncertainty until the women,\r\nbeing committed for trial, went flaunting out; and then was quickly\r\nrelieved by the appearance of another prisoner who he felt at once\r\ncould be no other than the object of his visit.\r\n\r\nIt was indeed Mr. Dawkins, who, shuffling into the office with the big\r\ncoat sleeves tucked up as usual, his left hand in his pocket, and his\r\nhat in his right hand, preceded the jailer, with a rolling gait\r\naltogether indescribable, and, taking his place in the dock, requested\r\nin an audible voice to know what he was placed in that \xe2\x80\x99ere disgraceful\r\nsitivation for.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold your tongue, will you?\xe2\x80\x9d said the jailer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m an Englishman, ain\xe2\x80\x99t I?\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined the Dodger. \xe2\x80\x9cWhere are my\r\npriwileges?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll get your privileges soon enough,\xe2\x80\x9d retorted the jailer, \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\npepper with \xe2\x80\x99em.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll see wot the Secretary of State for the Home Affairs has got to\r\nsay to the beaks, if I don\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mr. Dawkins. \xe2\x80\x9cNow then! Wot is\r\nthis here business? I shall thank the madg\xe2\x80\x99strates to dispose of this\r\nhere little affair, and not to keep me while they read the paper, for\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ve got an appointment with a genelman in the City, and as I am a man\r\nof my word and wery punctual in business matters, he\xe2\x80\x99ll go away if I\r\nain\xe2\x80\x99t there to my time, and then pr\xe2\x80\x99aps ther won\xe2\x80\x99t be an action for\r\ndamage against them as kep me away. Oh no, certainly not!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this point, the Dodger, with a show of being very particular with a\r\nview to proceedings to be had thereafter, desired the jailer to\r\ncommunicate \xe2\x80\x9cthe names of them two files as was on the bench.\xe2\x80\x9d Which so\r\ntickled the spectators, that they laughed almost as heartily as Master\r\nBates could have done if he had heard the request.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSilence there!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the jailer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is this?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired one of the magistrates.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA pick-pocketing case, your worship.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas the boy ever been here before?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe ought to have been, a many times,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the jailer. \xe2\x80\x9cHe has been\r\npretty well everywhere else. _I_ know him well, your worship.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! you know me, do you?\xe2\x80\x9d cried the Artful, making a note of the\r\nstatement. \xe2\x80\x9cWery good. That\xe2\x80\x99s a case of deformation of character, any\r\nway.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHere there was another laugh, and another cry of silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow then, where are the witnesses?\xe2\x80\x9d said the clerk.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! that\xe2\x80\x99s right,\xe2\x80\x9d added the Dodger. \xe2\x80\x9cWhere are they? I should like to\r\nsee \xe2\x80\x99em.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis wish was immediately gratified, for a policeman stepped forward\r\nwho had seen the prisoner attempt the pocket of an unknown gentleman in\r\na crowd, and indeed take a handkerchief therefrom, which, being a very\r\nold one, he deliberately put back again, after trying it on his own\r\ncountenance. For this reason, he took the Dodger into custody as soon\r\nas he could get near him, and the said Dodger, being searched, had upon\r\nhis person a silver snuff-box, with the owner\xe2\x80\x99s name engraved upon the\r\nlid. This gentleman had been discovered on reference to the Court\r\nGuide, and being then and there present, swore that the snuff-box was\r\nhis, and that he had missed it on the previous day, the moment he had\r\ndisengaged himself from the crowd before referred to. He had also\r\nremarked a young gentleman in the throng, particularly active in making\r\nhis way about, and that young gentleman was the prisoner before him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you anything to ask this witness, boy?\xe2\x80\x9d said the magistrate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t abase myself by descending to hold no conversation with\r\nhim,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Dodger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you anything to say at all?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you hear his worship ask if you\xe2\x80\x99ve anything to say?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the\r\njailer, nudging the silent Dodger with his elbow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI beg your pardon,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Dodger, looking up with an air of\r\nabstraction. \xe2\x80\x9cDid you redress yourself to me, my man?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never see such an out-and-out young wagabond, your worship,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nobserved the officer with a grin. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you mean to say anything, you\r\nyoung shaver?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Dodger, \xe2\x80\x9cnot here, for this ain\xe2\x80\x99t the shop for\r\njustice: besides which, my attorney is a-breakfasting this morning with\r\nthe Wice President of the House of Commons; but I shall have something\r\nto say elsewhere, and so will he, and so will a wery numerous and\r\n\xe2\x80\x99spectable circle of acquaintance as\xe2\x80\x99ll make them beaks wish they\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nnever been born, or that they\xe2\x80\x99d got their footmen to hang \xe2\x80\x99em up to\r\ntheir own hat-pegs, afore they let \xe2\x80\x99em come out this morning to try it\r\non upon me. I\xe2\x80\x99ll\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere! He\xe2\x80\x99s fully committed!\xe2\x80\x9d interposed the clerk. \xe2\x80\x9cTake him away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome on,\xe2\x80\x9d said the jailer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh ah! I\xe2\x80\x99ll come on,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Dodger, brushing his hat with the\r\npalm of his hand. \xe2\x80\x9cAh! (to the Bench) it\xe2\x80\x99s no use your looking\r\nfrightened; I won\xe2\x80\x99t show you no mercy, not a ha\xe2\x80\x99porth of it. _You\xe2\x80\x99ll_\r\npay for this, my fine fellers. I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be you for something! I\r\nwouldn\xe2\x80\x99t go free, now, if you was to fall down on your knees and ask\r\nme. Here, carry me off to prison! Take me away!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith these last words, the Dodger suffered himself to be led off by the\r\ncollar; threatening, till he got into the yard, to make a parliamentary\r\nbusiness of it; and then grinning in the officer\xe2\x80\x99s face, with great\r\nglee and self-approval.\r\n\r\nHaving seen him locked up by himself in a little cell, Noah made the\r\nbest of his way back to where he had left Master Bates. After waiting\r\nhere some time, he was joined by that young gentleman, who had\r\nprudently abstained from showing himself until he had looked carefully\r\nabroad from a snug retreat, and ascertained that his new friend had not\r\nbeen followed by any impertinent person.\r\n\r\nThe two hastened back together, to bear to Mr. Fagin the animating news\r\nthat the Dodger was doing full justice to his bringing-up, and\r\nestablishing for himself a glorious reputation.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n CHAPTER XLIV.\r\nTHE TIME ARRIVES FOR NANCY TO REDEEM HER PLEDGE TO ROSE MAYLIE. SHE\r\nFAILS.\r\n\r\n\r\nAdept as she was, in all the arts of cunning and dissimulation, the\r\ngirl Nancy could not wholly conceal the effect which the knowledge of\r\nthe step she had taken, wrought upon her mind. She remembered that both\r\nthe crafty Jew and the brutal Sikes had confided to her schemes, which\r\nhad been hidden from all others: in the full confidence that she was\r\ntrustworthy and beyond the reach of their suspicion. Vile as those\r\nschemes were, desperate as were their originators, and bitter as were\r\nher feelings towards Fagin, who had led her, step by step, deeper and\r\ndeeper down into an abyss of crime and misery, whence was no escape;\r\nstill, there were times when, even towards him, she felt some\r\nrelenting, lest her disclosure should bring him within the iron grasp\r\nhe had so long eluded, and he should fall at last\xe2\x80\x94richly as he merited\r\nsuch a fate\xe2\x80\x94by her hand.\r\n\r\nBut, these were the mere wanderings of a mind unable wholly to detach\r\nitself from old companions and associations, though enabled to fix\r\nitself steadily on one object, and resolved not to be turned aside by\r\nany consideration. Her fears for Sikes would have been more powerful\r\ninducements to recoil while there was yet time; but she had stipulated\r\nthat her secret should be rigidly kept, she had dropped no clue which\r\ncould lead to his discovery, she had refused, even for his sake, a\r\nrefuge from all the guilt and wretchedness that encompasses her\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nwhat more could she do! She was resolved.\r\n\r\nThough all her mental struggles terminated in this conclusion, they\r\nforced themselves upon her, again and again, and left their traces too.\r\nShe grew pale and thin, even within a few days. At times, she took no\r\nheed of what was passing before her, or no part in conversations where\r\nonce, she would have been the loudest. At other times, she laughed\r\nwithout merriment, and was noisy without a moment afterwards\xe2\x80\x94she sat\r\nsilent and dejected, brooding with her head upon her hands, while the\r\nvery effort by which she roused herself, told, more forcibly than even\r\nthese indications, that she was ill at ease, and that her thoughts were\r\noccupied with matters very different and distant from those in the\r\ncourse of discussion by her companions.\r\n\r\nIt was Sunday night, and the bell of the nearest church struck the\r\nhour. Sikes and the Jew were talking, but they paused to listen. The\r\ngirl looked up from the low seat on which she crouched, and listened\r\ntoo. Eleven.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAn hour this side of midnight,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sikes, raising the blind to look\r\nout and returning to his seat. \xe2\x80\x9cDark and heavy it is too. A good night\r\nfor business this.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Fagin. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat a pity, Bill, my dear, that there\xe2\x80\x99s none\r\nquite ready to be done.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re right for once,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Sikes gruffly. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is a pity, for I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nin the humour too.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFagin sighed, and shook his head despondingly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe must make up for lost time when we\xe2\x80\x99ve got things into a good train.\r\nThat\xe2\x80\x99s all I know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sikes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s the way to talk, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Fagin, venturing to pat him\r\non the shoulder. \xe2\x80\x9cIt does me good to hear you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes you good, does it!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Sikes. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, so be it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHa! ha! ha!\xe2\x80\x9d laughed Fagin, as if he were relieved by even this\r\nconcession. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re like yourself to-night, Bill. Quite like yourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t feel like myself when you lay that withered old claw on my\r\nshoulder, so take it away,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sikes, casting off the Jew\xe2\x80\x99s hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt make you nervous, Bill,\xe2\x80\x94reminds you of being nabbed, does it?\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nFagin, determined not to be offended.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReminds me of being nabbed by the devil,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Sikes. \xe2\x80\x9cThere never\r\nwas another man with such a face as yours, unless it was your father,\r\nand I suppose _he_ is singeing his grizzled red beard by this time,\r\nunless you came straight from the old \xe2\x80\x99un without any father at all\r\nbetwixt you; which I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t wonder at, a bit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFagin offered no reply to this compliment: but, pulling Sikes by the\r\nsleeve, pointed his finger towards Nancy, who had taken advantage of\r\nthe foregoing conversation to put on her bonnet, and was now leaving\r\nthe room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHallo!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Sikes. \xe2\x80\x9cNance. Where\xe2\x80\x99s the gal going to at this time of\r\nnight?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot far.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat answer\xe2\x80\x99s that?\xe2\x80\x9d retorted Sikes. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you hear me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know where,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the girl.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen I do,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sikes, more in the spirit of obstinacy than because\r\nhe had any real objection to the girl going where she listed. \xe2\x80\x9cNowhere.\r\nSit down.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not well. I told you that before,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined the girl. \xe2\x80\x9cI want a\r\nbreath of air.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPut your head out of the winder,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Sikes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s not enough there,\xe2\x80\x9d said the girl. \xe2\x80\x9cI want it in the street.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you won\xe2\x80\x99t have it,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Sikes. With which assurance he rose,\r\nlocked the door, took the key out, and pulling her bonnet from her\r\nhead, flung it up to the top of an old press. \xe2\x80\x9cThere,\xe2\x80\x9d said the robber.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow stop quietly where you are, will you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s not such a matter as a bonnet would keep me,\xe2\x80\x9d said the girl\r\nturning very pale. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean, Bill? Do you know what you\xe2\x80\x99re\r\ndoing?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKnow what I\xe2\x80\x99m\xe2\x80\x94Oh!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Sikes, turning to Fagin, \xe2\x80\x9cshe\xe2\x80\x99s out of her\r\nsenses, you know, or she daren\xe2\x80\x99t talk to me in that way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll drive me on the something desperate,\xe2\x80\x9d muttered the girl placing\r\nboth hands upon her breast, as though to keep down by force some\r\nviolent outbreak. \xe2\x80\x9cLet me go, will you,\xe2\x80\x94this minute\xe2\x80\x94this instant.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo!\xe2\x80\x9d said Sikes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell him to let me go, Fagin. He had better. It\xe2\x80\x99ll be better for him.\r\nDo you hear me?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Nancy stamping her foot upon the ground.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHear you!\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Sikes turning round in his chair to confront her.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAye! And if I hear you for half a minute longer, the dog shall have\r\nsuch a grip on your throat as\xe2\x80\x99ll tear some of that screaming voice out.\r\nWot has come over you, you jade! Wot is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me go,\xe2\x80\x9d said the girl with great earnestness; then sitting herself\r\ndown on the floor, before the door, she said, \xe2\x80\x9cBill, let me go; you\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t know what you are doing. You don\xe2\x80\x99t, indeed. For only one\r\nhour\xe2\x80\x94do\xe2\x80\x94do!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCut my limbs off one by one!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Sikes, seizing her roughly by the\r\narm, \xe2\x80\x9cIf I don\xe2\x80\x99t think the gal\xe2\x80\x99s stark raving mad. Get up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot till you let me go\xe2\x80\x94not till you let me go\xe2\x80\x94Never\xe2\x80\x94never!\xe2\x80\x9d screamed\r\nthe girl. Sikes looked on, for a minute, watching his opportunity, and\r\nsuddenly pinioning her hands dragged her, struggling and wrestling with\r\nhim by the way, into a small room adjoining, where he sat himself on a\r\nbench, and thrusting her into a chair, held her down by force. She\r\nstruggled and implored by turns until twelve o\xe2\x80\x99clock had struck, and\r\nthen, wearied and exhausted, ceased to contest the point any further.\r\nWith a caution, backed by many oaths, to make no more efforts to go out\r\nthat night, Sikes left her to recover at leisure and rejoined Fagin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhew!\xe2\x80\x9d said the housebreaker wiping the perspiration from his face.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWot a precious strange gal that is!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou may say that, Bill,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Fagin thoughtfully. \xe2\x80\x9cYou may say\r\nthat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWot did she take it into her head to go out to-night for, do you\r\nthink?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Sikes. \xe2\x80\x9cCome; you should know her better than me. Wot\r\ndoes it mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cObstinacy; woman\xe2\x80\x99s obstinacy, I suppose, my dear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I suppose it is,\xe2\x80\x9d growled Sikes. \xe2\x80\x9cI thought I had tamed her, but\r\nshe\xe2\x80\x99s as bad as ever.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWorse,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fagin thoughtfully. \xe2\x80\x9cI never knew her like this, for such\r\na little cause.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNor I,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sikes. \xe2\x80\x9cI think she\xe2\x80\x99s got a touch of that fever in her\r\nblood yet, and it won\xe2\x80\x99t come out\xe2\x80\x94eh?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLike enough.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll let her a little blood, without troubling the doctor, if she\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ntook that way again,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sikes.\r\n\r\nFagin nodded an expressive approval of this mode of treatment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe was hanging about me all day, and night too, when I was stretched\r\non my back; and you, like a blackhearted wolf as you are, kept yourself\r\naloof,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sikes. \xe2\x80\x9cWe was poor too, all the time, and I think, one\r\nway or other, it\xe2\x80\x99s worried and fretted her; and that being shut up here\r\nso long has made her restless\xe2\x80\x94eh?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s it, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Jew in a whisper. \xe2\x80\x9cHush!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs he uttered these words, the girl herself appeared and resumed her\r\nformer seat. Her eyes were swollen and red; she rocked herself to and\r\nfro; tossed her head; and, after a little time, burst out laughing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, now she\xe2\x80\x99s on the other tack!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Sikes, turning a look of\r\nexcessive surprise on his companion.\r\n\r\nFagin nodded to him to take no further notice just then; and, in a few\r\nminutes, the girl subsided into her accustomed demeanour. Whispering\r\nSikes that there was no fear of her relapsing, Fagin took up his hat\r\nand bade him good-night. He paused when he reached the room-door, and\r\nlooking round, asked if somebody would light him down the dark stairs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLight him down,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sikes, who was filling his pipe. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a pity he\r\nshould break his neck himself, and disappoint the sight-seers. Show him\r\na light.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNancy followed the old man downstairs, with a candle. When they reached\r\nthe passage, he laid his finger on his lip, and drawing close to the\r\ngirl, said, in a whisper.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it, Nancy, dear?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d replied the girl, in the same tone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe reason of all this,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Fagin. \xe2\x80\x9cIf _he_\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he pointed with his\r\nskinny fore-finger up the stairs\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cis so hard with you (he\xe2\x80\x99s a brute,\r\nNance, a brute-beast), why don\xe2\x80\x99t you\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d said the girl, as Fagin paused, with his mouth almost touching\r\nher ear, and his eyes looking into hers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo matter just now. We\xe2\x80\x99ll talk of this again. You have a friend in me,\r\nNance; a staunch friend. I have the means at hand, quiet and close. If\r\nyou want revenge on those that treat you like a dog\xe2\x80\x94like a dog! worse\r\nthan his dog, for he humours him sometimes\xe2\x80\x94come to me. I say, come to\r\nme. He is the mere hound of a day, but you know me of old, Nance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know you well,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the girl, without manifesting the least\r\nemotion. \xe2\x80\x9cGood-night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe shrank back, as Fagin offered to lay his hand on hers, but said\r\ngood-night again, in a steady voice, and, answering his parting look\r\nwith a nod of intelligence, closed the door between them.\r\n\r\nFagin walked towards his home, intent upon the thoughts that were\r\nworking within his brain. He had conceived the idea\xe2\x80\x94not from what had\r\njust passed though that had tended to confirm him, but slowly and by\r\ndegrees\xe2\x80\x94that Nancy, wearied of the housebreaker\xe2\x80\x99s brutality, had\r\nconceived an attachment for some new friend. Her altered manner, her\r\nrepeated absences from home alone, her comparative indifference to the\r\ninterests of the gang for which she had once been so zealous, and,\r\nadded to these, her desperate impatience to leave home that night at a\r\nparticular hour, all favoured the supposition, and rendered it, to him\r\nat least, almost matter of certainty. The object of this new liking was\r\nnot among his myrmidons. He would be a valuable acquisition with such\r\nan assistant as Nancy, and must (thus Fagin argued) be secured without\r\ndelay.\r\n\r\nThere was another, and a darker object, to be gained. Sikes knew too\r\nmuch, and his ruffian taunts had not galled Fagin the less, because the\r\nwounds were hidden. The girl must know, well, that if she shook him\r\noff, she could never be safe from his fury, and that it would be surely\r\nwreaked\xe2\x80\x94to the maiming of limbs, or perhaps the loss of life\xe2\x80\x94on the\r\nobject of her more recent fancy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith a little persuasion,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Fagin, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat more likely than that\r\nshe would consent to poison him? Women have done such things, and\r\nworse, to secure the same object before now. There would be the\r\ndangerous villain: the man I hate: gone; another secured in his place;\r\nand my influence over the girl, with a knowledge of this crime to back\r\nit, unlimited.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThese things passed through the mind of Fagin, during the short time he\r\nsat alone, in the housebreaker\xe2\x80\x99s room; and with them uppermost in his\r\nthoughts, he had taken the opportunity afterwards afforded him, of\r\nsounding the girl in the broken hints he threw out at parting. There\r\nwas no expression of surprise, no assumption of an inability to\r\nunderstand his meaning. The girl clearly comprehended it. Her glance at\r\nparting showed _that_.\r\n\r\nBut perhaps she would recoil from a plot to take the life of Sikes, and\r\nthat was one of the chief ends to be attained. \xe2\x80\x9cHow,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Fagin, as\r\nhe crept homeward, \xe2\x80\x9ccan I increase my influence with her? What new\r\npower can I acquire?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSuch brains are fertile in expedients. If, without extracting a\r\nconfession from herself, he laid a watch, discovered the object of her\r\naltered regard, and threatened to reveal the whole history to Sikes (of\r\nwhom she stood in no common fear) unless she entered into his designs,\r\ncould he not secure her compliance?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fagin, almost aloud. \xe2\x80\x9cShe durst not refuse me then. Not\r\nfor her life, not for her life! I have it all. The means are ready, and\r\nshall be set to work. I shall have you yet!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe cast back a dark look, and a threatening motion of the hand, towards\r\nthe spot where he had left the bolder villain; and went on his way:\r\nbusying his bony hands in the folds of his tattered garment, which he\r\nwrenched tightly in his grasp, as though there were a hated enemy\r\ncrushed with every motion of his fingers.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n CHAPTER XLV.\r\nNOAH CLAYPOLE IS EMPLOYED BY FAGIN ON A SECRET MISSION\r\n\r\n\r\nThe old man was up, betimes, next morning, and waited impatiently for\r\nthe appearance of his new associate, who after a delay that seemed\r\ninterminable, at length presented himself, and commenced a voracious\r\nassault on the breakfast.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBolter,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fagin, drawing up a chair and seating himself opposite\r\nMorris Bolter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, here I am,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Noah. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter? Don\xe2\x80\x99t yer ask me\r\nto do anything till I have done eating. That\xe2\x80\x99s a great fault in this\r\nplace. Yer never get time enough over yer meals.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou can talk as you eat, can\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d said Fagin, cursing his dear\r\nyoung friend\xe2\x80\x99s greediness from the very bottom of his heart.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh yes, I can talk. I get on better when I talk,\xe2\x80\x9d said Noah, cutting a\r\nmonstrous slice of bread. \xe2\x80\x9cWhere\xe2\x80\x99s Charlotte?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOut,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fagin. \xe2\x80\x9cI sent her out this morning with the other young\r\nwoman, because I wanted us to be alone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d said Noah. \xe2\x80\x9cI wish yer\xe2\x80\x99d ordered her to make some buttered toast\r\nfirst. Well. Talk away. Yer won\xe2\x80\x99t interrupt me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere seemed, indeed, no great fear of anything interrupting him, as he\r\nhad evidently sat down with a determination to do a great deal of\r\nbusiness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou did well yesterday, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fagin. \xe2\x80\x9cBeautiful! Six\r\nshillings and ninepence halfpenny on the very first day! The kinchin\r\nlay will be a fortune to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you forget to add three pint-pots and a milk-can,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr.\r\nBolter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no, my dear. The pint-pots were great strokes of genius: but the\r\nmilk-can was a perfect masterpiece.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPretty well, I think, for a beginner,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked Mr. Bolter\r\ncomplacently. \xe2\x80\x9cThe pots I took off airy railings, and the milk-can was\r\nstanding by itself outside a public-house. Ha! ha! ha!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFagin affected to laugh very heartily; and Mr. Bolter having had his\r\nlaugh out, took a series of large bites, which finished his first hunk\r\nof bread and butter, and assisted himself to a second.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want you, Bolter,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fagin, leaning over the table, \xe2\x80\x9cto do a\r\npiece of work for me, my dear, that needs great care and caution.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined Bolter, \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t yer go shoving me into danger, or\r\nsending me any more o\xe2\x80\x99 yer police-offices. Not\r\nto\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot to do anything, but to tell me where she goes, who she sees, and,\r\nif possible, what she says; to remember the street, if it is a street,\r\nor the house, if it is a house; and to bring me back all the\r\ninformation you can.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99ll yer give me?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Noah, setting down his cup, and looking\r\nhis employer, eagerly, in the face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you do it well, a pound, my dear. Ha! ha! ha! I\xe2\x80\x99m your man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI knew you would be,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Fagin, elated by the success of his\r\nproposal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course, of course,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Noah. \xe2\x80\x9cWhere is she? Where am I to wait\r\nfor her? Where am I to go?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll that, my dear, you shall hear from me.
